name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Friday, 19 June 2020.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The final draft agenda (654.272/PDOJ), established by the Conference of Presidents pursuant to Rule 158 of the Rules of Procedure, has been distributed.  A number of amendments have been tabled. I would like to inform you that I have received two requests for urgent procedure, pursuant to Rule 163 of the Rules of Procedure, to add the following legislative documents during this part-session. The first concerns transitional arrangements to deal with the effects of the COVID-19 crisis. The second concerns the carrying out of clinical trials with medicinal products for human use containing or intended genetically modified organisms intended for the treatment or prevention of coronavirus disease and the supply of such medicines. These requests will be voted on today in the first voting session. Under the Rules of Procedure, only the authors of the requests and one speaker against, as well as the chairmen or rapporteurs of the relevant committees, may be heard. Is there anyone in this House who wishes to speak on the request for urgent procedure on transitional arrangements in order to deal with the effects of the COVID-19 crisis?  No, no one is asking for the floor. Is there anyone in this House who wishes to speak on the request for urgent procedure on the carrying out of clinical trials and the supply of medicines? I give the floor to Mr Beazley. Kateřina Konečná, who asked to speak against this request.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Mr President, the GUE/NGL would, in the light of the crisis, be open to make an exception from our strict approach towards the GMOs. Nevertheless, our flexibility is not unconditional. To limit the possibility of misuse of the derogations of all safety obligations in the GMO legislation, we think it should be limited to only vaccines. The proposed derogation needs to be limited in time. According to the proposal, an environmental risk assessment may be delayed for up to several years, during which time the potential risk to human health and the environment will remain. Finally, we stress that the public should be informed about the GMOs being used in the trials. The Dutch advisory body also calls this setting aside of GMO legislation and the authorisation of GMOs without a prior environmental risk assessment irresponsible and disproportional. We strongly agree with them and I would like to urge all colleagues to oppose the use of the urgency procedure. Thank you very much for your support.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Following consultations with the political groups, I would also like to submit to the House a number of proposals to amend the final draft agenda. In view of the number of amendments tabled and the number of requests for split and distinct votes, the votes were distributed in several voting sessions. Information on the distribution of votes is available on Parliament's website. The second voting session on Friday will be open from 2.15 pm to 3.30 pm. The results of the second voting session will be announced at 6.00 p.m. Friday's third voting session is cancelled. Are there any objections? There are no objections, so the amendments are approved. (The order of business is thus established) ***** Finally, with regard to the Council's position on "Electronic information on freight transport", I would like to inform you that no proposal has been submitted to reject the Council's position and no amendments have been tabled pursuant to Articles 67 and 68 of the Regulation.  The proposed act is therefore deemed to have been adopted.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the presentation of the German Presidency's programme of activities (2020/2667(RSP)). I would remind honourable Members that for all the debates during this part-session there is no catch-the-eye procedure, nor will 'blue card' applications be accepted.

name: Angela Merkel
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, Madam President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. It is a pleasure for me to address the plenary of the European Parliament at the beginning of the German Presidency. Like most of you, I have the direct encounters with people who miss face-to-face conversations, and for me this is now the first trip abroad since the outbreak of the pandemic, and it leads me consciously and with complete conviction to you, to the heart of European democracy. At a time when the European Union wants to strengthen this crisis, the European Parliament needs it. The tasks ahead of us are enormous and they require enormous efforts. They need a parliamentary debate, they need political mediation, they need cultural translations into the various countries and regions. And that's what you need! It is therefore a special honour for me to present to you today the priorities of the German Presidency. Five issues are particularly important to me at this time: our fundamental rights, cohesion, climate protection, digitisation and Europe's responsibility in the world. These five issues are important because we need to change Europe sustainably if we are to protect and preserve Europe. Only then will Europe, even in a rapidly changing global order, be able to play its own role sovereignly and responsibly. We are all aware that today's visit is taking place against the background of the greatest test in the history of the European Union. The global coronavirus pandemic has also hit people hard and relentlessly in Europe. We have more than a hundred thousand deaths in Europe alone. Many citizens could not even say goodbye to their loved ones in the last hour because of the strict quarantine rules. This must not be forgotten with all the commitment to the new beginning, with all commitment to economic recovery: the mourning for the dead, the pain of the impossible farewells. That will be with us for a long time to come. Our economy has been and is being severely shaken throughout Europe. Millions of workers have lost their jobs, and in addition to concerns about the health and health of families, many citizens have also been left with fears about their economic existence. They all need our common support now. In order to break the chains of infection, the most basic fundamental rights had to be temporarily restricted. That was a very high price, because generations in Europe fought hard for these fundamental rights. Human and civil rights are the most valuable asset we have in Europe. And they can only be restricted for very important reasons and only in the very short term. A pandemic must never be a pretext for undermining democratic principles. Every country in Europe remembers differently its own historical upheavals, the different struggles for freedom and the rule of law. At the same time, it is precisely this achievement of fundamental rights in Europe that united us. For me, who have lived thirty-five years of my life in a system of freedom, restricting these rights in the pandemic was a decision that i found infinitely difficult.  At this historic stage, Germany is taking over the EU Presidency. This task fills me with respect, but also with great passion. Because I believe in Europe. I am convinced of Europe, not only as a legacy of the past, but as a hope and vision for the future. Europe is not just something that has been handed over to us, something fateful that obliges us, but Europe is something alive that we can shape and change. Europe does not deprive us of any means of action, but in a globalised world, Europe gives us first. We can maintain our convictions and freedoms, not without, but only with Europe. And for that we need this: more than ever, the orientation towards fundamental rights, but at the same time, more than ever, mutual support and Community cohesion. Europe will remain only Europe if, on this basis, there are innovative responses to the challenges of climate change and digitalisation and if it rises to its responsibilities in the world.  These are the big tasks, but I am confident. Think of what Europe has already passed in terms of trials and conflicts. Think, for example, of the failed Constitution for Europe fifteen years ago or of the economic and financial crises that we fought hard about. Or think of the refugee movements five years ago. It's never been easy. This has always led to injuries. But even the most bitter crises have helped to better understand each other's needs and needs. We learned together. Europe survived all these crises because, in the end, everyone was aware of what is essential: fundamental rights and cohesion. Human and civil rights, the inviolability of human dignity, freedom for individual personal, political and social development, protection against discrimination and contempt, not least equality – the equality that has been asserted, but also achieved – are the ethical and political foundation on which Europe rests. These are the rights that apply to everyone. They do not apply to one more and the other less. They do not apply to some and only sometimes to others. They apply. This is Europe's promise that we must guarantee: that citizens can really be free to live their religious beliefs, their cultural or political beliefs, that they can attach their respective ideas of happiness or good life. Democracy, including European democracy, thrives on public critical debate. A democracy in which opposition voices are undesirable, a democracy in which social or cultural or religious diversity is undesirable is not one.  The pandemic has made it all too clear to us how precious fundamental rights are, how fundamental the freedoms they guarantee are. Strong institutions in the European Union, the European Commission, the European Court of Justice and the European Parliament, are vigilant over the protection of these fundamental rights. Fundamental rights, they are the first thing that is close to my heart in this Presidency. This must be supported and supplemented by the second principle that makes up Europe: our cohesion. For Europe will only emerge stronger from this crisis if we are prepared – despite all the differences – to find common solutions if we are prepared to look at the world through the eyes of the other and show understanding for the other perspective. After the crisis, Europe will become stronger than before if we strengthen common sense. No one is coming through this crisis alone. We are all vulnerable. European solidarity is not just a humane gesture, but a sustainable investment. European cohesion is not just something that is politically necessary, but something that will be worthwhile. And that is also the leitmotif of our Presidency: 'Together. Make Europe strong again." I will devote myself to this task with all my passion, together with the Federal Government. But I need you for that! In order to protect this common sense in the EU, Parliament is needed. Because you are the mediator of the mutual understanding that we need in order to reach compromises. They represent almost 450 million citizens in 27 countries. They are the translators of European principles. They explain Europe to the people and thus mediate between Brussels, Strasbourg and their home regions. Not only do you communicate in 24 languages, but you live with this diversity of perspectives and experiences. Who, if not you, could explain to the people of Europe the attitude of other Member States? That is why I ask you, as mediator and mediator of cohesion, for your support at this difficult time. Help us deepen mutual understanding of each other. Help us strengthen Europe's cohesion. The highest priority of the German Presidency is for Europe to emerge from the crisis united and strengthened. But we do not just want to stabilise Europe in the short term – that would be too little. We also want a Europe that gives hope. We want a Europe that is confident and courageous in facing up to the challenges of the present. We want a Europe that is sustainable and that innovate and sustainably asserts its place in the world. We want a new start for Europe. This conviction is also followed by the german-French initiative of mid-May. Together with French President Emmanuel Macron, I have proposed a EUR 500 billion European building fund. I am pleased that the European Commission is taking many aspects of this german-French initiative into account in its proposal on the Multiannual Financial Framework and the reconstruction programme. On this basis, the European Council, headed by Charles Michel, is currently discussing this. Our common objective is to reach agreement as quickly as possible, because the depth of the economic slump is urging us to hurry up. We must not waste any time. Only the most vulnerable would suffer. I very much hope that we will be able to reach an agreement this summer. This will still require a great deal of willingness to compromise from all sides, including you. The situation is exceptional, indeed unique in the history of the European Union. That is why Germany has also advocated this extraordinary and unique effort of this magnitude of 500 billion. It will now be important for us to reach european unity. I am convinced that the social dimension is as crucial as the economic dimension. A socially and economically just Europe is crucial for democratic cohesion. It is the best recipe against all those who want to weaken our democracies and question our commonalities. For this reason too, during our Presidency, we will also pay particular attention to young people and children. They are Europe's future and particularly hard hit by the crisis. That is why, among other things, we want to promote their development with a European youth work agenda and actively support them on their way to their working lives with a strengthened Youth Guarantee. We must not be naive. In many Member States, anti-Europeans are just waiting to abuse the crisis for their own ends. We must now show all of them where the added value of cooperation lies in the European Union. We must show that a return to nationalism means, not more, less control, that only joint action as Europe protects and strengthens us. That is why it is right and important that the regions particularly affected by the crisis, and especially the people who live there, should be able to count on our solidarity. It is in our own interest. At the same time, however, the result always means that the effort that is now necessary for the benefit of all must not unilaterally place undue burdens on the economically strong Member States, that each of us is required to put ourselves in the position of the other. So you also consider what the individual Member States can and cannot do – economically, socially and politically. In all this, I ask you today, as a Member of the European Parliament, for your support. I am convinced that everyone in this crisis is ready for extraordinary solidarity. Germany is. The management of the pandemic and its consequences will shape our Presidency. At the same time, we must always keep an eye on the other major challenges of our time that still exist. These are the issues three, four and five that will matter to Europe. First, climate change. About six months ago, the President of the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, presented her climate protection programme in this House. She has spoken forcefully to you, stressing that Europe must act now if our planet is to remain viable. I, too, am convinced that a global solution to climate change is only possible if Europe takes the lead in climate protection. The strategy for a green deal by the European Commission is therefore an important guideline for us. With their close support during our Presidency, we want to create the transition to a carbon-neutral economy and society, to a green economy with strong and innovative companies – an economy that protects and strengthens Europe's natural livelihoods and competitiveness for future generations. It is important to me that we legally establish Europe's climate neutrality by 2050. I therefore welcome the European Commission's consideration of reducing emissions to 50 to 55 per cent by 2030 compared to 1990 levels as an intermediate step. In this perspective, we will also accompany the work on the European Climate Protection Act. The other major challenge and the fourth point, which is particularly important to us during our Presidency, is digital change. It, like climate protection, requires that we change the way we live and operate sustainably. This triggers fear in many people – fear of the loss of the familiar, fear of the pace of change. And that is understandable. But let me be very clear: the commitment to digitisation as well as to climate protection does not mean that we are abandoning everything that has been established and thus putting the jobs of millions of Europeans at risk. On the contrary, it is a question of a necessary change in our society, which will offer more protection and more sustainability in the long term. It is precisely in recent weeks and months that Europe's digital dependence on third countries has once again become clear to us. Many of us have undoubtedly noticed this in the course of our daily digital communications, whether in technology or in services. It is important that Europe is digitally becomes sovereign. We want to make progress in key areas such as artificial intelligence and quantum computing, but also in building a trustworthy and secure digital infrastructure. However, it is also crucial to protect our democracies effectively from cyber threats and disinformation campaigns. A democracy needs a public in which knowledge and information can be shared, in which citizens can exchange ideas and communicate on how they want to live. We are experiencing it right now: lies and disinformation cannot combat the pandemic, as little as hatred and hatred. Populism denying the facts is shown its limits. (Applause) In a democracy, truth and transparency are needed. That is what distinguishes Europe, and germany will be pushing for this in its Presidency.  And fifthly, for Europe's responsibility in a globalised world. A glance at the map shows that in addition to the United Kingdom and the Western Balkans, Europe is surrounded at its external borders by Russia, Belarus, Ukraine, Turkey, Syria, Lebanon, Jordan, Israel, Egypt, Libya, Tunisia, Algeria and Morocco, among others. At the same time, we are living in a time of global upheaval, in which the fields of power are shifting and Europe – with all the involvement of many Member States in the transatlantic alliance – is more on its own. We can and must decide for ourselves who Europe wants to be in this rapidly changing world order. It is more important than ever whether we are serious about Europe, whether we want a Europe that preserves its freedom and its identity even in times of globalisation. In this situation, there is a need for a strong European foreign and security policy. The UNITED Kingdom is and will remain an important partner in this. The design of our future relationship will occupy us a lot in the coming six months. The progress made in the negotiations so far is, to put it mildly, clear. We have agreed with the United Kingdom to speed up these negotiations in order to conclude an agreement in the autumn, which would then have to be ratified by the end of the year. I will continue to push for a good solution. However, we should also make provision in the event that an agreement does not come about. During our Presidency, we should make every effort to make progress in three other foreign policy areas, firstly with Northern Macedonia at least with Northern Macedonia, and, if necessary, Albania – an important step on the way to giving the western Balkans an accession perspective – and, on the other, for our relations with our neighbouring continent, Africa and the African Union, which we want to deepen in a forward-looking manner at an EU-Africa summit. This will continue to include issues of our migration cooperation. There are more people on the run than ever before. That is why we have a special responsibility to move forward on an issue as central to Europe as asylum and migration policy. This is a question that requires a great deal of political sensitivity, but we must not look the other way, but must face up to this humanitarian and political task together. (Applause) Last but not least, our strategic relations with China, which are characterised by close trade links, but also very different socio-political ideas, will be of great concern to us, first and for all in respect for human rights and the rule of law. Although the EU-China Summit in September cannot take place, we want to continue the open dialogue with China. During the German Presidency, we also want to continue our reflections on whether or not we want to maintain the principle of unanimity on foreign and security policy issues, and what lessons Europe should learn from the Coronavirus crisis, for example with regard to how Europe's sovereignty in the health sector could be strengthened. We should also have this debate in the context of a conference on the future of Europe. The one proposed by the European Commission last year, on which it has developed many ideas with its resolutions. I call for a conference that focuses on a few issues, offers concrete results and brings together citizens from and in different Member States for discussions. I have already spoken to the President of the European Parliament, David Sassoli, on this subject today. Mr President, Madam President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Do we want Europe? Then what I have been talking about today is needed. Then we need fundamental rights and cohesion. Then you need answers to climate change and digitalisation. Then europe's responsibility in the world is needed. Then we need to make Europe greener, more digital and therefore more innovative and more competitive. Europe should stand for an international order of law, and Europe should stand internationally for innovation and sustainability. That is the vision for Europe. Let me conclude with a personal thought. I am a music lover, so it is a great pleasure for me that there is a very special anniversary during our Presidency. In December 2020, the composer of the European anthem, Ludwig van Beethoven, would have turned 250 years old. This Ninth Symphony still fills me again and again. Every time I listen, I discover something different in music that hits and impresses me, just like Europe. It can be rediscovered again and again, and it still impresses me. And so let me end today with the wish that the message of this music, the idea of brotherhood and harmony, guides us in Europe. What message could be more appropriate than this that this Europe is capable of great things if we stand by each other and stick together. (Members rose from their seats and applauded the speaker)

name: Ursula von der Leyen
text: Präsidentin der Kommission. – Herr Präsident, Frau Bundeskanzlerin, sehr geehrte Mitglieder! Wir freuen uns auf die deutsche Ratspräsidentschaft. Ratspräsidentschaften kann man sich ja nicht aussuchen, sondern sie werden nach einem strikt festgelegten Muster verteilt, und Deutschland ist in der Tat in eine Phase gefallen, die herausfordernder nicht sein könnte. Die Erwartungen an die deutsche Ratspräsidentschaft sind hoch – ich weiß, das drückt –, aber das ist ja auch etwas Schönes, denn das zeigt ja auch: Man traut euch etwas zu. Die Corona-Krise stellt vieles in Frage: gesellschaftlich, wirtschaftlich, auch unser eigenes Selbstverständnis, die Art, wie wir uns selber sehen, und die Art, wie wir uns auch im Verhältnis zu anderen sehen. Das Ganze spielt sich ab vor einer Kulisse, einer Welt, in der die Halt gebenden Strukturen sich auch immer weiter auflösen. Wir denken – durch die Corona-Krise ausgelöst – über den Wert von Solidarität und Gemeinschaft anders und neu. Wir denken neu und anders über den großen Wert, den unser gemeinsames Europa hat, das jeden Tag neu erarbeitet werden muss. Und ja, es war am Anfang so, dass viele nach innen geschaut haben, auf das Kleine und zu wenig auf das Große und das Gemeinsame. Aber dann haben wir uns zusammengerissen und wieder mit europäischen Augen gesehen und wieder mit einem europäischen Herzen gefühlt.  Frau Bundeskanzlerin, auch dank des Beitrags Deutschlands in den vergangenen Wochen ist dieser Geist für die Verantwortung für das Ganze wieder in Europa zu Hause. Im Angesicht dieser Krise hören wir aus allen Himmelsrichtungen unseres Kontinents inzwischen Worte und sehen wir Taten, die Anlass zur Hoffnung geben, dass wir es gemeinsam schaffen können. Was gut ist für Europa, das ist auch gut für uns. Wenn ich das höre, dann weiß ich: Das ist wieder der Klang Europas, den wir hören wollen, und dieser wiederentdeckte Geist der Verantwortung für das Ganze. Das ist kein schlechter Wegbegleiter, wenn man in den Startblöcken einer Ratspräsidentschaft steht, die wegweisend sein wird für die Zukunft unserer Union. The challenge ahead of you, the rotating Presidency, and ahead of us all in the next six months, could not be more extraordinary. In the last six months, more than 100 000 lives have been lost in Europe because of COVID-19. We have entered the worst recession in almost 100 years. The summer forecast from yesterday shows a contraction of more than 8% this year, with only a partial rebound next year. This crisis is deeper and it is way broader than the one ten years ago. But the one ten years ago is still vividly present in our minds. Some of our Member States during that crisis endured sky-rocketing youth unemployment. They saw young people leaving their homes in droves in search of job opportunities elsewhere. They saw an unprecedented drop in public investment to historically low levels, all of which ultimately damaged public programmes and public infrastructure severely. For many, this was a traumatising experience.  But it does not have to be that way. In other parts of our Union the economy was supported by strong public investment from the very beginning of the crisis. People were able to stay in their jobs. That was when the concept of ‘Kurzarbeit’ was implemented on a large scale and this allowed some to come out stronger from the crisis than when they went in. We should draw lessons from this and this time we should do it together. If we do it right we can also emerge stronger from this crisis thanks to a common European purpose and thanks to Next Generation EU. And this Presidency has chosen one word at the core of its programme – ‘gemeinsam’, together, ‘tous ensemble’ – and that’s the engine of our Union.  There are two points I want to emphasise. First of all, solidarity means that those who need it get more support. But what it does not incentivise is a lack of action, and that is why in Next Generation EU investment is linked to reforms based on our existing country-specific recommendation in the European semester. Let me tell you each and every Member State has homework to do. There is not one Member State that does not have country-specific recommendations that should be linked as reforms to investment. If we want to come out stronger from this crisis, we must all change for the better. There is not a single Member State that is exempt from that – we must all change for the better. This is also what European people expect from us. They are certainly very different in their individual expectations, but are completely united in wanting to drink clean water, to breathe fresh air, to see their children grow up in nature. What they certainly do not want is that politics contributes to increased flooding, to heat waves, to droughts, to the loss of millions of species. This is a very real scenario in case of non-action and therefore economic recovery is inseparable from the European Green Deal, from digitalisation and from resilience.  My second point is: do not neglect the core Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), our seven-year budget over Next Generation EU. We need them both. (Applause) Next Generation EU is for the acute crisis, but the MFF is there to stay. It is the most important tool with which to implement our long-term goals – research, innovation, migration, foreign policy, security, to name but a few. These policies need real European added value, and they need a strong seven-year budget to bring all that to life.  All this has to be agreed now, in the next weeks, to clear the path for all the other topics that we want to tackle. By the end of the year we will have to chart the path towards our goal of a climate-neutral Europe. In September, we will propose the European Union’s new 2030 climate target, underpinned by a robust impact assessment and here, cooperation with the European Parliament and the European Council will be vital. We will also aim to click the digital transition into a higher gear.  Mesdames et messieurs les députés, au cours de cette présidence, nous ferons le maximum pour trouver un accord avec le Royaume-Uni sur nos nouvelles relations, tout en respectant nos principes et en préservant notre unité européenne. De même, il est important pour moi de maintenir une relation transatlantique forte, même s’il y a beaucoup de problèmes. Le partenariat avec l’Afrique figure au cœur du programme de la présidence allemande ainsi qu’au cœur de mon programme. En faisant face à ce virus, nous devrons montrer que ce partenariat avec l’Afrique n’existe pas uniquement par beau temps mais que nous sommes également solidaires quand le ciel se couvre. Et nous devrons également continuer à travailler avec la Chine pour bâtir un partenariat plus équilibré. Enfin, et surtout, le moment est venu d’ouvrir la conférence sur l’avenir de l’Europe. Nous voulons tous donner le coup d’envoi dès que la situation sanitaire le permettra. (Applaudissements) Pour toutes ces questions, je suis heureuse que nous puissions compter sur l’expérience de l’Allemagne, en commençant par le Conseil européen de la semaine prochaine. C’est le moment d’agir ensemble, et pour reprendre votre devise: «Gemeinsam. Europa wieder stark machen», «Together for Europe’s recovery», «Tous ensemble pour relancer l’Europe».

name: Manfred WEBER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, his name is Francesco. He’s a junior doctor in a hospital in Bergamo. He faced the question that no doctor should ever have to answer. He wants to save lives, but in this hospital there are no more beds available and he is forced to decide between life and death. At the same time, the neighbouring countries in Europe block the export of protective masks. Fear reigns, national self—interest triumphs and the neighbouring countries hang Francesco out to dry. And it’s not just Francesco. Many people all over Europe are asking themselves: ‘What happened to solidarity; where is Europe when we need it the most’?  Hohe Erwartungen liegen auf der deutschen Ratspräsidentschaft, liebe Frau Bundeskanzlerin, liebe Angela Merkel. Europa vertraut dir. Wo andere trügerische Stärke suchen, indem sie spalten, führst du zusammen. Was für Adenauer der Staat der europäischen Einheit, was für Kohl der Euro, das ist wahrscheinlich für deine Kanzlerschaft jetzt der Wiederaufbau Europas nach der schweren Corona-Krise. Ja, die deutsche Ratspräsidentschaft darf keine Fußnote der Geschichte werden. Es geht um nicht mehr und nicht weniger als um den Zusammenhalt Europas und die Frage, ob die 20er-Jahre gute Jahre werden oder nicht. Looking back at the last ten years, all people can see are the euro crisis, the migration crisis, the Brexit crisis, and now the corona crisis. We are stumbling from one crisis to another, and why? Because, all too often, we are led by fear and fear is the enemy of solidarity, fear is the enemy of the future and fear is the enemy of our freedom. Look again to Francesco. He was not led by fear. He showed courage, courage that we need in Europe now more than ever before, courage to show solidarity, and the first important step is now the Recovery Fund. We need a solution this month. Courage in the future. We cannot spend the money we borrowed from our children on the past. We need to build the future — climate, digital, industries — simply the most modern continent. Courage to be fair. When you borrow money, you need to say honestly how to pay it back. Does anybody here in this room seriously believe that you can pay the debts of the European Union without digging into own resources? I think not, and that’s why we need a repayment plan before 2028 with, for example, a new digital tax. And courage to be free. Europe is not a cash machine. Europe is a union of shared values. The rule of law must be respected.  (Applause) And you referred to several other points in today’s introduction of the German Presidency. We have to deliver on concrete solutions on migration, on Brexit, on trade and a lot of other things. But, colleagues, I am afraid that this is simply not enough. Seventy years ago Robert Schuman was confronted with even greater challenges. Europe lay in ruins with millions dead, people displaced, hunger. Nevertheless, Schuman had the courage to look beyond the everyday events. He had faith in Europe.  Today we also have an immense job to do. The digital revolution, a hostile Russia, American in retreat and an assertive China are putting us to the test. The North Pole is melting, Australia is burning, and the liberal democracy, in which we all believe so strongly, is heavily under attack. Yes, the everyday is testing us again, and again the question is whether we, like Schuman, now have the courage to look beyond the everyday. And what is my question when I talk about ‘beyond the everyday’? I think we have to talk about identity. Today we justify Europe on the basis of small everyday success stories — roaming charges, no border controls, the euro, we build motorways, no foreign exchange rates, and so forth. But this perspective is quite an egotistic perspective. If Europe delivers for me, then Europe is good. If Europe does not delivering for me, Europe is bad.  This is not enough anymore. This view of Europe leaves Francesco high and dry in the emergency room once again. No community can survive without community spirit, without shared beliefs, without its own identity, simply — I would mention it in EPP terms — the European way of life, as you described it, Madam Chancellor: democracy, the independence of our courts, the prohibition of the death penalty, the social market economy and, above all, freedom. In the United States they still have the death penalty and no national health insurance, and in China there is no democracy and no freedom at all. Our European way of life is unique and that makes us Europeans. It is good to be a European and I am proud to say that I am a European.  We need to rediscover our courage for the future, the courage to take the next step. Solidarity will only last and our values will only win at the global level if we can create a shared community spirit. Therefore, we need a truly European democracy that people can connect to. That is why we need to think big — like Václav Havel, Helmut Kohl and Lech Wałęsa  to mention only a few.  Chancellor, I trust that the German Presidency and you yourself will be up to the task: to deliver not just on the daily challenges but also, looking beyond, for the next step in European integration, building a living European democracy. Yes to a truly European identity. Yes to the European way of life.  (Applause)

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear Chancellor Merkel, welcome to this house, which is the home of European democracy. There are times in history when vision and courage are required, and this is one of them. That is why we have your experience and your German quality of building consensus, beyond particular interests, to work in the general interest of Europe. We have six months ahead of us that will set the course for the Union and we must take advantage of them to address shortcomings that have become apparent in recent times. We must be able to react more quickly and more closely to crises and strengthen our strategic sectors and resilience as a society. The next Council to agree on the recovery plan and the next budget will be decisive, yes. And that's why there's a lot of talk about money these days, but this isn't just a discussion of figures: this is a political project discussion. When Robert Schuman proposed to Konrad Adenauer the Coal and Steel Community, Konrad Adenauer clearly understood its historical scope. It was not a technical project, nor material, but a moral responsibility towards the peoples of Europe. Germany's future today remains dependent on the future of Europe and vice versa. I ask that in the next six months we work side by side to overcome the differences and divisions between north and south, between east and west; that we should reforce our Union for the sake of citizenship. Let us show the world that it is possible to create a more just, sustainable society that thinks about the environment and future generations; an egalitarian society with women in leadership positions in all institutions; a society that values public policies, such as health care or education; protecting workers; demanding fair wages; that values diversity and is able to manage migration flows with solidarity. All this is on your agenda, and you'll count on us to work. What is clear is that the formulas of the past are no longer valid and that we have to be bold. In my political group, together with my colleagues at the SPD, we have worked on a roadmap to a more effective Europe close to citizenship. And that is why we have two major outstanding subjects: on the one hand, own resources, in order to solve transnational problems; and, on the other hand, reconnect with citizens through the Conference on the Future of Europe. Chancellor, we share European values, so let us also share our commitment to defend and make them a reality.

name: Dacian CIOLOŞ
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Madam Chancellor, while I was listening to your speech, I felt a strong emotion. We both come from the same side of Europe. We have both experienced another Europe, the one often referred to as Eastern Europe, ravaged by decades of communist dictatorship and other totalitarian regimes. And there are many of us here in this room, coming from this often overlooked part of the continent. But today we all want the same thing: a free, strong and prosperous Europe. To do this, we must fight against the disenchantment, discouragement and decline of the European idea. We must show ambition and relaunch a significant number of European issues and projects because only hope, as you have said, will triumph over disillusionment. You talked about the conference on the future of Europe. The urgency now is the adoption of the stimulus package and the new multi-year financial framework. The latest European Commission forecasts on our economy show us, once again, that we have no other choice. The future of Europeans is at stake. And to give in to divisions now would be a historic mistake. I have no doubt, therefore, that you will be on the side of the President of the Council to forge a compromise as early as next week. I have shared with you the emotion I felt when I listened to you, but I cannot hide my concern from you either. You recently said that you have to have the money first before you talk about the rule of law. Let me disagree on this point because Europe is not being built on a purely accounting approach. Europe is being built, as you have said, around a project, a vision and solid values. Today, too many European leaders continue to torpedo these projects and all that they represent. And the perfect example is Viktor Orban, who is also a member of your political family, but he is not the only one. It is time, Madam Chancellor, to twist the arm of those who want to turn the tide of history. It is time to start conditioning EU funds on the rule of law. The political opportunity is clearly there. This unprecedented 1,800 billion euro package must be used as leverage. Stand on the side of the Europeans - of all Europeans - so that they can live in a free, just and prosperous world. You have the power, Madam Chancellor. Don't disappoint them!

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Chancellor, President of the Commission, President of Parliament, I would like to thank the President of the Commission for her work on this Many people in the European Union expect and expect political wisdom and foresight from this German Presidency. Never before has the EU been in existence has this been more necessary than it is today. But what you deliver here has nothing to do with prudence and foresight, but a lot with ignorance, infamy and ideology. Unfortunately, you are not the noble custodian of the European idea, as you are so happy to be celebrated. They are, in fact, their gravediggers.  (Interjections) Europe's ideals are based on cultural identity, enlightened reason and the freedom of the individual. But they trample it all underfoot. You want to replace the cultural identity of Europe, its Christian-Jewish roots, its beauty and diversity with an ultimately cultureless and contourless multiculturalism. We have recently seen where this leads us during the serious riots in Dijon and Stuttgart. Those who do not want to see this are ignorant and overlook the true interests of the people. By the way, they first feel French, Italian, Poles, Hungarians or Germans, and only then as Europeans.  Reason grown out of the Enlightenment demands a policy based on the knowledge of the sciences and respect for the law. Their chaotic and headless monetary and fiscal policies ignore all of this, and with 500 billion of the Green Deal and 750 billion for the Recovery Fund, you are finally leaving the basis of sensible decisions. That's infam. However, the most serious thing is the ever-increasing restriction of people's freedom. What you are pumping up with the Green Deal, with debt-sharing, with the insane spending excesses, is the exact opposite of freedom. To the delight of the French president and other Mediterranean friends, Mrs Merkel is casually giving away 500 billion. Ms. von der Leyen spontaneously packs a staggering 250 billion on top. It is not your money, but it is the money of the taxpayers who have not been interviewed to pay this bill. It is state paternalism in the most intense form. All this is driven at the heart of socialist ideology. It is downright a rape of freedom. And then, Mrs Merkel, you talk about the need for Germany not only to think of itself, but to be prepared to act of extraordinary solidarity. Do you know that the average wealth of Germans is much lower than that of the French, Spaniards and Italians? Are you aware that the home ownership rate in Germany cannot keep pace with that of those countries and that Germany has a significantly higher retirement age than all Mediterranean countries? What kind of absurd understanding of solidarity do you have, Chancellor?  You, Mrs Merkel, and you, Mrs von der Leyen, together with ECB President Lagarde, have long been a triumvirate of economic policy horror.  Instead of using the German Presidency to abandon this disastrous course, you are even increasing the speed of your political ghost journey once again. You are not just doing Europe as a disservice, as is the EU, you are betraying the European idea with your course and you are criminally passing away on the future of future generations.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, Ms Merkel, I think I can tell you on behalf of the broad majority of this House: a warm welcome to the European Parliament. (Applause)  It is certainly a place where we can see the difficulties of the European Union, but where, in a very large majority, we are all working to make this Europe better for the citizens – even if we sometimes differ in how we want to get there and what exactly that means – and a place where we must work even harder to better represent the diversity of the European Union – in this House. Germany takes over the Presidency of the Council in very difficult times. The Corona crisis has also become a historic test for the whole of the European Union. At the beginning of the crisis, the Union threatened to disintegrate into national components: trees were back in Europe, and citizens' confidence in the common Europe suffered dramatically. But the crisis is also an opportunity to finally build the Europe of solidarity that we so desperately need. It is now also up to you, Chancellor, and the entire German Federal Government, to seize this opportunity to set off and to re-enter Europe. I would like to congratulate you explicitly on the german-French proposal on the building fund. For he is counting on courage instead of hesitation and on solidarity instead of national selfishness. I believe that it is a sign that some of us would have liked to see before. But voilé, here we are.  But nothing has been won yet. It still takes a lot of work before such a fund, a programme, actually stands. This requires strong partners. We Greens in the European Parliament are ready to support an ambitious reconstruction plan. We stand for a fund that enables future investment, paving the way for an ecological and social transformation of the economy that addresses the challenges of our time, a fund that helps the countries most affected in the European Union without increasing the debt levels of some countries even further, and a fund that defends the rule of law and protects the climate, but which does not repeat the old mistakes and rely on economically damaging conditions, a troika. This is what we Greens are committed to everywhere: here in Brussels, but also in the national parliaments.  The terrible Corona crisis shows that we can act decisively and achieve a great deal. We also need this courage and determination to confront the climate crisis. Because climate change is not waiting until we have time to deal with it again. We are the first generation to feel climate change first hand: whether in heat waves, forest deaths or stronger storms that threaten our health and threaten the livelihoods of humanity.  And we are also the last generation that can still stop climate change halfway. We have the answers for renewable energy, for the green future, for the clean environment or for sustainable transport. We just have to do it, we just have to implement it.  The German Presidency can make an important contribution to this. Central to this are the Climate Act and the EU Climate Targets for 2030. But they must be ambitious, because, as a major historic greenhouse gas emittor, we must ensure that other countries are also on board and shoulder our historic responsibilities.  That is why we are calling on the whole of the European Union to adopt a 65% greenhouse gas reduction by 2030. I appeal to you: show courage in Europe and show courage in the fight against climate change! The world is waiting for a signal from Europe. Overcoming the Corona crisis and preventing the climate crisis: it can succeed. But that is what we must act for now, and that is what you, Chancellor, need.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Chancellor Merkel for being here today to set out the priorities of the German Presidency. Germany is taking over the rotating Presidency at the most difficult time in the history of our continent since the Second World War. Unfortunately, up to now, the European Union's response has been slow, limited in effectiveness and lacking a real spirit of solidarity between the Member States. Yesterday, the Commission revised down its growth estimates in Europe: - 8.7 % in the euro area, over - 10 % for France, Spain and Italy. Today we have only one certainty: there is no more time, it is time to act. Reaching an agreement next week is a necessity; it is a duty to ensure that money reaches citizens and businesses as soon as possible. That is why we do not want a down-to-the-bottom compromise, but we want an ambitious agreement. Germany has a huge responsibility during these six months: to put selfishness aside and to recover the original spirit of the European Union, avoiding the mistakes of the past. No more austerity and conditionality, we need to breathe new life into the economy, supporting the companies and sectors most affected, implementing favourable trade policies and relaunching the internal market. But the internal market must be balanced: greater flexibility in state aid must not exacerbate disparities between Member States. It is all very well to demand responsibility for the use of resources, but it is wrong to impose constraints that undermine the principle of state sovereignty and autonomy. We say yes to greater environmental sustainability, but without compromising the economic sustainability of our businesses. Failure to reach an agreement would make any discussion about the future of the Union hypocritical, and let us be clear about this: we do not need centralist brussels taxation, but rather we want a More Flexible European Union that is more respectful of the prerogatives of the different countries. It is unacceptable for democratically legitimised national governments to be hit with the club of alleged violations of the rule of law simply because they are not politically aligned with the thinking of Brussels. We also need a breakthrough on migration policies: your Home Secretary acknowledged yesterday that many Member States have been left alone in managing flows. There is not only the problem of reforming the asylum system but, above all, the need to firmly defend the external borders against uncontrolled immigration, including the naval blockade to stop trafficking in human beings. Migratory blackmail is one of the weapons that Erdoğan is using against Europe: it is intolerable that Turkey should continue to expand its influence in the Mediterranean in total silence of the European Union. It is essential to reach a virtuous agreement on Brexit and strengthen transatlantic relations; the fight against terrorism and international trade can only be issues where we will be stronger if we reach an agreement with our historic partners. We want a European Union that deals fearlessly with China, that strongly stigmatises the attitudes of some Member States that wink at Beijing, that actually defends Hong Kong's autonomy, that knows how to protect commercial interests, that is able to counter unfair practices and defend European assets from the risk of hostile operations. Yours is the country of Joseph Ratzinger, a true European patriot. (Mixed reactions from some Members) I did not listen to the same screams when others spoke, this does not seem to me to be a civil fact. I have listened carefully and this Parliament must listen carefully to everyone. Yours, Madam Chancellor, is the country of Joseph Ratzinger, a true European patriot. The Pope emeritus has repeatedly stressed that one cannot think of a common European home by denying one's own identity and common roots. I hope that your Presidency will be guided by these lessons, so that Europe does not persevere with the mistakes of the past.

name: Martin SCHIRDEWAN
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Chancellor, I would like to say that the Rapporteur. with this Presidency of the Council, you have been given a second chance. The Europe that you quoted a lot in your speech has not forgotten that the German answer, that your response to the financial and economic crisis at the time was austerity. The south of Europe, in particular, paid the price for the crisis at the time. Massive youth unemployment has been mentioned, privatisation, the dismantling of public services of general interest, lower wages and lower pensions.  This wrong policy almost tore the EU apart at the time. I hope that you will find the insight of this Presidency to correct the mistakes of that time. Instead of a policy of austerity, Europe needs a policy of solidarity. Chancellor, you will be judged on whether the Corona pandemic can be mastered economically and socially. But has anyone in this debate noticed today that there has been no mention at all of those who have kept society going day in and day out in recent months? Has anyone noticed here that those – nurses, medical staff, educators, salesmen at petrol stations, supermarkets or bakeries – have not been mentioned here at all in this debate?  Our political task is to act for these people and against poverty and against precarious work. Europeans are now scaly about the dispute between the Member States. Clarity on the multiannual financial framework and the building fund is needed now, before the summer. When I hear again, Chancellor – here in this debate gladly presented by your party friends, but today, for once, by the President of the Commission – that the allocation of funds should once again be linked to reforms, that is to say, to savings and privatisation again, one wonders whether the Conservatives have not been watching any news in recent months.  I would like to give you some advice, Mrs Merkel: so far, the German Finance Minister, Olaf Scholz, has blocked the digital tax in the Council and has always referred to the OECD. That excuse has lapsed now that the Trump administration has pulled out of international negotiations. Germany must stop blocking important projects in the Council. In addition to the digital tax, for example, so-called country-by-country reporting, which would be so important to block and hinder the tax avoidance practices of large companies. The socio-ecological transformation is a key project – we all agree on this – for the future of Europe. This requires a climate change policy that is committed to the objectives of the Paris Agreement. The Green Deal, as you have presented it today, is miles away from that, as Mrs von der Leyen keeps portraying here.  If you really care about climate protection, Chancellor, why are you sticking to a trade agreement such as the one with Mercosur, for example? You know as well as I do that the far-right Brazilian President Bolsonaro is partly responsible for the mass deforestation of the amazon jungles. Incidentally, I do not think that democracies with right-wing extremists should conclude any trade agreements at all. Or, when it comes to business, when economic interests play a role, do the European values mentioned suddenly no longer play a role?  At Europe's external borders, these European values sink to the bottom of the Mediterranean every day with every drowning. This is an intolerable state of affairs. These people are not helped by dirty deals with any autocrats or warlords, but by a policy based on human rights based on solidarity. Please also tell your Minister of the Interior, Mr Seehofer. However, you can increase confidence in European democracy, Mrs Merkel, by reducing lobbying influence on the Council and by making the Council minutes transparent. You have also stressed this: transparency is a leitmotif of your Presidency. That would be a sensible step, which of course many more will have to follow. But that would be a sensible step to turn the Member States' side-by-side and opposition in the Corona crisis into a coexistence, the aim of which is a socially just, ecological and more democratic European Union.

name: Martin SONNEBORN
text: Mr President, Chancellor Merkel, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work she has Who, if not you, could lead the European Union out of this crisis? This is what millions of leaders ask, who usually do not think of anyone else. Apparently, Europe has an irrepressible longing to submit to German leadership. Why only now and not 80 years ago? The continent would have been spared a lot – wink smiley. If I read correctly, you plan to suffocate the Corona virus with a lot of money – something that the EU has unfortunately not succeeded with the no less shabby dictator Orban.  They will ban climate change and encourage the Chinese to laugh at us a little quieter in the future. You will manage the migration by making sure that the gems happen where they are not so noticeable. There is only one limit to your power: even you and your 750 billion cannot ensure that Hamburger SV ever re-enters the Bundesliga.

name: Angela Merkel
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I can actually be brief. I would like to thank those who have sent me good wishes. It is clear, I believe, that the 'collective' does not only refer to the Member States, but also to work with the European Parliament. It has also become clear in the speeches that there are very different ideas about what is really to be achieved. In other words, it is not only up to us Heads of State and Government and the President-in-Office of the Council to find a solution, but we will all have to come together if we are to achieve something. I would like to make it clear – and I have not spoken at length about the rule of law and fundamental rights for nothing – that these are also an absolute priority for the German Presidency in Europe. Nevertheless, we must also, so to speak, create the basis for us to work. This includes the medium-term financial framework, including the building fund, and I would like to point out today that we will certainly also need to be willing to compromise with Parliament in our discussion – I also discussed this with the President of Parliament – because I can tell you – as the President-in-Office of the Council will also tell you – that, of course, the ideas are still far apart among the Member States today. What is not acceptable, I would like to say quite clearly, is, so to speak, the duct of the claim to absoluteness of certain opinions which declare the rest of the world absurd. This is incompatible with democracy and tolerance, and then we will not come up with any solutions. I would like to make that very clear here.  (Applause) We will indeed also be talking about difficult issues. Manfred Weber raised the issue of "own resources". I would like to draw attention to one aspect here: i understand the subject on the one hand, and it is also a matter for the European Parliament. On the other hand, for example, certain appropriations, which the Commission may now classify as own resources, are already planned in the national budgets. In other words, we must take account of each other, and we must be careful that, at an economically difficult time, we do not use the word 'own resources' to send out actual false tax increases – I am not explicitly opposed to digital taxation, I want to make that quite clear – as a factual false sign, as if we had, for example, general tax increases. That would be a difficult answer now in the difficult economic situation.  With the digital tax, I would like to say the following: of course, it is always better if a tax can be agreed internationally on a global basis, and I therefore think it is perfectly legitimate that we have set out to wait for the work of the OECD, because everything else could then lead us into difficult trade conflicts. We have already seen this in a number of examples in Europe. If, however, no solution is visible here, then we must seriously consider how we can find a solution for Europe here, because it cannot be the case that a certain type of value creation, which is now increasing through digitisation, has, so to speak, come through the area almost tax-free, and I believe that we have already had good successes in international financial market rules in terms of transparency, including tax havens. Unfortunately, working on a digital tax seems to be a little more difficult here.  One last thing: I believe that we need to make a very clear distinction between the euro crisis or the financial crisis that we have experienced in the individual European countries as a result of the global financial crisis and today's pandemic. It is undisputed that we are all in international competition, every Member State, and we can only live our social model if we do not become vulnerable. And if we all have excessively high levels of debt, then we know how vulnerable we become in our model. That is why it was right that there were reforms in the Member States, but in return, of course, there was also a great deal of solidarity. I am thinking only of the structure of the ESM and other things. Today's crisis is a crisis that is not the fault of countries, but a virus that has come upon us, for which no one can do anything, and which has affected the countries in very different ways. If something like this happens, then we need completely different instruments and completely different answers, and that is why I am promoting this building fund.

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: Mr President, Chancellor, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work she has done on this I am campaigning that, in view of the terrible economic development of legislation in the Presidency of the Council, we are not simply continuing as before. We must give prospects and confidence to entrepreneurs who are facing the ruins of their livelihoods, workers who are in short-time work or unemployment. That is why we must keep old structures with borrowed money artificially alive. In the case of climate, the environment and infrastructure, the following applies: fewer targets, restrictions and bans, and instead more money for truly sustainable investments. I am campaigning for us to decide on repayment at the same time as spending money. Simply cutting the general budget is not possible. How, then, should we invest in research, shape Europe or build a European external border protection? However, I am campaigning for us not only to talk about money, but at the same time to develop political union, to strengthen Europe on issues such as foreign and security policy, innovation, climate change, external trade and all the issues on which we need a strong Europe. All this is on your agenda, and I wish you every success.

name: Jens GEIER
text: Mr President, Chancellor, President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. The recovery of European societies and the European economy is a common eu project. Either it succeeds all over Europe or it does not succeed at all – Chancellor, you have talked about it. Designing the new Building and Resilience Facility within the EU budget is a forward-looking step. This budget is the responsibility of the governments of the EU Member States and the European Parliament. I believe that the increase in European cooperation cannot be bought with less European democracy. We have examples in EU budgetary law, such as how the Council and Parliament jointly determine the expenditure of funds, such as the EU Globalisation Fund. This is about transparency, including with the public, so that it is clear how the money from the reconstruction package will be used. This transparency cannot exist without parliamentary control. That is why my urgent request to you, Chancellor, is to ensure that the European Council is committed to ensuring that Parliament's co-determination rights are fully exercised.

name: Malik AZMANI
text: – Mr President, I would like to welcome Chancellor Merkel to the European Parliament where we have high expectations for this German Presidency. Renew Europe wants to underline the importance of reaching an agreement on the EU Recovery package and MFF in the midst of this unprecedented crisis. However, we do not just need recovery: we need smart recovery. Europe has to show the ambition to come out of this crisis stronger. This is the time to revive our economies in a sustainable, digital and green way, but it’s also the time to strengthen our democracies.  Renew Europe insists on strengthening the rule of law of conditionality. It’s of vital importance and I hope the Chancellor agrees with me. And if so, I will be keen to hear how the German Presidency will also deliver on this topic. And we have of course more challenges on the horizon. We need progress on the Migration pact, to avoid a hard Brexit and to build a stronger EU in a turbulent world.  Let me finish by saying that Renew wishes to extend its hand to you, to work together on these important challenges. Ms Merkel, let me look you in the eye Eine Frage: Möchten Sie mit uns Europa erneuern?

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: Mr President, contrary to what might have been expected, the European Union has not gone down a notch after Brexit, but on the contrary, the accelerator of the European unity state is being pushed extra hard in many areas. All this according to good EU custom, by the way, without taking into account the mood among the population.  Mrs Merkel, you yourself will – I think – use this Presidency of the Union as a happy coincidence to give your career a nice turn, but let me tell you that there are many people among the citizens of the European Member States who are critical of this federalist evolution of the Union and who are therefore particularly worried as you are going to add german power and strength to the federalist concert. , and now that you are even going to push the EU into debt. Critical citizens therefore see your taking office as a double threat.  I would like to take this opportunity to draw your attention to this. After all, one must have no hope of doing business, nor should we succeed immediately in order to persevere.

name: Gwendoline DELBOS-CORFIELD
text: Mr President, Madam Chancellor, we can be convinced Europeans, even federalists, fully aware that it is on this European scale that we will face the immense global problems of this century, but we can also be very worried about the future of this European Union. In 2020, there was Brexit. But today, two Member States are taking advantage of the flaws of this European Union, from its mortal capacity to self-discrimination to set up quasi-authoritarian regimes, to discriminate against part of their population, to reduce powers, counter-powers, oppositions, the media, justice. This can have a terrible contagion effect for neighbouring governments because it seems that rights and freedoms can be attacked in this European Union without any consequences but mere alerts and reports. Madam Chancellor, by your history, which you have recalled, because of your remarkable career in dignity, ethics, in the history of your country, in the growing influence of this country on the European stage, I ask you to make the German Presidency an exemplary, courageous, even more courageous presidency than the Finnish Presidency on these matters of the rule of law. I ask you not to put economic interests and diplomatic considerations before the rights and freedoms of all European citizens. (Applause)

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Madam Chancellor, i would like to thank you very much Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Chancellor, your country is not only the largest contributor to the Union budget, paying around EUR 30 billion, but also the largest beneficiary of the common market. The benefits are estimated at €210 billion per year, which is seven times the contribution. It is therefore most justified to call for German solidarity with less prosperous countries during the coronavirus pandemic. Your country has opted for more than EUR 1 trillion in public aid to the economy, which accounts for more than 50% of the eu's public aid, but if the crisis in the EU economy continues, the German economy, largely export-oriented, will not return to growth soon.  It is therefore necessary to conclude the budgetary negotiations quickly and to mobilise the Reconstruction Fund for all Member States later this year. Thirdly, the common agricultural policy and European farmers have ensured food security during the coronavirus pandemic for 500 million European consumers. It is therefore necessary to further strengthen the financial capacity of this policy for the next seven years, especially as agriculture and farmers are to be involved in the implementation of the Green Deal.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Merkel, I have one minute to address you, the woman who is perceived by the citizens of Europe as the master of Europe, and you who, with your former minister, Mr von der Leyen, at the head of the European Commission, have the opportunity to make good the mistakes that have been made so far. COVID-19 is a warning to you to act differently: the recovery fund must be approved immediately: fresh, no-go resources are needed and within the year. The European Parliament will not accept any compromise to the downside of the Commission's proposal; Moreover, it is the least that Europe can do. These resources cannot come from the ESME, do not insist that Italy activate it. Italy's health has been slaughtered by austerity and the Stability Pact needs a thorough review and not a timed suspension. Italy has learned from our Greek brothers: we will not sell off the country to privatisation and wild liberalisation; we will not allow large foreign companies – German, French, Dutch but also Chinese – to plunder public goods and strategic assets. As an Italian, I do not accept the insults to my fellow citizens, their enormous sacrifices to make ends meet. Do we want a more competitive Europe? Then the single market works for everyone: tax havens; yes to a common and consolidated tax base; european minimum wage and equal pay for men and women. The green new deal says goodbye to the fossil: just safeguard the interests of the lobbies and finance the large steel polluting industries! And be ware: the hydrogen of the future is green hydrogen, not blue hydrogen! We need courage and ambition: we are here, but under these conditions.

name: Enikő GYŐRI
text: - Dear Chancellor,  I ask you to help the Union get back on its feet. Under the circumstances, this work could not be carried out by anyone else. Implement your motto: make Europe strong again. In the 11th, the Hungarian Presidency also chose this as its motto. Then we've made small strides, now it's time for the big steps. This requires prioritising the issues that bind Member States together and promote the competitiveness of the Union. Without internal cohesion, we cannot stand our ground either in the fight against the epidemic or in the global arena. So use your strength to have a fair and balanced budget, with a strengthened cohesion policy that has already been proven and is a condition for competitiveness. You are aware of the situation in the Eastern Member States. They can count on us in economic policy. Please let us count on you. Leave behind what separates you: issues laden with ideology, psychological warfare that is so fashionable against individual Member States and third countries. In the field of the rule of law, rise above preconceived notions. Along the lines of the treaties, everyone can only be examined by equal standards. Finally, we need the famous German sobriety so that we can reach an agreement with the British people and finally accept that they are imagining their future outside the Union, but let us not give them up as our number one political and economic partner.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the German Presidency is starting at one of the darkest moments in Europe, bent in two by the coronavirus. You, Chancellor, have already mentioned the people who have left us and the economic and social consequences of this crisis. It is precisely Europe that is called upon today to respond to the challenge we are experiencing. Your Presidency comes just a few days before a crucial European Council to reach agreement on the reconstruction plan presented by the Commission. Let me be very clear: we cannot and must not go back from that plan if we want to build the Europe that you mentioned, a Europe that is solid and supportive, and in which I too believe and if we want to put at the centre the priorities of the six months that have opened up today. This Parliament has already expressed itself by a large majority several times in recent months, because there is the Council, which you have the burden and the honour of chairing, but there is also Parliament, the only institution directly elected by the citizens. We will never approve an agreement that lowers the ambition of the reconstruction plan, that does not give hope and a future to the citizens of Europe. The Commission's proposal is the minimum trade union, it is a starting point, but it certainly cannot be the end of the day, let alone a watered-down compromise. We can no longer wait, yesterday's estimates are clear: two months of waiting is worth 2 percentage points less than GDP for the European economy. So good job, Chancellor, I say this without rhetoric. This is a moment in history when vision and courage are needed. We have high expectations: surprise us, Chancellor, and this Parliament will be with you.

name: Nicola BEER
text: Mr President, Chancellor, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Those who put them into perspective lose! Europe needs courage, speed, willingness to reform. Money can do a lot, but not everything. Let us not make the mistake of believing that we could use money to conceal missed reforms and structural location deficits. Then the next crisis will hit us all the more. This Corona package has too much volume and too little future. Let us make Europe stronger – stronger internally – with a budget for reform, innovation and modernisation for a Europe of inventors, for the prosperity of the people, with a depoliticised rule of law mechanism for a democratic Union and with a new asylum and migration policy without a Dublin principle, but with a European talent pool for a sincere Europe – and more outwardly – with a European Union with a strong voice and ambition in the world through the more efficient institutions. A truly strong geopolitical union must not be divided, it must not be slow and it must not be indebted. This ambition should be our ambition.

name: Jaak MADISON
text: – Mr President, Mrs Merkel. I listened carefully to your review of the German Presidency. You repeatedly emphasised unity and solidarity. I have a question for you: how can we take seriously the unity and solidarity of the European Union when Germany has repeatedly shown that solidarity is very selective.  Germany is currently currently building Nord Stream 2 with Russia, for example, to buy gas from Russia in a favourable way, ignoring geopolitical risks and security interests, ignoring the interests of its partners and the Member States of the European Union by increasing Russia's influence in the Energy Sector of the European Union. I'm afraid you're ignoring it.  How can you talk about solidarity when, to this day, very many farmers in the European Union receive only two thirds of the agricultural subsidies only because Germany and France are against it, otherwise they would lose a competitive advantage in the European Union's single market. How can you talk about solidarity? Finally, is solidarity only for you if Germany supports uncontrolled migration and the opening of borders? If the problem is too big, it will only be solved by redistributing these people under quotas. Is this the solidarity that Germany wants? I do not want such a European Union, thank you.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, Chancellor, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work she has done on this It may surprise you, but I would like to congratulate you. I would like to congratulate you on having overcome three taboos of German European policy with the german-French proposal for a reconstruction fund.  The three taboos are: solidarity grants and investment instead of the unfortunate talk of the transfer union; secondly, the question of shared debt, which is used to finance large joint investments, instead of the repeated miserable talk of Eurobonds, and, finally, support for European taxes.  But, Chancellor, this is, of course, a 180-degree turnaround from politics back in the euro crisis. But at the same time, you probably already suspect that something is coming. The question, of course, is this confession must now be more than a one-off. So far, it has been said that the building fund is unique. Yes, crisis management is unique, but the principle of investment financed by solidarity must become the permanent economic policy principle of Europe. If we now act together and in solidarity only once, then your 180-degree turn will be turned into a pirouette in a few years' time. That is why it is so important that the Corona crisis does not allow the rift in Europe to diverge further. It will become clear in this Presidency, Chancellor, whether you want to be a crisis manager or an architect of a stronger Europe. Only if the Reconstruction Fund becomes a lasting expansion of economic and monetary union will Europe take a major step towards a solidarity-based investment union. This requires your full clarity and commitment. Good luck!

name: Helmut GEUKING
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the There are high expectations of this Presidency, no question at all. This is what the debate has shown today. In addition, COVID-19 is already casting its shadow over the Presidency of the Council. We must tackle the consequences of COVID-19 together, to fight it together. I think that has been made very clear. To this end, we proposed the handcuff bonds at the time. I would ask you to look again at them. I believe that this is the best way forward, including in all other countries. This would also bring Europe one and further forward. In this Presidency, Germany has taken social policy to the fore. Here I say to you, as Federal Chairman of the Family Party of Germany and a Member of the European Parliament, that we must now finally tackle the child guarantee. We can only tackle this with child benefit, which we need to introduce across Europe in order to get millions of children out of poverty, to strengthen the families, the victims of this COVID-19 crisis, and to align our society with the people.  It is only from strong families that a strong Europe can be created that can hold its own in this global world, and Here I am counting entirely on the German Presidency. I hope that your support, Chancellor, will finally stop paying lip service to Sunday speeches, but that we will finally get families and children out of poverty here.

name: Carles PUIGDEMONT I CASAMAJÓ
text: – Mr President, Chancellor, the EU’s problems are not only economic. Certainly, you must face a crisis that will be hard.
