We need to prevent today’s inequalities and poverty, which are the sources of tomorrow’s conflicts. In a world where some blocs are ever readier to seek conflict, the EU must work to solve them. Indeed, the EU’s problems are democratic as well.  Getting out of an economic crisis to enter into a crisis of civil rights and freedoms will not save Europe. We need the economic recovery agenda to be linked to democratic consolidation. We must demand that countries where fundamental rights are questioned, as in the case of Spain, respect the rule of law. Ending the persecution of ideas, the arbitrary jailing of political dissidents, artists or journalists, is a moral and legal imperative that the EU can no longer avoid.

name: Dolors MONTSERRAT
text: – Mr President, in Spain, as we suffer the pain of the loss of thousands of citizens and face the worst economic and social crisis, the virus has made us aware of the unplaceable need to strengthen and modernise Spain and Europe.  Strong leadership in Europe is now more than ever needed. Von der Leyen, in the Commission, the German presidency, with Chancellor Merkel, is a hope for millions of Europeans for their strong support for the recovery plan.  The People's Party applauds this Presidency, and we ask it to approve the plan in the Council and the budget proposed by the Commission, which will enable us to protect our health, revive the economy to save the productive fabric and create jobs, which is the best social policy.  European solidarity must be accompanied by ambitious national reforms to make Spain and Europe more competitive and resilient, with an industrial, digital and sustainable economy, without ever giving up freedom and equality.  Europe's success will be the failure of populism and nationalism. The next six months are decisive. The European People's Party is going to live up to it, as great Democrats and Europeanists we are.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: Mr President, Madam President of the Commission, Chancellor, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work she has done on this. Welcome to the House of European Democracy. It's nice that you're there. There is a lot of talk in your programme about digitalisation and climate protection. I think one thing is clear: without technology, there is no Green Deal. I think the transformation involves great opportunities, and we need to look at that. The german-French GAIA-X initiative, for example, can ultimately give us the opportunity to interrupt oligopolistic tendencies around the world. I believe that it must also be our aim to tackle global technological leadership, particularly in the field of hydrogen technology and the battery cell industry. The hydrogen strategy has been presented today – Mrs von der Leyen, thank you very much for this – and ten billion euros are planned for this over the next ten years. But the battery cell industry is also of crucial importance – and, Maro's , is here with us, thank you very much, Maro, this is your baby, we know – but here too, in my opinion, it is important to take advantage of the great opportunities. This European battery market is expected to be worth EUR 250 billion in 2025 and create five million new jobs, and European industry has already announced EUR 100 billion in investment. The European Commission will make the proposals and, Chancellor, the German Presidency has the opportunity to support this today and now. Thirty years ago today, Germany became world football champions, and with this good omen we are keeping our fingers crossed.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Mr President, Chancellor, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work she has done on this As renew europe's spokesperson on agricultural policy, I would ask you to support agriculture. During the COVID-19 crisis, European farming families produced high-quality, safe and affordable food and ensured the uninterrupted supply of the population. We owe this to a European agricultural model. Large and small businesses, family-run and cooperatively organised and organic and conventional enterprises operate under this umbrella of the common agricultural policy.  In the future, a new CAP model will be introduced that rewards performance and makes it transparent, rather than just rewarding compliance with rules. Payments are linked to objectives such as the environment, climate and animal welfare.  Chancellor, we need you at our side. Please support the free internal market. Please advocate a strong agricultural budget. Ensure equal conditions in global competition and legal certainty for farmers.  With a strong and efficient agricultural economy, we can also face future crises.

name: Peter KOFOD
text: Mr President! Thank you, Chancellor Merkel, for putting the priorities of the German presidency on the table. They concern me – very much – especially those who are in the field of immigration. When you, Chancellor Merkel, handled the immigration area back in 2015, it was under the slogan "wir schaffen das", and with one thing, Europe turned into a great chaos, with more than one million people wandering into Europe from Africa and the Middle East. Your immigration policy is not the solution, but it is the problem itself. I will not distribute the migrant flow between EU countries, I want to slow down the flow of migrants, I want to close the external border and I will protect our communities. Europe must not be a hot room for Islamists, foreign fighters and other rogues who, on the pretext of seeking freedom, come here precisely to undermine our freedom and our society. Chancellor Merkel! Your immigration policy has brought great destruction all over the European continent. I will do everything I can to limit the damage that you and your policy have caused!

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Madam Chancellor, i would like to thank you very much Madam President of the Commission, i voted in favour of this report. The pandemic recession could result in a further deepening of economic imbalances in Europe. The fear is rightly expressed that stronger Member States will become even stronger and weaker Member States will become even weaker. The Reconstruction Fund is an attempt to prevent this dangerous trend, but the same unfortunately applies to the Green Deal, especially in times of recession, and we do not know how long the pandemic will last. It goes without saying that some countries cannot, for historical, geographical and economic reasons, achieve at national level the climate objectives set at Union level without huge economic problems, without inhibiting the development of their industry. The Fair Transition Fund can mitigate the effects of this transformation, but it cannot solve this problem.  We expect the German Presidency to realisticly assess climate targets and launch a pragmatic strategy for achieving them.

name: Andrzej HALICKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Madam Chancellor, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. The coming time is a time of great challenges. We are talking a lot today about the economy, about the recovery plan, about the billions that should help us recover from the crisis. Some even say the "Marshall Second Plan" for our European community.  But we also need to talk about democracy. We must also have a Marshall Plan for the restoration of democracy and the protection of the values that underpin our Community. And here's one word – solidarity. Solidarity is a guarantee of security. Solidarity – every child in Poland knows this: it is a slogan that says that there is no freedom without solidarity, that it is the defence of everyone by all. And this is our common interest – even those who do not feel and understand this word. Europe must emerge from the current crisis with a stronger and more solidarity-based solution.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Madam President, Madam Chancellor, the German Presidency will have to take on immense responsibilities. Europe, more than ever, must be there to support and be useful to European states and citizens. Useful today, but also tomorrow, and that is why you must succeed in the first stage of the Green Pact for Europe, in particular, with a real reform of the common agricultural policy which should be in line with these climatic, sociological and economic upheavals. The upheaval will also be budgetary, as you know, and you have, again, an obligation to succeed. The European Union needs its own resources to finance its reconstruction plan and, beyond that, strengthen its multi-year financial framework. Yes, there will need to be a real tax on financial transactions, a tax on the profits of multinationals, especially those of digital, as well as a coordinated European-wide tax on billionaires and multi-millionaires. Tax competition will still have to be ended and a progressive environmental tax package devised. Finally, public support for virtuous tax practices and the rule of law, and strengthen the fight against tax evasion and evasion, must be conditioned. Madam Chancellor, we no longer have time to fail, we must be by your side to succeed in this challenge and this challenge.

name: Luis GARICANO
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank Ms von der Leyen and Ms Merkel for being here. Ms Merkel, I realise that securing an agreement on the massive recovery plan at your summit will feel like a huge achievement and a big relief. And it should be. You will have accomplished a level of fiscal integration that most of us hadn’t expected to see in our lifetimes. But I’m sorry to say that such an achievement will not be enough. As you have stated repeatedly, we need a repayment plan. Without a plan to repay our debts, we will be postponing the problems we face now by seven years. 505 Members of this Parliament have proposed a solution, namely that the deal you reach now includes an own resource package that secures the financial future of Europe, a system that is politically viable because it relies on big polluters and big tech contributing what they must. Madam Chancellor, please don’t kick this can down the road by seven years. Please make it the objective of your Presidency to leave Europe with a system of own resources that makes its finances solid and its economy prosperous.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Chancellor Merkel, you have for years been the true master of this Europe, dominated by German interests and tailor-made to favour Germany and sink Italy. In recent years you have massacred Italy with austerity, you have filled our country with illegal immigrants, you have imposed on us governments never elected by anyone – from Monti to Conte – ready to obey your orders. And today you want to impose the last big rip-off called the ESA, to put Italy under the enhanced surveillance of Brussels. Chancellor Merkel, but who gives you the power to trample on the Italians, democracy and the sovereignty of our people? The Italians do not want alms from Berlin or Brussels, the Italians simply want their money back, real money, like the hundred billion euros that Italy has given Europe over the last twenty years. We want our money back because we have a duty to save the lives of millions of Italians and the lives of millions of businesses in the face of the coronavirus economic crisis. I wish you good work, Chancellor Merkel, but remember that Italian citizens, not Germans, are in charge in Italy. Our freedom and the dignity of our country are not for sale, either now or ever.

name: Derk Jan EPPINK
text: Madam President, Chancellor, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work she has Many see the building plan as your political legacy, but what is the legacy?  There was the energy transition and "We can do it". In the EU, Germany was always a paymaster and a breeding master at the same time. I have the impression that you have given up the second task, the thrifty four are standing alone. In the construction plan, we are only talking about large sums of money. My question is: how should the money be used? There are no concrete plans yet, only amounts as symbolic politics.  The President of the Italian Central Bank, Mr Visco, has said that Italy does not need money, but reforms. Spain is in the process of introducing a basic income. At the same time, poverty is increasing in Germany and the Netherlands. They are turning monetary union into a transfer union. That is your European heritage. A mountain of debt as high as the Tower of Babel once did.  Germany is guided by guilt and morality, and I understand that. But those who are guided only by morality lose sight of reality and make many things worse.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Mr President, Mrs Merkel, let me say, as a European, as a representative of Europeans, like Portuguese, as a member of the EPP and as a member of the PSD, that you have our support, that you have our support for the commitment and european commitment you have shown here today. I would like to leave you two very specific questions, both relating to European democracy. There has been a lot of talk here about rule of law and democracy in the Member States, but democracy is also needed at European level.  First, to the recovery fund. On the one hand, it mobilises European obligations and, on the other hand, it also mobilises a great deal of European expenditure and expenditure, and it is therefore important that Parliament, together with the Council and the Commission, be involved in the process of approving this fund.  Secondly, as far as the Future of Europe Conference is concerned, it must involve as many citizens as possible, it must be oriented towards the medium term and I ask whether we should not be open, if so decided and conclude by that conference, for a possible revision of the treaties, if necessary, to increase legitimacy and democracy in the European Union.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – Madam President, Chancellor Merkel, throughout many crises you have shown yourself to be a real European leader and now again the expectations of citizens are high. We must deliver real solutions in times of social and economic hardship. But next to economic solidarity, we must also stand firm on our fundamental values. As my family grew up behind the Iron Curtain, I share your belief in a united, democratic Europe. You yourself have experienced what it is like to live under a dictatorship, so, Ms Merkel, be courageous on protecting the rule of law. Speak up when autocrats like Viktor Orbán are undermining the very foundations our free societies have been built on, and act decisively next week at the European Council. Take a firm stand on a rule of law conditionality for the next seven-year budget. Failing to stand up for our common values is a price Europe cannot afford to pay.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Madam President, I would like to say to Madam Chancellor that, whenever we have faced global challenges, be they with Putin, with Erdoğan, you were the person who took the leadership and united Europe. But what I have taken the most from your leadership role was your ability to find a practical solution to real problems, to turn words into action. Now we need these skills more than ever here in Europe, in Brussels. We need them on the long-term budget and we need them to restart our economies. You asked us to be mediators. So let me ask you to play the role of an honest broker here in Brussels. I ask you to work not only for a Franco-German solution, but for one that works for the east and west, for the north and the south, for Berlin, Paris and in Prague, a compromise that unites us. I believe that Germany can find this balance and be the voice of not only German, but European, consensus. We need it more than ever.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: Madam President, Chancellor, Secretary of State and Minister for Europe Mr Roth, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work she has said. I also warmly welcome you to the European Parliament.  I look forward to this presidency and have as high expectations as the others. But I see the federal government well equipped for this. I believe that the german-French proposal was very helpful in making it clear that this Presidency wants to act in the European spirit. You spoke of passion, Chancellor. You know my great passion: this is the rule of law, that is rule of law. I am very pleased that you have put fundamental rights at the very beginning. My appeal now, of course, is that these speeches should be followed by action. We need the rule of law, democracy, an independent judiciary and a free press throughout Europe. We need a sanction mechanism that works. I therefore urge you not to be intimidated or re-turned by those who, for example, want to turn around the two-thirds majority – we need this effective mechanism. It is not just a question of reining in these governments, but also of showing the citizens of the other countries that we are on their democratic side.

name: Katalin CSEH
text: – Madam President, Chancellor Merkel, the Hungarian rule of law crisis is at a critical stage. A little over a month ago, a member of my opposition party, Momentum, was detained by police because of a Facebook post criticising the Orbán government. Index, the largest Hungarian news portal, is fighting for survival because of interference from the Fidesz government. Municipal governments are being stripped of their revenues after electing opposition mayors last year. Corruption and state capture are out of hand. Madam Chancellor, Mr Orbán has been in power for ten years. It’s been a decade of procrastination from Europe’s side. And we can keep telling ourselves that there is nothing that the Council can do. But this is simply not the case. Direct EU funds to local governments, to NGOs, to people who need it the most – instead of funnelling them through a corrupt government that openly abuses them and tramples on the EU’s values. Madam Chancellor, there is a concrete proposal on the table, a mechanism. Can you support this? Because continuing to do nothing is a choice as well. A choice that is detrimental to the stability of the EU and means one more nail in the coffin of Hungarian democracy.

name: Heléne FRITZON
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Madam Chancellor, I would like to thank you for your I welcome the german Presidency's ambitious programme. The motto "recovery together" is good. We must deal with the crisis with determination, unity and solidarity. We need an ambitious, pragmatic and responsible recovery plan.  Together we must take responsibility for building our new economy – an economy in which green transition, social rights and gender equality build sustainable Europe. Unemployment must be combated. Child poverty is to be eliminated. We must take responsibility for the fact that girls and women have been hit harder, with violence increasing. We would also like Germany to lift the rules for women on boards. Together we now have the opportunity to make Europe fairer, more sustainable and more equal. We owe that to our children and grandchildren.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: – Madam President, I’m not sure if we are still allowed to say this in the ‘Me Too’ era, but I would like to say to the Chancellor that for me, Madam, you are one of the only politicians that has the balls to take decisions. (Scattered applause and laughter) You showed courage when you decided to help Greece – courage, because your own Minister of Finance was against it. You showed the right moral compass during the migration crisis, the right compass, even when your own public opinion was against it, and again, during this crisis, we really count on your leadership to guide Europe. The proposal of the Commission, inspired by our resolution and the French-German proposal, is the right thing to do. Push it through!  Finally, I would like to urge you to take one other important decision – go for a new strategy with China. China’s crackdown on human rights in Hong Kong needs to be on the agenda. We defend human rights and the rule of law. We must start to confront China with this. Good luck and you can count on us. We will be with you.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Madam President, Chancellor, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work she has The debate shows how much hope lies on the shoulders of the German Presidency. Yes, I think it is right: the right steps have been taken, and the first signs of the last few weeks and months give hope that we can tackle this together.  Social Democrats in Germany have always insisted that there be solidarity, solidarity and renewal. We cut off a lot of old braids, we left red lines, and we broke taboos that were backward-looking and outdated. That is a good thing. But it must continue. There must be socio-ecological renewal, because we need a strong Europe in a troubled world. The signs of the times – in New York the data is collected these days: the world is massively thrown back by Corona. Only if we rebuild Europe in the sense of socio-ecological renewal will we be able to make our contribution to the world.  One final sentence – the debate on the rule of law: when we talk to our Scandinavian friends, we will see how many concerns there are about the abuses by Mr Orban and others. They do not want the oligarchs to be given their pockets. Give the money to the mayors, to small and medium-sized enterprises, who know what they are doing with it and do decent work!

name: Fabienne KELLER
text: Madam President, Madam Chancellor, on 15 May, the European Parliament adopted, by a large majority, a strong resolution on the recovery plan. On 18 May, you launched an initiative with President Emmanuel Macron, which was then strongly taken up by President Ursula von der Leyen. Madam Chancellor, the speed at which this plan is put in place is decisive. How are you going to secure a strong agreement in the Council in ten days' time to help businesses and citizens recover from the crisis tomorrow? Will you defend its funding with new own resources, as Proposed by Luis Garicano at the moment?  And on the subject of the migration crisis, are you ready to commit to a political agreement on the pact on migration and asylum?  Madam Chancellor, dear Angela Merkel, viel Erfolg for Ihre Ratspresidentschaft!

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first I would like to thank you for the truly dynamic European debate and I would like to thank you, Madam Chancellor, for your true European leadership. I think now it’s needed more than at any time in European history and I think that your decisiveness in presenting the Franco-German proposal has opened the possibilities for the European Commission to present to all of you the unprecedented proposal where we are looking at how we can best combine the next seven-year budget, the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) with the Next Generation EU instrument. I will not go into detail because I think that the next debate will be very much focused on that and that we will also have a chance to debate it with the President of the European Council, Mr Michel. So let me go a little bit in the other direction – into what else which will be so crucial to the German Presidency. Madam Chancellor, I very much appreciate your strong words on European values, on the importance of solidarity, on underscoring how important fundamental rights are and the fact – which sometimes we forget in the heated debates we very often have in the Council – that cohesion is the sustainable investment into the future and that the successful projects in our Member States are making the whole European economy much stronger, much more resilient for the future. I think this is exactly what you need. I think you saw from the Chamber how much your clear stance on fighting dangerous populism and hatred and the push for rule of law is appreciated by this House and by this Chamber.  I think that we both lived large parts of our lives under a regime where we were longing for freedom, longing for the possibility to travel across Europe. Therefore, maybe for us, it’s a little bit different when we talk about the importance of democracy, about sensitivity for freedoms, about the importance of the Schengen system being restored as quickly as possible, because we know how it was when we didn’t have that opportunity.  So, whatever happens next week, and of course we are all very hopeful and optimistic that we will clinch the historic deal for the European Union, the German Presidency will coincide with the fateful moment in this European debate and in our history. I think if the European Council reaches an agreement, then the real work will start and we will have ahead of ourselves, together with you, a frantic semester of legislative activity to make sure that this investment can indeed re-energise Europe and revitalise the European economy to make it greener, cleaner, more digital and more resilient. And, to answer to my good colleague, Ismail Ertug, I believe that batteries will also be very high on the list of priorities.  To conclude, I would like to thank all of you for this very important debate and to thank Chancellor Merkel for a very ambitious programme for the next six months, which I know had to be adjusted because of the COVID crisis realities. But I believe that today, and in the next week, we will reach a very important agreement which will open a new chapter in European history, a new chapter in European integration.

name: Angela Merkel
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, I would like to thank the Yes, I just want to finish.  I would like to thank you for all the speeches. In the second round, the question has once again emerged: advocating the rule of law. We do this on the German side and also name the issues to our colleagues, even when it comes to Viktor Orban and we have disagreements about what is going on in Hungary. I believe that it is above all the absolutely legitimate interest of Parliament, but also of the European Council, for the money to arrive where it should go: that is, on the ground. We will, of course, monitor this together and attach great importance to this.  I can also reassure those who say that we should not just make german-French proposals. We know that Europe is made up of 27 Member States, and yet it is the case that if Germany and France have very different opinions, then most of the time, things are not really going ahead in Europe. In other words, one thing can be done, but never with the claim that a german-French proposal is now a European one, but then work must be done on it, and we will do so next week. I was pleased that the issue of agriculture was raised again. On closer examination, it is, of course, the case that we already have different views on this, if I only mention the keywords 'pillar 1' and 'pillar 2'. But if we want to be an ecological continent, we must also have organic food production, and we must have food production with us.  In other words, we must also accept and recognise farmers in what they are doing, while insisting that the issue of animal welfare be given better consideration, that the sustainable use of land be taken into account. For this, however, the economic and market-based framework conditions must also be made available, so that these constraints can really be managed. I was pleased that the issue of technology has once again played a role here, I think we can now take temporary debt, we can set up a building fund. However, we must then organise the repayment and agree on it immediately. And whether we start there in the next period or not better underline the credibility of the repayment by starting repayment within the next seven years, I think that is important. Permanent indebtedness cannot be Europe's response to international global competition. In other words, we must, on the one hand, rely on new technologies, and I hope that we will also be able to reflect this to some extent in the MFF. It is, of course, a danger if we have the Structural Funds on the one hand, and then, on the other hand, expenditure on innovation. However, Germany will also be in favour of strong funding for technology, especially as I very much welcome the fact that the Commission has adopted the hydrogen strategy today. We also have one in Germany, and many other Member States have one. I think it is good that we have these European projects of strategic interest. In addition to battery cell production, which has now got off to a good start, we will certainly have to do something about quantum technologies as well.  I would like to say to those who ask whether we want to renew Europe: of course, we must renew Europe every day. The world is changing, and if we stop, we will fall behind, so much is certain.  The fact that we have taken the country-specific recommendations as a basis is not a gown! Germany, too, is being criticised there, and rightly criticised, because we need to invest more in the future. We must all get on with this, try to get better and, in particular, use the resources of the Building Fund to do so. This will not be the last meeting with the European Parliament in these six months. I would like to thank all those who have endured to the end and I wish us good cooperation.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 171)

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Writing. – Angela Merkel is the right person to lead the European Union out of the current crisis. He has not only been a good leader for Germany, but for the whole of the European Union. In the current crisis, Germany is one of the few countries that is so strong that it is able to emerge from the crisis by acting alone. Angela Merkel was expected to send a message that Germany, europe's strongest economy, is ready to support the development of the whole of Europe by its own means. And this message came – Angela Merkel declared that Germany was ready to show extraordinary solidarity. Of course, this requires everyone else to make an appropriate contribution. Words together and together were used by Angela Merkel repeatedly. A strong Germany alone would not be able to compete equally with China and the United States. Mrs Merkel said the most important thing is for Europe to emerge stronger and more united from the crisis, so that Europe is innovative.

name: Robert BIEDROŃ
text: in writing. – I would like to warmly welcome German Presidency and its ambitious programme for the next half a year. We live in unprecedented times, so we need unprecedented solutions. I am very pleased that the German Presidency has devoted a lot of attention to social issues. In times of a real economic crisis, it should be our priority to protect citizens. We need horizontal remedies aimed at improving the situation of vulnerable people who suffered the most during the corona crisis. Eliminating poverty, increasing access to the labour market and building high-quality, inclusive education systems should be in the centre of our agenda and the future MFF will be a major contribution to this supporting recovery. But what ought to be highlighted is that the European Parliament is still waiting for the Council move on a number of issues: Dublin IV, Horizontal Anti-Discrimination Directive and effective solutions in terms of the Rule of Law crisis. I hope the German Presidency will be the one to address these issues promptly.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – I would like to thank the honourable Chancellor for presenting the programme of the German Presidency. During your presidency, we will have to make difficult decisions about the future multiannual financial framework and mobilise forces to combat the COVID pandemic and its consequences. From your speech, we send a clear message that Germany is determined to help Europe meet the huge challenge of the pandemic, as well as to build a greener, more innovative, sustainable, competitive and digital Europe. We fully agree that a pandemic must not serve as a pretext for the principles of democracy. We also welcome the priority areas you have identified, but we must at the same time respond appropriately to the economic and social consequences of the pandemic. We expect support and funding from Germany for our people who have lost their jobs and income, to pay more attention to the most vulnerable members of society and to much more funding for social measures in the future financial perspective.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – The German Presidency of the Council, which is now starting, has a programme which is clear as to what Germany expects from an integration process of which it is the first and main beneficiary. The most significant event of this presidency is likely to be the adoption of the so-called Recovery Plan and the Multiannual Financial Framework, the EU budget by 2027. As for the first, of which Germany will receive in grants roughly twice as much as Portugal, this instrument is clearly insufficient in view of existing investment needs. Moreover, it is significant that the German government has mobilised to intervene in your country much more than what it has proposed for the recovery fund to meet the situation of 27 Member States. As for the budget, the need for growth of funds for economic and social cohesion is expected to be compromised. The enlargement and deepening of the single market, in a context of worsening inequalities between States, will create the conditions for an even greater concentration of capital at European level. The so-called reindustrialisation and relocation of value chains cannot be done on the basis of the exclusive interest of the main European powers. On the contrary, it must take into account above all the interests and needs of countries, such as Portugal, which are most affected by deindustrialisation.

name: Carlo FIDANZA
text: in writing. Merkel makes a walkway in a Chamber of eunuchs who slavishly pay tribute to her regardless of the dramatic situation in Europe, not only because of the Coronavirus but because of too many years of wrong choices wanted by the Chancellor. The usual platitudes, the usual rhetorical optimism about the EU's thaumaturgical properties, a decomposed attack on populists and a border in Orban to please the left and the confirmation of the privileged axis with France. Not a word about the role of the ECB since the German Court's ruling, about the excess state aid – largely always German – that is drugting the internal market, about the excessive trade surplus in defiance of every treaty or about the mountain of toxic derivatives in the belly of German banks. Nothing even about Turkey's growing aggression in the Mediterranean and China around the world. As always, the manoeuvrer maneuvers undisturbed and the victims stand up to applaud and become accomplices.

name: Patryk JAKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Poland expects the German Presidency, above all, to treat all EU Member States equally. The Presidency's programme focuses on 6 themes, one of which is a fair Europe. In Poland, we are counting on justice in the first place. Today we are unpardonablely attacked. We understand that everyone has the right to their political sympathies, but we should not use the EU institutions, which should be above political divisions, to fight politically. We do not want the Union to go beyond its competences. We count on balance and justice. We are very Polish the government will cooperate, but there is a need to cooperate on the other hand. The fear of sanctions, constant attacks, the creation of artificial problems and the destruction of my country's image must end. Poland sees its field to build a strong European position on the international stage, wants a safe and innovative continent. However, we must build all this on a partnership basis.

name: Beata MAZUREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The motto of this Presidency is 'Together we will rebuild Europe'. I hope that it will not be an empty slogan, but will translate into real action to pull Europe out of the crisis. A properly functioning single market should be at the heart of the recovery of the European Union's economy after the COVID-19 pandemic. We should focus not only on re-functioning it, but also on further strengthening and developing it.  Poland has consistently supported the elimination of all administrative barriers and obstacles that limit the cross-border activities of entrepreneurs. It is also necessary to ensure that existing rules are properly implemented in the Member States. We cannot use the pandemic to introduce protectionist measures. An example of such action is the social and market part of Mobility Package I currently being prepared, which is contrary to the objectives of climate policy but, above all, does not take into account the new economic reality and the key role played by the transport sector in maintaining supply chains. When we talk about community in the fight against the effects of COVID-19, we cannot put the interests of some above the interests of others.  Another issue is the European Green Deal. Here, too, there is an unequal treatment of Member States in terms of adapting to the 'energy revolution'. If we want to act and make changes effectively, we must do so with the respect and understanding of all the participants in the European Community.

name: Leszek MILLER
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The programme of the German Presidency of the Council will determine the challenges arising from the coronavirus pandemic in Europe. The most serious problem to be faced will be the economic downturn. The weakening of Member States' economies will increase competition from non-EU countries, which will be encouraged by falling share prices of European companies to take over. Exiting the crisis will therefore require the Presidency to build a majority for the Commission's draft plan for Europe's economic recovery and the 2021-2027 budget.  The main challenges are the issuance of common bonds secured by Member States' contributions, the implementation of the European Green Deal, the digital sovereignty of the Union and European industrial policy. The search for a compromise between Member States may be facilitated by the fact that the Federal Republic of Germany merges the Presidency of the Council with the status of the strongest EU economy and the largest contributor to the EU budget. On the other hand, the absence of such an agreement during a State Presidency of such a crucial importance in the Union would indicate a serious structural crisis.  In addition, negotiations on the Union's future relationship with the United Kingdom will be a challenge for the Federal Presidency. The Brexit transition period ends on 31 December and, in view of the likelihood of negotiations not extending, it will be up to the German Presidency to propose and conclude a final EU-UK compromise. All these problems are also compounded by the need to discuss the future of Europe at the forth coming conference.

name: Gheorghe-Vlad NISTOR
text: in writing. – Today, Chancellor Angela Merkel is in the plenary of the European Parliament to present to us the priorities of the German Presidency of the Council of the European Union. I welcome his presence in our midst and look optimistically towards the next 6 months of this particularly difficult year. The Chancellor listed the key components of the German Semester and highlighted solidarity, cohesion, innovation and digital and green development as the main directions of his strategy. The current moment is a particularly difficult one, on many levels. Germany had already taken on ambitious goals, and these will overlap with the difficult challenges facing the whole Union at this point, caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. I am confident of Chancellor Merkel's ability to manage such moments of crisis. The German Government's commitment to the European project is well-known and will hopefully give a new impetus to the European Union. I consider the current situation to be favourable, and the auspices seem to be on the Union side. I urge the current Presidency to pay close attention not only to the Union's difficult internal challenges, but also to the complex international situation, in which the EU is a key player. It is necessary to continue the traditional transatlantic link and the alliance with the US and to be vigilant in relation to other international partners.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. – Angela Merkel, who presented the roadmap for the German Presidency, negaded european unity. Given the turbulent times we have today, it is important to recall that most things are better, both in Europe and internationally, if EU countries are able to agree and deliver big things together. Priority is given to the development of a coherent EU Policy for China, which is solely thoughtful from the point of view of foreign and security policy, but hardly achievable with just one presidency. Another priority is the development of Europe's relations with Africa, and as President-in-Office, Germany will have the opportunity to propose a way forward with the EU's policy on Africa with a view to reducing poverty and the resulting migratory pressure.

name: Guido REIL
text: Writing. The European Unemployment Reinsurance Scheme, which the German Presidency describes as part of the European Pillar of Social Rights, is a mistake. A Community model such as unemployment reinsurance relieves the Member States of their responsibility for creating functioning labour markets. Instead, it creates a new funding pot, a "bail-out mechanism" for countries that are themselves in financial trouble. Unemployment reinsurance saves individual Member States corrections of their own political errors and shifts the financial burden to other Member States. Moreover, a 'fair Europe' means for the German Presidency that it actively supports the further development of the Commission's proposal to develop and introduce an EU framework for national minimum wages. I see it differently. This initiative is not only illegal, but also economically harmful. It is illegal because it is contrary to the Treaties and the established case law of the ECJ and cannot be based on the Charter of Fundamental Rights. It is economically and politically damaging, because it misses the fundamental fact that the labour markets of the various Member States are very different. The respective roles of the state and the social partners vary, as do the mixture of legislation and collective bargaining to regulate wages, working time and employment protection. This proposal has a significant impact.

name: Christine SCHNEIDER
text: Writing. I stand behind the presidency's motto: together. Make Europe strong again. The EU is capable of great things if it holds together. I hope that solidarity between the Member States will prevail. The current challenges are the EU's biggest test since its inception. And only together will we stand.

name: Loránt VINCZE
text: Writing. Mrs Chancellor, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the excellent work she has done on this Mr President, I would like to thank the president for his excellent work It is an important sign that you have personally come to Brussels to present to us the German Presidency programme. Following the pandemic crisis, joint steps are needed at European level, which will make us all stronger. This year's crisis has shown us that the EU still lacks some visible features. Joint coordination has been delayed. People often asked the question: "Where has Europe gone?". Now we have to take decisions that will bring our economy, the European internal market, but also health systems, education and our diverse culture back into shape. This is also a justified demand of our citizens. Great challenges are ahead, but if we can learn from our past mistakes, we will create a better future. It is good to read that the Presidency wants to work to strengthen the fundamental values of Europe. These values include respect for the rights of indigenous, traditional minorities, who, as Europeans, have been contributing to our European diversity and culture for centuries. It is true that Europe can only succeed together, and I am quite sure that citizens belonging to a national, traditional minority must participate and will participate.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Written. "Much is expected of the German Presidency in Europe, and the list of issues requiring a solution is long. With regard to the Recovery Fund and the MFF, the financing of the priorities set and the need to keep member states' responsibilities moderate should be reconciled. In order for the package to be balanced, the loan weighting of the Recovery Fund still needs to be increased, repayment accelerated and the overall level lowered. More important than the size of the recovery fund and the financial framework, however, is how the money is spent. In order for the debt now to be taken out to create the conditions for future growth, investments must be made correctly. In relation to the proposals now on the table, additional funding must be channeled towards new growth: education, research, defence, digitalisation, the transition towards a carbon-neutral society and investment in infrastructure. In the last MFF proposals, funding for the CEF and defence sectors, for example, has sunk far too low, and leadership is needed from Germany in this. In addition to the Recovery Fund and the financial framework, there are three acute challenges to be solved, in which we must finally move forward. The first is the rule of law, where problems can be addressed when the financial framework is agreed. The second acute challenge relates to immigration policy, for which common solutions must be found before the new immigration crisis. In the midst of all this, a solution should also be found to the future relationship between the UK and the EU, which is threatened by the end of the brexit deal transition period at the end of the year. I am confident that, under German leadership, we will be able to agree solutions to all of these when we prioritise correctly and only look beyond the years to come.

name: Bettina VOLLATH
text: Writing. – "Together. Making Europe strong again." – Under this motto, the German Presidency wants to lead Europe out of the crisis and into a positive future. There is much to be done about this. First and foremost, we must place the European reconstruction plan, which does not ignore the climate, and the further European approach to the pandemic. In parallel with the COVID-19 crisis, however, major challenges also arising. Asylum reform, conditionality, digitalisation and the future of the Union are central issues. Fundamental rights and cohesion should be two of the cornerstones of the German Presidency. Both will be crucial on these issues – as principles in the establishment of an asylum system that respects the fundamental and human rights of all, in tying EU funds to respect for the rule of law, in a digital transformation that focuses on the social aspect of digitisation, and as a guide to a future conference that sets the course for ever closer European cooperation. In all this, fundamental rights and cohesion must form the basis of all action. So that we can live in a fairer and more united Union in the future – and thus remain more than two key words after the next six months!

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – As an MEP for the UDMR, I wholeheartedly support the priorities of the German Presidency of the EU, as presented in the EP plenary by Chancellor Angela Merkel. "Together" is the key word of the German Presidency. This gives me hope, because the extraordinary challenges that we must respond to over the next 6 months can only be overcome together and in solidarity. Germany takes over the rotating EU presidency at a crucial time, when the pandemic has induced economic consequences of unprecedented gravity in the last 90 years. The EU must provide fair support to Member States in the most difficult economic situations because of the pandemic. Of the 5 priorities, cohesion is the most important, with the preservation of the funding of cohesion and agricultural policy in the new European budget being essential. As a representative of the Hungarian community in Romania, I welcome the inclusion of fundamental rights among the priorities. The EU is built on values, and national minorities are a value and a wealth. I hope that under the German Presidency of the Council the regulation of the objectives of the Minority Safe Pack will be supported. By including in European law the provisions of the MSPI, members of the communities of national minorities in the EU will benefit from effective equality of rights and the elimination of discrimination to which they are still subject.

name: Anna ZALEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Chancellor Angela Merkel presented the priorities of the German Presidency of the European Council during today's plenary session of the European Parliament. Noting that Europe should become "greener, more digital and more competitive", she referred to the Green Deal, whose legal framework is the subject of the work of the ENVI Committee.  Poland is in a difficult situation because its economy is primarily based on fossil deposits. Huge efforts by governments, local governments and energy m.in include reducing CO2 emissions and investing in renewable energy. An example is the energy and mining complex "Turów", which since the 1960s has responded to all reservations from czech and German neighbours, adapting to new environmental conditions.  Efforts to extend the concession in 2020 have been met with resistance and criticism from czech border towns. The complaint signed by the 13 000 inhabitants of the Liberec Country regarding the closure of the "Turów" mine has been lodged with the European Parliament and is to be the subject of the work of the Committee on Petitions.  I am deeply concerned. Complex "Turów" together with cooperating companies gives work to about 15 thousand inhabitants of the region. Its dismantling would mean a collapse of the labour market in the region and dramatic social changes. Workers, trade unionists, residents of Polish, the Czech Republic and Germany do not agree to actions aimed at hindering the work of "Turnov", which is why they submit about 30 000 signatures to the Committee on Petitions in the European Parliament, supporting the functioning of the company.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. Despite decades of forced integration and in the midst of an ever-worsening economic crisis, negotiations and discussions between Member States on the Recovery Fund continue to be on the European scene. This is the background to the German Presidency, which, instead of insisting on a centralist model, should focus on revising the rules and treaties that have long oppressed the Member States.  The fear is that Germany, eager to define the dossiers dear to it as soon as possible, will hasten the conclusion of the agreement on the European economic recovery plan.  The premises of this presidency are not among the best and this vision is also suggested by the approaches adopted towards Russia, on whose soil the issue of the dispute with the USA for the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline insists. Not least the issue of Brexit, which is central in the current six months, which will put the Germans in front of the test of managing the final phase of relations with the UK. We need a leader who drags Europe out of the impasse, who protects the health of citizens in this serious period of pandemic, who does not just represent his own interests, but gives priority to those states that have suffered most from the consequences of the crisis.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – The German Presidency of the European Union (EU) starts a trio of presidencies which also includes the Portuguese and Slovenian Presidencies, which will play a decisive role in the recovery and transformation of the EU.  By paraphrasing the mobilising line of the Presidency, we will only be able to recover the Union together and respond to the expectations of the citizens. I welcome the priorities set. They will make a difference if they are achieved quickly and effectively.  Health overcoming requires a successful implementation of the public health strategy. Economic and social recovery depends on the rapid realisation of the solidarity fund. A strong and innovative Europe needs to be well-implemented by programmes such as Horizon Europe, Digital Europe or the European Space Programme. A fair Europe must focus on convergence and employment policies. A sustainable Europe needs to deliver on the Green Deal. A Security Europe requires coordination in cybersecurity and defence policies. A strong Europe in the world depends on the multilateral vision and the multiplication of partnerships between equals.  If you realise environmental, digital and social ambition without weakening into confidence-destroying economic constraints, the German Presidency has all the conditions to be a positive milestone in the future of the EU.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Before continuing with the debates, I would like to inform you that the first round of voting will be opened at 4.30 p.m. We shall vote on the dossiers on the agenda adopted today at the opening of the sitting. Voting time, which will be open at 4.30 p.m., will close at 5.45 p.m. The votes will take place in the same way as in the previous part-session. For the reports on the appointment of Helga Berger as a member of the Court of Auditors and the appointment of the Executive Director of the European Banking Authority, the votes will be held by secret ballot.  Members will be able to vote as usual, but the voting card they have to sign will not indicate the vote cast, but only the fact that they voted.  All other votes will be by roll call. Explanations of vote may be submitted in writing. Exceptionally, explanations of vote of up to 400 words will be accepted.  I declare the first voting time open. You have until 5.45 p.m. to vote. The results will be announced at 20.00.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the joint debate on the statements by the European Council and the Commission on the conclusions of the European Council meeting of 19 June 2020 (2020/2669(SRR)), and - the declarations of the European Council and the Commission on the preparation of the European Council meeting of 17 and 18 July 2020 (2020/2704(RSP)).

name: Charles Michel
text: President of the European Council. Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank you for this opportunity to speak with you.  COVID—19 has shown that we can't always control what happens to us, but we can control how we respond. Let's not forget that the pandemic is still with us. As we speak, it continues to destroy lives, businesses and jobs. One statistic alone paints the dramatic picture. Compared to pre-COVID growth forecasts, the EU is estimated to lose EUR 1.5 trillion euros in economic output in 2020-2021 alone. This is indeed a grim prospect.  As you know, on 23 April, the European Council asked the Commission to urgently come up with an ambitious recovery plan that was commensurate with the challenge we are facing. In June, leaders had a first discussion on the Commission proposals. I will say more about this in a minute, but our initial discussion highlighted that some elements of the Commission proposal were simply not acceptable for a number of Member States. That's why, after our meeting, I launched the process of bilateral talks with all the leaders. I then called a physical summit, the first since the crisis, on 17 and 18 July.  There are three issues in particular that I would like to discuss with you. One is my traditional debrief to you on the leaders' video conference in June. The second is to clarify the outcome of my bilateral meetings with leaders and share with you my intentions for the upcoming European Council. And lastly, I wish to make a strong appeal for ambitious cooperation between the Member States and with you, the European Parliament. We need to work together if we want to make this work. Our last video conference of the European Council on 19 June was the first time EU leaders discussed together the Commission's proposals for the multiannual financial framework (MFF) and the Recovery Fund. This summit was a necessary step to prepare for the decisions we need to take. It served as a bridge connecting the consultation phase to our current negotiation phase. We noted the areas where consensus is emerging. First, Member States agreed on the need to address together the MFF and the Recovery Fund. They agreed that an unprecedented crisis required an unprecedented response and third point - they also agreed that we would focus on the regions and sectors most affected.  But we also observed areas where our views still needed to converge. For instance, the idea of loans for grants is still difficult, even very difficult, to accept for some Member States. Similarly, some leaders showed reluctance to accept the allocation criteria suggested by the Commission because they considered that there is no link in the current proposal with the COVID—19 crisis and the consequences of the COVID—19 crisis.  Last week, I concluded my first round of bilateral discussions. They have been intense and sometimes difficult, even very difficult, but always in a constructive spirit. This allowed me to identify the six building blocks of a possible future agreement on which I think we need to find the right political balance. First, the size of the MFF. Firstly, the size of the next European budget. You know that there are different opinions about the level that is acceptable. And the second point, which is linked to the first, is the question of corrections, the 'rebates', since, for some Member States, this point is essential. For others, this point no longer needs to be. This will certainly be one of the issues that we will have to rely on in a possible comprehensive agreement. The third point is the level of the recovery fund - you are aware of the proposal put forward by the Commission - not all Member States share the conviction that the proposed amount must be accepted. The fourth point, as I mentioned earlier, is the issue of borrowing and subsidies. The very principle of subsidies poses difficulties for a number of Member States. And the balance of balance between borrowing and subsidies is another sensitive issue on which decisions must be taken. The fifth point - I would like to dwell on it for a moment - is the question of allocation criteria under the recovery fund. Many Member States expressed their reluctance in June to the extent that they consider that the Commission's proposal, which is based on pre-crisis data (these data being the level of unemployment, the reverse GDP criterion and the population criterion), is not sufficiently dynamic, adequate, to take into account what the real situation will be in terms of economic impact , and therefore social, for regions and therefore countries and sectors that are more affected. That is why we are testing the idea of taking a slightly more dynamic approach to the allocation criteria in question. Finally, the sixth point, which is a very essential point is the question of the link between this recovery fund, the reforms that need to be implemented in the different Member States and how to organise governance, the role of the different institutions. There is certainly a debate here which also concerns the European Parliament and its role very directly. Also in terms of conditions or links with the recovery fund and with the MFF issue in particular, the question of the rule of law is also an issue that needs to be debated. The issue of the link with climate ambition is also extremely important. You will recall that a few months ago we proposed before the start of the crisis that a significant part of the MFF should be directly linked to our climate ambition. And I would like to remind you that in December we set this very strong ambition for the European Union to achieve climate neutrality in 2050. There are also other issues at stake which I know are crucial to you, the European Parliament. First, own resources and I'm aware that these are key for your agreement. We worked a lot on plastic waste and on the Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS). There is some reluctance on that, but we have also looked at other possible resources that have gathered some support, like digital taxation and financial taxation. Flexibility in the MFF for cohesion and agriculture is also an important topic for some Member States and there are two other issues that we need to tackle in order to try to reach an agreement. The first is the issue of the front—loading in the Recovery Fund and the question of the commitments and payments, the timing we need for both, and the issue of the repayments. When do we start the repayments? You know that the Commission proposed to start the repayments not in the upcoming MFF, but in the next one. Maybe it would be useful to propose to start the repayments earlier. Looking at the next steps, as you probably know, I have announced that I intend to publish a negotiating box by the end of this week. Together with the German Presidency, we will discuss this further in Coreper, the meetings with all the Ambassadors, and these processes allow us to prepare thoroughly for our July European Council summit.  I can assure you I am doing all I can to secure an agreement. We need to find a workable solution quickly. My assessment, my impression, after this extremely intense round of consultations over the last few days and the last two or three weeks, since the last Council, is this: we are not yet at the end of the negotiation, a great deal of work remains necessary and my conviction is that we can make progress on the condition that the Member States are determined to cooperate more with each other. My conviction is also that it will be essential, because the crisis is unprecedented, that cooperation between the European democratic institutions is also unprecedented and up to the challenge we are facing.  Be sure that I am listening to this call from the European Parliament to be fully mobilised, to take full responsibility for the decisions that will have to be taken. You can count on me in full partnership with the Rotating Presidency to ensure that, as best we can, we can make progress together. Finally, a common-sense conviction that I must share with you: we will only succeed if everyone agrees to take a step towards the other. If everyone, Member State or institution, remains frozen, blocked, immobilized by its initial problem, there will be no solution and we will not be up to the challenge for this European project that brings us together. The only option is to take a step towards each other in order to be able not only to carry this European interest with ambition, but also with the realistic conviction that one must take into account the point of view of the other, in order to be able to make decisions together. It is this call that I want to make to all of you today. In conclusion, more than ever, this debate is very fundamental, because the amounts at stake are unprecedented in the history of the European Union, at the same time a European budget for the next seven years and a recovery fund, the amounts discussed are indeed totally gigantic. My conviction is that we must be inhabited by three objectives, which we cannot lose sight of, which we must try to achieve in parallel. The first is the objective of continuing what has fuelled this European project from the beginning: convergence, ensuring that we can continue to work, to work tirelessly for the European convergence which is also and will be the strength of this European project.  Working also - recent history has shown - for resilience, the ability tomorrow to be stronger, to learn from this crisis, to learn from this crisis and to ensure that we have the capacity to respond better, more appropriately and stronger. And finally, the third objective that I think must, constantly keep in our political sights: the transformation of the European project on the basis of the digital agenda, on the basis of this need to take into account the climate as an opportunity to make the European Union stronger, stronger, whole oriented towards a future that we must build confidently , in an optimized way. I can see that the issue is difficult, I can see that the stakes are high. Be convinced, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, that I am very determined, not only to move the debate forward in the European Council, but very quickly, as long as it has been able to move forward and take a step forward with a decision taken, I intend, to be entirely focused on positive dialogue, constructive with the institutions and especially with the European Parliament.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, as we discussed just a moment ago, it’s quite clear that our Union is undergoing a great crisis – one that has engulfed not only Europe, but the whole world. The COVID—19 pandemic has had a horrific human and economic cost. I would say that it also has changed us. Therefore, I am sure that you would agree with me that there is no going back to the way things used to be. Therefore, we must now look to the future. If we act decisively we can find opportunity in this disaster. But for that we need the right tools for the job. As you know, I often say that this Chamber is the heartbeat of European democracy, a place where policy is debated and shaped, but no matter how much we talk about the political priorities, we must have the money to implement them.  Ahead of the European Council next week, I would like to focus on two points with you, both of which hold great significance for our future. First, the state of play with regard to the Next Generation EU recovery plan and the revamped Multiannual Financial Framework proposals.  I really would like to thank the President of the European Council for his very active approach for the very dynamic bilaterals he had with the heads of state and governments of the European Union and for the close cooperation with the Commission. All this is needed, because this is a very ambitious package that responds directly and forcefully to the needs of our Union. The future MFF reinforced by the Next Generation EU crisis instrument will bring the total financial firepower of the EU budget to almost EUR two trillion in today’s money – that’s a very impressive, but at the same time a very necessary figure. It is a necessary response to what is a crisis without precedence in the history of the European Union. It is the plan designed not only to see us through the first years of recovery, but also to ensure our financial programmes can deliver strong support for our priorities until 2027 and beyond.  I would like first to stress that the European Parliament plays, and will continue to play, a vitally important role in this process. Later today, President von der Leyen, together with President Michel and Chancellor Merkel, with President Sassoli, will meet under Article 324 where we will start, through – and I believe thanks to – our leaders, the first convergence of views creating an atmosphere conducive to the compromise which will be needed at the leaders’ summit on 17 and 18 July to which President Michel just referred. The meeting will follow on from the encouraging discussions the leaders had during the recent video conference. Overall, we in the Commission feel that there is a positive dynamic in support of the proposals which I have just described. In particular, there is an agreement that this unprecedented crisis required an exceptional response. There is an agreement that this response should be financed through Commission borrowing and there is also agreement on the fact that own resources really need to be increased. In addition, we feel there is agreement that our efforts should be targeted towards Europe’s most affected regions, fostering cohesion and convergence and that this crisis and the response which we are debating right now will create a unique opportunity to reform our economies and make them greener, more digital and more resilient. The proposed package reflects much of what was expressed by Parliament in the resolution of 15 May. In particular, I would like to thank this House for its continued support for the new own resources. Like you, we are convinced that this is the right approach. New own resources will support our shared objectives. They will help us repay what we borrow for Next Generation EU without compromising the funding of our future programmes. While we are taking a big step forward in the coming weeks by agreeing on the proposals already on the table, we can take a giant leap when we set out new proposals next year. We will soon put forward a roadmap for these extra resources, on how to achieve these new own resources. In the meantime, I count on you to help relay the message, also at home to your governments, to your constituencies and to the national parliaments, as to how much we need their support, because time is of the essence, leadership is needed more than any time before, and we have only a few weeks left. We all know that it’s absolutely crucial for our response to the crisis to reach agreement before the summer break if we want to make sure that before the end of the year we will also complete the process of national ratifications needed for the own resources decision. Not only are we unable to start borrowing without this decision, but if the national parliaments endorse the debate, the results and these new instruments, I believe that it would also ensure the democratic legitimacy of these innovative proposals on an unprecedented wide scale.  To continue, I also would like to underline the fact that this would also help us to create the new tools not only for sustainable economic recovery, but also for clear demonstrations that our democratic rules will always prevail even in times of crisis. So an extremely constructive approach by all institutions is required and therefore I think that we need to listen to each other and factor in our different views at all stages of the process. Certainly, the involvement of this Parliament in all aspects is fundamental. Every euro will be spent through programmes co-designed and co-decided by this Parliament. You will play a strong scrutiny role through the budget discharge and because of legal constraints we are relying on an extraordinary system to mobilise the extra recovery funding, but this should in no way prevent either this Parliament or the Council from playing their roles to the full. Special arrangements will be put in place to ensure that this is the case. We are ready to work with you and the Council on the institutional declaration, to put this on a formal footing and to ensure that cooperation among our institutions is as fast as it can be. As I said already, time is short but I’m confident that with the right mix of ambition, realism and leadership we can deliver for the citizens of the European Union. The Commission will need your help, and we will need to be quick in all phases of negotiations. This includes agreement on our bridging proposal to jump start the recovery plan under the current MFF as well. The sooner we can launch REACT-EU and the solvency support instrument, the better. My second point today concerns Brexit. As you know, my colleague Michel Barnier is today in London where another round of negotiations is taking place. I think it’s very important because we are now less than six months away from the end of the transition period. Together with the United Kingdom, we recently took stock of the ongoing negotiations where we jointly stressed our willingness to undertake all possible efforts to come to an agreement, seeking solutions that will allow us to sign a one-of-a-kind partnership. Since then, as you know, not much progress has been made. Yet the simple truth is that the negotiations will in a few months one way or another. So if we are to reach an agreement, we will have to resolve a number of serious divergences on fundamental issues. These relate to the robust guarantees for a level playing field, a balanced agreement on fisheries, and an effective governance framework.  You of course know these points very well, and you know that they are important for us because of the principles of fair competition, the protection of our citizens – principles which are at the very heart of our Union. We will do everything possible to reach an agreement but here, too, time is very short and no one can say with certainty where the negotiations will lead us by the end of the year. Even if we do reach a deal, many things will still change in our relationship with the United Kingdom – for citizens, for businesses, for administration. We therefore need to plan for these changes and we will continue to assist the national authorities and other stakeholders in their preparations.  Alongside the negotiations, as President von der Leyen emphasised to the leaders, we must continue our work to ensure proper implementation of the Withdrawal Agreement, which is a precondition for the establishment and maintaining of trust. As a Co—Chair of the EU—UK Joint Committee, I can add that we are also moving into a higher gear on this front and will remain very attentive on all its dimensions.  European unity continues to be our main asset, and the European Parliament is of course also in this regard playing an important role in all of its work. I am deeply grateful for your unwavering support as laid out in the report adopted by this Parliament on 18 June.  Thank you very much for your attention and for all the support that will be needed in the coming days and weeks.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to welcome President Michel to the European Parliament. We are listening to you. We are worried, and we do not agree with you. We are worried because you are not informing and not involving Parliament in talks on the budget as you should, because this House is a budgetary authority. And we cannot agree with you because you are going to propose a smaller budget for a European Union that has to do more, and simply we cannot do more with a smaller budget. The EU budget is not the same as magic beans, and does not become bigger just when the members of the European Council look at it. I have to be clear: the European Parliament can only give its consent on the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) if the MFF will finance properly what we have jointly agreed on.  What are our demands? Firstly, that we finance properly the traditional priorities of the European Union – agriculture and cohesion. Secondly, that we keep our promises and finance, according to our promises, the new priorities – digitalisation, greening, protecting the environment, research, development, innovation, external borders, migration. We cannot solve the coronavirus crisis by creating problems in other areas through under-financing. Please convey to the European Council members the following message: we cannot hide a small MFF behind the recovery package.  On the recovery package, money should be well spent. Firstly, it should be spent on modernising Europe, it should be spent on projects with European added value. Secondly, the more money we spend, the better the control needs to be. Thirdly, we need to provide a repayment plan. Every citizen, every enterprise, when they take a loan, needs to provide a repayment plan. They need to say when and how they will pay it back. As the European Union, we should do the same.  Own resources: we should introduce the plastic tax now, pay the interest rates and start repayment before 2027 and have a binding plan, a binding calendar on the other own resources. Only if these demands of Parliament are met will we be able to give our consent in the end. And whatever deal, whatever compromise you reach in the Council, we are ready to talk to you, to negotiate beforehand, because the deal of the Council will not be the final deal; the views of Parliament will need to be taken into account.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, the pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 177,000 European compatriots, mostly elderly people without whose sacrifice the European project we continue to build today would not be understood; also of many women who, from the health and social services sectors, have sacrificed their lives to protect us, not forgetting the victims of gender-based violence as a result of confinement. In turn, this human catastrophe has caused a social tragedy, because the virus has confined the expectations and future of millions of young Europeans. This generation, which was in the 1920s in 2008 and now in the 1930s, is facing its second economic crisis in just twelve years. Many generations have been forged by traumatic events; events so often marked by fear and uncertainty; life-changing events that force people to take risks. And, on this life journey, time also conditions life. After several months of pandemic, July must be the month for the agreement on the recovery fund and the budget of the European Union. Present and future generations must feel that the European Union is an economic security space in their lives. And, thanks to Parliament's power in this negotiation, I am convinced that we will be able to do so. The Social Democrats will not accept less than EUR 500 billion in subsidies provided for by the Commission. Nor will we accept any kind of macroeconomic conditionality, because we already know what austerity means: weaker conditions for workers and deep cuts in social spending. We cannot allow us to return to austerity policies. And, of course, in the allocation of aid, our support will depend on strict compliance with the rule of law and the proper use of funds. Young people are the least affected by the virus, but they are much more exposed to the economic consequences, so the pandemic cannot be an excuse not to tackle inequality through the European social pillar, with the implementation of the children's guarantee and European unemployment insurance. Because no one in a society can feel safe without a job. Our commitment and solidarity with future generations also requires the transformation of our economy to address the challenges of climate change and the digital revolution. And in order to finance the recovery fund and the ecological and digital transition, without strangling the public accounts of the Member States, we need to address the debate and the proposal of own resources. That is why this debate is so fundamental to us. If the most disadvantaged classes rescued the financial sector in the previous crisis, it is now up to markets and multinationals to contribute to a fair recovery. The bankruptcy of the social pact leads to radicalization, populism and confrontation between generations. The future of a generation and the survival of the European project will depend on the success of this plan.
