Mr Michel, I ask you — and I also know you will — that, during the negotiations in the coming days with the Prime Ministers, I look you in the eye and ask you this: if we cannot guarantee the citizens that their lives will be better, then why are we here? This Parliament is really clear and we are going to work for it. And I am convinced that, among all of us, we will be able to defend a strong, fair and supportive project.

name: Valérie HAYER
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Mr President of the European Council, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this recovery plan is unprecedented and it must be the advent of a concrete Europe. The final agreement that will come out of this Chamber will have to change the daily lives of Europeans, from Brest to Athens, from Sofia to Helsinki. For this reason, 500 billion subsidies are a minimum to avoid economic and social erosion.  Mr President, our political family will be vigilant on two points in particular. Two points that will determine our support, or not, for this interstate agreement. The first condition is to make new resources of their own, in the plural, to repay the loan. Let's be clear! We will not satisfy the plastic contribution alone. I recognise that taking a common position on this issue is not an easy task. Nor is it in this chamber. But we did. We have surpassed our divisions, sometimes calibrated our ambitions, to move forward. Today, the urgency of taking out this great loan without weighing on future generations must guide the agreement between states. Let's put the burden on GAFA, multinationals that practice tax optimization, big polluters.  The second condition is a mechanism for the protection of the rule of law, effective and activatable in the facts. That is a value in our treaties. It is no less important than the objective of economic convergence. In other words, we no longer want the autocrats Orban, Kaczynski and their friends to use the taxes of European citizens to establish their autocratic hold in their country, in our Europe. Mr President, I wish you all the best. Our political family, at the heart of a Parliament united in its priorities, expects an agreement from this summit. In the process, we will be ready to negotiate to ensure a green and prosperous future for the next generation of Europeans. A democratic and debt-free future, if not recognition.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, the Council discussed the European recovery plan on 19 June and will discuss it again on 17 and 18 July. We are moving towards EUR 750 billion, including 500 grants and 250 loans. I am against this project for three reasons. First of all, this plan will lead to a European mutualisation of debt to the tune of EUR 500 billion, which will be a further step towards the creation of a European federal state which my group does not want. Then you have to be naïve to believe that this money will be distributed without consideration. The EU will impose drastic conditions to affect it, including the reduction of pensions and health spending. Finally, Germany and France will pay. However, if Germany has the means to afford this generosity, this is not the case for France, whose debt already reaches 120% of its gross domestic product. President Macron, who is one of the instigators of this recovery plan, seems to have forgotten that the first duty of a head of state is to take care of the future of his own people.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, Mr President of the European Council, I must confess that I am sympathetic to your situation because if we here in Parliament must find a majority, you must find unanimity. And there is a small difference between the two, of course, since the lowest can be the one that sets the dancing rhythm. So I'm really supportive of the difficulty of your situation. So I wonder: but what could you possibly tell them? Because, in the end, there are recalcitrants. So what could you possibly tell them? You could say to them: yes, you are afraid of the amount, but frankly what are we talking about? We are talking about 1.5 percentage points of GDP for three years, in the face of a recession that this year may be 9 or 10 per cent of GDP. Compared to the efforts that are being made, for example in the United States, you are talking about "huge" amounts, but in reality they are not that huge. So let's put it in perspective. And I'm sure you're already using that argument. The second objection that we can make to you, and to which I am sensitive, is this: are we not finally going to go into debt to, in fact, spend that money on lost funds? In other words, will all this not get lost in unnecessary uses, tax giveaways, what else do I know? And there is the question of conditionality. I know it is a theme that is trapped but I think it is very important. And I think that the conditionalities that are required in the world that we have today are: conditionality in democracy and the rule of law and conditionality in terms of useful investments. And what could be more useful today than to invest, certainly in countries in difficulty, but in tools that will improve the economy of the entire continent? Indeed, it is in the investment in the ecological and solidarity transition and in the investment in the digital transition that the conditionalities must be found. If we really imagine that it is by imposing austerity, as we did ten years ago, that we will improve our common lot, then hello! We tested for you, we saw the results, I think it's completely next to the plate. The last point that I think should be made with regard to the recalcitrants is this: what will they say - pass me the expression - if the result of the non-decision in favour of a European plan is the break-up of the euro zone? I would like to know where the prosperity of the Scandinavians will be, the prosperity of the Austrians, the prosperity of the Dutch when the monetary union is passed by profits and losses. And in its wake, perhaps, European integration. It is a matter that our prosperity, individual at the national level - and here I totally disagree with Mr. Lebreton - depends on the prosperity of the whole. And so I agree that there is no question of investing with lost funds, but it would be a total historical mistake to risk the end of monetary union and therefore the end of the European Union for reasons which, let me put it bluntly, are vulgarly electoralist.

name: Johan VAN OVERTVELDT
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, I think it is an understatement to say that the corona crisis has seriously shaken the economic fabric, society in general. The worst economic crisis in 100 years. It is now up to the authorities – and, of course, the European institutions – to provide citizens and businesses with the necessary security, because citizens and businesses are in danger of going head-to-head in a tsunami of uncertainty. The recovery fund that has been proposed certainly contains levers that can contribute to this, but I think we need to see this above all in a dynamic perspective.  We don't know where all this is going to lead. There could be new lockdowns. The situation we are experiencing is certainly having consequences that we do not yet know or which we are not yet able to correctly assess. The dynamics of this crisis are therefore of great importance. We still need to continuously assess and adjust the exact impact in the longer term, or adjust and assess it. This also applies to the consequences of Brexit. In other words, it is now a matter of increasing the resistance, resilience, resistance of our society and our economy. In order to guide citizens and businesses through the turbulence we are experiencing, I would argue that, in the context of the multi-annual budget negotiations, the renewal of the economy, the innovative programmes, should be given absolute priority and to be prioritised.  As far as the negotiations on the multiannual budget are concerned, I think it is very clear that Parliament has clearly articulated its objectives and desiderata a long time ago, including recently. There has never been the slightest discussion about that. There is, moreover, great unanimity in Parliament on this. I therefore call on all those involved, including the Council and the Commission, to do everything possible to avoid an interinstitutional blockade. The chances of that happening are real, but we must avoid it at all costs.  I started my intervention by pointing out the importance of combating uncertainty. If we were to achieve this interinstitutional blockade, we would really be in a very difficult place to create a great deal of uncertainty and the European institutions – which may never be the intention – to contribute to a lack of momentum to achieve an economic and social recovery.

name: Manon AUBRY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, as we debate today, the European Council is secretly negotiating what you deceptively call the European recovery plan. But behind this bombastic name, how dare you talk about a recovery plan when the funds will have to, at least in part, be reimbursed rubies on the nail by the European peoples? Because you mustn't be fooled! Until there are sufficient own resources, the debate on the distribution between loans and subsidies is at least partly theoretical, because it is ultimately the European states that will have to repay, and therefore the European peoples who will have to pay the bill. How dare you talk about a stimulus package when it is really a meagre 0.5% boost to European GDP when it will fall by at least 8% in 2020 alone? How dare you talk about a stimulus package when only a quarter of the funds will be available by 2023? It is now, right now, that the Member States need money. But European aid will arrive after the battle. At the same time, the European budget will probably be reduced and that is the danger we are hearing. So, simple sleight of hand, give with one hand and take back with the other.  How dare you finally talk about a stimulus package without any democratic debate being held to define its direction? Who can guarantee here in this Chamber that Parliament will have a say in ensuring that the funds are not allocated without social and ecological consideration? No one. Who can guarantee that this plan will avoid the cascade of social plans that has already begun across Europe with thousands of layoffs in companies like: Nokia, Airbus, Renault or Sanofi, some of which for that matter, have taken advantage of the crisis to make profits, like Sanofi. No one. The only certainty we have at this stage is that the Commission will come out stronger to impose austerity on the Member States. I note, moreover, that Mrs von der Leyen is becoming increasingly clear, as President of the European Commission, about the return by the small door of the European Semester and therefore of budgetary control and austerity imposed on the Member States. This recovery plan, as you understand, is therefore very badly named. If there is a revival, it is your liberal ideology, not the economy. In the end, it looks more like a broad communication plan to swallow the pill of new liberal reforms. And yet another path was possible. First, by allowing Member States to respond quickly to the crisis through direct loans from the European Central Bank and partial cancellation of their debt. Then, by putting in place a vast ecological reconstruction plan, financed by a tax of multinationals, polluters and billionaires. This is what we need today: a plan and implementation, not a slogan, nor a communication operation or a staging - as is the case at the moment, with the famous Franco-German couple. So act, act before it's too late for people and the planet!

name: Márton GYÖNGYÖSI
text: – Mr President, we all feel a sense of urgency to adopt the MFF and the recovery package at next week’s Council. Many have stressed the importance of fairness, sustainability and solidarity. However in April, the idea of a Eurobond was killed at the Eurogroup, the only proposal so far that could have transferred debt from the level of the Member States to the European level automatically, and hence transfer the debt, and with it absorb the costs of the recession from the Member States to the European Union.  In the recovery plan as it is today, I can’t see the guarantees that the funds go to the most desperate European citizens, enterprises and SMEs, and I can’t see the guarantee that the funds will not lead to an increase in Member States’ debt that will eventually lead to austerity and an increase in social inequalities. I’m appalled by the idea that funds are distributed by governments that are in cahoots with either corporate businesses, on the one hand, or with a domestic oligarchy on the other. How can we expect that under such circumstances, funds will go where they are most needed? These guarantees should be included in this agreement before the Recovery Fund, and the MFF, are adopted.

name: Charles Michel
text: President of the European Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for the various interventions, for the messages that are addressed to me.  I recognise that, on the methodology, I do not fully understand what Mr Mure-an has said, because I have the impression that the cooperation between the European Council, the Commission and Parliament is unprecedented and we will continue to mobilise to ensure that, not only on the formal level, as is the case today, before a plenary assembly , we will continue to mobilize to ensure that there is permanently this close dialogue. And I am convinced, I repeat, that we will all have to demonstrate an ability to be creative, to innovate, to reach out to each other. It is not by repeating almost threateningly, hour after hour, day after day, that progress will be at the rendezvous, it is indeed by having the sleeves rolled up, with the intellectual will to conclude an agreement that we can actually reach an agreement that must meet in my eyes, I can not be clearer, a very specific objective : a robust Europe, a strong Europe. The facts have shown that, that is what we need. And those who make the illusion that it would be the national retreat, that it would be the scraping that would be the solution are wrong. We do need strong, robust Member States that are up to the challenge and we need a European Union that can carry this forward-looking ambition with a clear vision of the levers at our disposal.  And we have a clear vision of the levers we have, we know that the climate agenda, we know that the digital agenda must be priorities. Coincidentally, the fact that it is now that we will decide on the next European budget for the next seven years, must lead us to learn the lessons, in the budget, and to take into account the consequences of COVID in the next European budget, in parallel with the launch of a very exceptional fund which must be, I think, , a moment of transformation for the European project. Mrs Hayer, I think, is right: the issue of own resources is a very important issue which can be a turning point in the history of the European project. Perhaps that is why this debate is so difficult from a political point of view, because there are indeed different views on how to look at this debate on own resources. And, I note, in the different political families represented in the European Council, as is the case in this European Parliament, opinions do differ. I thank Mr Lamberts who, with goodness, with great realism and common sense, says that the majority is not like unanimity. In the democratic context, there are institutions for which the majority allows us to take the step forward and then then say that Parliament is united. I heard the first round of the table, I did not hear exactly the same messages expressed a few moments ago. But there is indeed a majority of Parliament which has a common position and that is very good, it is a very strong encouragement that I take into consideration. In the Council, we must work to try to achieve unanimity, this is not simple and to try to be ambitious it is essential for me, that is why I am fully mobilised. Finally, the rule of law and values. I believe, as many have said, many have expressed, that we must also consider that governance, the rule of law, fundamental values, is the backbone of this European project and, in this sense, we must take this political moment into account in order to move this ambition in the right direction as well. And then I conclude by saying that, from my point of view - this is also revealed by this crisis - prosperity, it is not just measured by an indicator that would be quantitative growth. For decades, we have considered progress to be measured by a parameter, with a criterion that is the percentage of GDP. Well, this element, it is interesting, it is not enough. This does not reflect the concrete impression that citizens, in a country or within the European Union, have a better life than it was the previous year or a few years ago.  It is in this, I think, that, in this transformation project, which I believe we must implement, perhaps we must also ask ourselves how. When one carries this conviction of economic reform, of social reform, how can one have this democratic debate which tends to set the objectives that one wants as a society on the European plan? The question of the quality of education, the question of the environment, the question of the reduction of inequalities, access to quality and indiscriminate health care are certainly parameters that we must take into account in order to measure the progress that is possible through this European project which must bring together and not divide.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: – Mr President, I will speak my mother's Bulgarian language. Thirty, actually sixty seconds is not enough for a real speech, but we Bulgarians like to say that we need more deeds and less talk. I wish good luck to the German Presidency and the Council. It comes at a difficult time for the European Union, in the middle of the COVID crisis, and it has an incurable destiny to address another issue that will not only not solve the COVID crisis, but can lead us to a new crisis. The priorities of the Presidency are two: saving people's lives and their health; protecting the economy and jobs. Economics and jobs.  I don't know about health, but it's as if the COVID crisis has affected the mind of the European Union. The Mobility Package is just that evidence.  To all the colleagues who will vote in favour of this package: colleagues, do you know what you will vote for? Have you read to the end what's left in there? You say you're protecting the rights of the drivers. Well, so am I - we're fighting for their fundamental right to have some work already, and a salary. Working conditions are not decided by meaningless legislation and rules. And the weather conditions are not improving with empty trucks, thousands of empty trucks touring Europe. It would be an embarrassment for Parliament to accept this package as such, given that the European Commission has given up on it too – it has said it will rethink it if the return of the truck and the driver remains. Finally, in order to distinguish good from bad, we must be able to distinguish them.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, next week's European Council will have a crucial task: to reach agreement on the budget and recovery fund and to achieve it immediately. Let me be clear: for Parliament, the proposal made by the Commission is the starting point, not the end of the proposal. If anyone in the Council thinks they can get the European Parliament to accept anything, they are wrong; Parliament is certainly prepared to reject any agreement that is pejorative to the proposals on the table today because, as MEPs, we know that we must show courage today. The thousands of citizens who have suffered from the pandemic in recent months are asking us to do so. Only by embarking on a new phase of European integration will we be able to emerge from the crisis stronger and more united. We need ambition, so we need new own resources, such as a tax on web giants and speculative financial transactions, to ask more of those who have so far contributed too little than our companies and our workers. The Council therefore has an enormous historical and political responsibility and must live up to it. The European Parliament has a clear position and knows which way to stand: on the side of the citizens. It is now up to the Council to demonstrate the same.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. After a few months of forced interruption, it comes to mind even more about how impotent the European Union is in many areas and how pointless it actually is in some areas.  If one looks at this work at European level at the heart of the crisis at home, one inevitably comes to the realization that, where national action is still possible, much more can take place in crisis management than is the case here. In general, we also come to the view that the European Union is often not the problem solver, but actually the fire accelerator, because the idea of internationalisation and globalisation is responsible for many problems.  To abuse the multiannual financial framework in such a way that the Corona crisis is now shoveling even more money and even more power and even more powers into Brussels is certainly the wrong way to go. As a representative of a net contributor country, Austria, I can only say: no more cents to Brussels, competences back to the nation states! That is the right way to go.

name: Rasmus ANDRESEN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It is time for the Heads of State and Government to leave their trenches. We Greens will judge the outcome of next week's summit by how future-proof it is.  We do not care how the EUR 1.8 trillion is spent. The entire EU budget must be compatible with the Paris agreement on climate change. Fossil energy must no longer be promoted. Heads of government who violate the rule of law and democracy must no longer receive EU funding. The money is better taken care of by local mayors and NGOs.  President Michel, Chancellor Merkel, do not make lazy compromises at the Council summit at the expense of the climate and our democracy! Do not cut the multiannual budget together to put a compromise on the table for the stingy four. Climate change, nature conservation, the Erasmus programmes, but also money for democracy are permanent tasks and must not be limited to three or four years in a fund. Be courageous and show responsibility!

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the decisive rigour for Europe must be rigorous: the next Council. We are living at a time when the economic crisis and social, employment and fiscal inequalities between states are wiping out the confidence of European citizens. Rigour achieves this with a solidarity recovery plan and an ambitious multiannual financial framework, along the lines of the proposal made by the European Parliament, putting the necessary money into the real economy, planning sustainable investments and perhaps laying the foundations for overcoming tax competition between Member States. Rigour, on the other hand, is wrong in complying with demands for a watered-down agreement from countries that have had enormous advantages and privileges from the Eu ropean Union and its single market. It kicks it to the stars by continuing to propose austerity instruments, such as the ESA, the damage of which in Greece has also been admitted by the IMF and former President Juncker. The designated rigorist is German: the President of the Commission, Mrs von der Leyen, is now joined by Chancellor Merkel. Pelé said penalty is a mean way to score. Maybe... It is certainly the wrong way to govern this Europe.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Madam President, Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has First sentence on the budget: it is not possible to reduce the budget, as is currently being discussed among the Member States in the Council. As Mr Mure'an has pointed out, this weakens the European Union in the long term, and it also weakens Parliament's rights of participation. We cannot accept that.  Secondly, on the reconstruction plan, I believe that we need an ambitious development plan for two reasons: millions of employees are unemployed, millions of workers are now on short-time work. I think that if we hesitate now, the first companies and companies will be bankrupt, and so will the jobs be gone before aid from Europe even starts. That cannot be the point, and that is why a quick agreement is what we need.  Thirdly, if we are now thrifty, it will end up costing us twice, perhaps even three times the price. We must now see to it that we invest in the right fields of the future, especially in the skills of our citizens, in the development of infrastructure and the like, and not just leave our children with debts – that is, to agree a repayment plan right now and to start repayment before the end of this financial period. For me, this is also a mandatory condition for agreeing.

name: Javier MORENO SÁNCHEZ
text: – Madam President, our European integration project is going through a decisive moment which needs a historic response.  The Presidency of the Union, together with the German Presidency and its Government, with a strong socialist imronta, must act at the next Summit courageously so that all Europeans and Europeans leave this crisis without leaving anyone behind, with an ambitious recovery plan coming into force as soon as possible.  The time has also come to introduce the Union's new own resources, which will return that money that will reach the citizens, businesses and regions that need it most.  And finally, the time has also come to adopt a courageous immigration pact, with legal immigration pathways and mechanisms, which are the best tool for combating illegal immigration.  Chancellor Merkel has already braved the reception of thousands of migrants in 2015. Now, with President Von der Leyen, two German women can make history by making the plan and pact a reality, following the European path of Willy Brandt and Helmut Kohl, among others.

name: Laura HUHTASAARI
text: – Madam President, last month, the Commission’s website read that the EU must not finance its own budget by borrowing. Now this finance debt limiting specification has been deleted. The rule of law is a joke in the EU because the EU does not follow it. An eternal question from whom the money is taken and to whom it is given.  Ms von der Leyen emphasises that Member States should not think of their own good, but the common good. What is the common good? In 2011, it was the French and German banks. Now we should support the Italian and French banks. By how much must all countries first become over-indebted before this madness ends?

name: David CORMAND
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, how can we fail to understand the historic moment we are going through? How can we fail to see that, in the face of the combination of ecological, social and democratic crises, our institutions must protect Europeans, their jobs and our economies, without turning away from the objective of safeguarding the climate? Europe and its long-awaited financial resources are stuck in the corridors of the European Council and haggling between Member States. The European Union is powerless to act because, for lack of its own resources, it remains a prisoner of national selfishness. To have its own resources is to have the capacity, not only financial but above all political, to act. It is therefore to preserve the very reasons for our existence as a political entity and as a historical actor. If we persevere in impotence, it will pave the way for our demise, much to the delight of all populists who are enemies of the European idea. Also to the delight of financial interests that speculate on our weakness and to the great misfortune of the peoples.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the coronavirus has called into question, perhaps even at risk, the survival of the European Union. The action of the European Central Bank is good, the action of the European Investment Bank is good, and the ESME's credit line is also good for protecting our health. I am convinced that Italy should use that 36-37 billion euros to improve health facilities, even in the face of a possible new second wave of coronavirus. But now we cannot back down, there can be no downside compromise at the European Council on 17 and 18 July. We absolutely must defend the European Commission's initial proposal. The countries of the North that think they can cut back on actions to support growth are wrong: we must continue to have investment, we must have loans to enable industry and small and medium-sized enterprises and agriculture to recover after this crisis. It would be a mistake not to do so, it would be dangerous for the survival of the European Union itself.

name: Margarida MARQUES
text: – Mr President, I have already said this and I repeat, this overall proposal from the Commission for a multiannual financial framework and recovery plan is a creative and innovative proposal and we must welcome the Commission for having found the necessary answers within the framework of the Treaties. It is the basis for the desired European response to the crisis, an immediate response, but also a recovery of economies. We also welcome the fact that the Commission triggered Article 324.  This is what the European Council understands. The pillar has been moving too slowly in this urgency. The European Parliament has largely majority positions. The risk at this European Council is that urgency will lead to overpragmatism, but one and the other cannot compromise the future.  The recovery plan is key for Europe to emerge from the crisis, the multiannual financial framework is key for future generations.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Madam President, Mr Efsovic, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work he has EUR 750 billion and the EU budget in addition is a gigantic political responsibility. Responsibility, above all, for making good use of this money. It only makes sense that if we now help in solidarity with the reconstruction of Corona, we will at the same time invest in the future of our young people and in the future of an ecological economy. Ladies and gentlemen! I am very sorry, I have little confidence in the European Semester here, and it is also significant that Mr Michel is no longer here to discuss this with us. This will certainly be – and hopefully – different in the financial negotiations.  This European Semester is almost at will stretchy: in the end, taxpayers will pay for governments that have slept through their reforms for many years. We therefore call for more commitment to innovation. We are calling for a financial quota for future issues, Erasmus, the energy transition, the circular economy and digitalisation. We call for powers of control and veto for the European Parliament. European added value and the European semester must not be a contradiction in the crisis. We will only be guaranteed this if the European Parliament has more involvement.

name: Paul TANG
text: Mr President, in times of corona restrictions and economic hardship, people want solutions and not a row between North and South.  The bacon buyers of the European Recovery Fund are the multinationals. They benefit from direct economic support and investment in our economy and the internal market. Yet they hardly contribute taxes. So let them contribute to our recovery, make them pay for a subscription to the single market, make them pay for pollution. But above all, do not foot the bill with the ordinary taxpayer, in the North or in the South.  And yes, there are conditions to the expenditure. Sure. For countries and for companies. European money must make us prosperous and sustainable and must never cause harm, never be accompanied by damage to people, the environment or the rule of law.  So, Prime Minister Rutte, stop arguing. No longer keep a high standard of control of the multinationals and choose the Dutch interest. Choose a recovery that is paid for by those who benefit from it and do not contribute now. Choose a sustainable and prosperous Europe and the Netherlands.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Madam President, Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Having a huge package of financial measures in front of us, I would also like to make it very clear that the European Semester is not suitable for this. With the rule of law, we are currently seeing member states partly deal with Commission recommendations.  We need concrete ways of identifying and also checking, as the European Parliament, the respective payment flows, the nature of the projects, those that receive the money – whether these are the specialist committees from a technical point of view or whether we in the Committee on Budgetary Control are financially so. We need to get out of a kind of stagecoach age in the area of the transmission of data that concerns the financial and budgetary spheres. We need a digital information system that transmits all the necessary data in real time and which, in particular, makes public or accessible to economic beneficiaries, so that we no longer have to wait months for information, as is the case to date, and start real research campaigns in order to obtain adequate information about projects and their financing.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for The meeting of Heads of State or Government is a litmus test for the five objectives, the commitments, the necessities that Mrs Merkel has formulated today. This Parliament supports the principles, the basic approach of the German Presidency. We cannot say that about all the comments made by other Heads of Government. I therefore call on them to follow the Merkel speech and the vision of Europe. We must not focus on our future and the five Merkel goals: values, cohesion, climate neutrality, digital, self-confident, innovative Europe in the world.  Those who do not realise that time is pressing are closing their eyes to the economic, social, environmental and democratic consequences of the current crises and global challenges. Those who do not realise that an extraordinary courageous act of solidarity is needed is unaware of their shared responsibility for the future of Europe and of the consequences for their own country. Finally, anyone who delays, dilutes or even blocks here is guilty of the next generation in Europe. Anyone who wants to make cheap domestic money here is burdening the political and social consequences of the whole of Europe, which everyone has to repay with large bills.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Madam President, I believe that the next European Council is also at a historic meeting and a historic council. The adoption or rejection of the economic package is not judged to support countries, their economies and citizens. The history of the European Union itself is judged, and if this European Union wants and can go forward and secure the future of Europe and of future generations, so for me it is inconceivable, and I will fully agree with colleagues' previous positions, that there should be any separation between North and South. If the South goes bankrupt, both the North and the European Union itself will automatically go bankrupt. Any division is against the European Union and what it does is pour water on the mill of populists and nationalists.  I fully agree with the President of the European Council that the European Union respects the rule of law, the principles and values that are fundamental, and not a single euro should be given to countries that violate them. First and for best, Turkey, which attacks Member States of the European Union but even insults our religious feelings, is in violation of these principles and values, wanting to turn an ecumenical symbol of Christianity and Culture, Hagia Sophia, into a mosque. These countries have no place in the European Union's coffers, so I propose that Turkey be excluded from the next multiannual financial framework. Thank you.

name: Benoît LUTGEN
text: Madam President, a recovery plan cannot be envisaged without the confidence and confidence of the Europeans. We see savings rates in a whole range of countries, which are extremely high. This confidence depends in particular on the newfound sovereignty of Europe, in areas as strategic as digital, food, defence, security or, of course, as we have seen, health and the health sector. Therefore, this recovery plan should be geared towards this sector to give Europe more strength. It will also have to be boosted by enhanced own resources, some of which could come from carbon taxation at our borders, for example, or the taxation of GAFA. This will give more strength and resources to Europe, to the European Union, to the Commission, to the Commission, more autonomy too, more sovereignty, I dare say. And this will avoid the blackmail of certain Member States who are playing with the future of all Europeans. This newfound autonomy, this sovereignty, it is also trustworthy for Europeans. It is through this that we will be able, I think, to breathe new life into the whole of the European Union.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: – Mr President, for the future of Europe, the European Council and the Member States need common solutions to three key issues.  The first is Europe's common response to the economic crisis, which will be on the table next week and on which policies are now needed. As such, there is strong support for the need for a common response, but we must also ensure that these investments are used in such a way that they strengthen European competitiveness and sustainable growth as effectively as possible. At the same time, it is also necessary to decide how to repay that loan against the EU budget. In addition, Member States must also find ways of ensuring that all Member States are committed to common democratic values and the rule of law. I also expect the German leadership to decide that, in future, EU funding will be tied to member states' compliance with common principles. This is essential for the future of Europe.  Moreover, the fact that we do not have a common line on immigration continues to be a matter for the Member States of the European Union. I also expect a common policy under German leadership over the next few months.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank very much all the honourable Members for taking the floor. I was quite extensive in my introductory remarks, so now I can be much briefer. I would just like to react to the four most frequent issues which have been highlighted by the honourable Members.  The first is the sense of urgency mentioned by Mr Mureşan, by Mr Lamberts and by Mr Andresen, who made reference to ‘Zeit, zeit, zeit’, and also to Mr Tajani, who highlighted how important it is to send a strong signal now. I think that this should be the absolute priority for our leaders. I think we cannot wait any longer. We need to get a deal at the next European Council because that would be the best signal, the best response we can provide, first to our citizens. It would be the best response to the crisis. It would help us to secure jobs, and I think it would be a very important sign to our global partners, financial markets and representatives of industry that Europe is back, that we are overcoming the crisis, we are introducing new policies and will be emerging from the crisis stronger than when we entered it. A second very important group of remarks referred to the social aspects, to the thrust of the policies to make sure that we would underpin the green and digital transformations together with resilience. There have been some question marks on how all this would be organised, so I just want to reassure all honourable Members that the recovery plans would be drafted by the Member States themselves. Of course we want to make sure that the issues, the accumulated problems which have been building up in all Member States year by year would be tackled. Gradually we would be removing them and by that we would really be achieving the resilience which should be stronger in our Member States and for the whole European Union.  The Commission will, of course, be in a close iteration process with our Member States and we are ready to inform the European Parliament, as we always do, under the consultations, under the structured dialogue, under the hearings, when it comes to the European Semester process. The European Parliament will have strong oversight over all expenditure as it does right now when we are reviewing expenditure on an annual basis. This was also, I would say, the thrust of the remarks by Ms Aubry, Mr Pieper, and also by Ms Hohlmeier, to make sure that this process is transparent and that the role of the European Parliament is properly maintained. As Ms Marques suggested, I think right now we have the first meeting of our leaders and Presidents under Article 324 and, as I said in my introductory remarks, we are ready to make a proposal for institutional declarations which would really put in a very clear framework how we see our close cooperation among the institutions on the important parts of implementation of Next Generation EU and the MFF in the future.  The last point, which was raised by Ms Virkkunen, who was our last speaker, but also by Mr Benifei, Ms Hayer and Mr Cormand, was on own resources. Indeed this is a very important question, because we have to propose new ways of how we are going to pay, with money which would be raised on financial markets, to finance our resilience and recovery instrument.  We are considering, as was highlighted, the emission trading system; also the carbon adjustment mechanism, but also an own resource based on operations of enterprises in the European Single Market and the Digital Tax. We continue to work on our plastics tax and on some other ideas which are coming along in this process of deliberations and discussions.  What we want to propose to you is that we are ready to work on the roadmap, on how we want to assess, when we want to propose, and how we want to debate these potential new resources because we know that it’s important for this Parliament. It’s also very important for the national parliaments, because as you know, if we want to increase the ceilings of our resources and financing, we need to get the support of all EU Member States’ national parliaments. So to conclude, I really would like to thank you for your support, for the sense of urgency, for your readiness to cooperate in the very dynamic way which would be needed for the next Semester. I’m very much looking forward to our debate. Once again, be assured that the role of the European Parliament will be properly maintained.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you very much Vice—President Šefčovič. The debate is closed.  Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – Deciding upon a future European budget is crucial for the future of Europe. We cannot postpone the discussions anymore and we need a decision that will generate a constructive budget that will match the tasks that are in front of us. The recent proposal of the European Commission adds some positive ideas regarding especially the Recovery Plan but we also need to look at the long term objectives. We need to focus more on innovation, education and the sustainable development of our societies while using the successful results of the cohesion and agricultural policies. The European leaders have to go beyond their party-political interests and really live up to the challenge. In a more national note, I believe Romania should keep its allocation of about 50 billion euros in the MFF and receive more grants in the 33 billion euros planned in the Next EU Generation programme in order to reduce the gaps with the rest of Europe and manage the impact of the COVID-19 crisis and of Brexit.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission Council statement on a comprehensive Union policy to prevent money laundering and terrorist financing – the Commission's Action Plan and other recent developments (2020/2686(RSP)). I would point out to colleagues that there are no spontaneous speeches and no blue cards in this debate.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. This is a first for me today, a very special moment. I have been a Member of my home Parliament for 22 years and I have now been Minister of State for Europe for seven years, but I have never been allowed to speak before the European Parliament. I am not doing this ad personam, I am doing it for the Council. I am very grateful for this opportunity and I look forward to the next few months. I am always at your disposal and I look forward above all to constructive and critical cooperation at this difficult time. The fight against money laundering and terrorist financing is one of the central issues of the German Presidency. As you know, it is also an issue to which the Council as a whole is very committed. Parliament, the Council and the European Commission have worked closely together in recent years to create an effective system for combating money laundering and terrorist financing. We have made considerable progress here, not least in the legislative field, and this is, of course, mainly due to your commitment, ladies and gentlemen. I would just remind you of the amendment of the anti-money laundering directive, the banking package, the regulation on the European Banking Authority and the new legislation in the field of criminal law and the use of financial data for law enforcement purposes. However, ladies and gentlemen, Mr President, this is really no reason to rest on any laurels, as we are still too often reminded that there are still alleged cases of money laundering involving European banks. This must be unacceptable to all of us! In the meantime, there has been a wide-ranging political debate in and between the institutions of the European Union on how to make our framework for combating money laundering and terrorist financing even more effective in the future: what needs to be done, where do we simply need to improve? Your resolutions, our conclusions and the Commission's communications are exemplary for these considerations, but of course we must not stop at the deliberations.  I would like to mention a few examples which also show how we have been engaged. In December 2018, the Council agreed on a concrete action plan to combat money laundering, the implementation of which we are continuing to monitor. In December 2019, the Council adopted strategic conclusions in which it invited the Commission, inter alia, to look at ways and means of achieving greater harmonisation in the area of combating money laundering. And the question must be examined of the advantages and disadvantages of a supervisory body located at European level. As the latest example of our commitment, I mention the Council's conclusions on improving financial investigations, which was approved on 17 June, a few weeks ago. Ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We agree that we need to make substantial progress. On 7 May, the Commission presented its current anti-money laundering package. On the one hand, it contains the Commission's action plan and, on the other hand, it provides in particular for very important legislative proposals to be presented in the first quarter of 2021. Our Presidency warmly welcomes this package of measures and we propose that this important issue be put back on the Council's agenda. In particular, we intend to give the Commission further guidance in the form of Council conclusions, on the basis of the Commission's action plan. We hope that these conclusions will help the Commission to draw up the legislative proposals that it intends to present next year, so that we have a system for combating money laundering and terrorist financing that has the greatest possible impact. There's really still air up there. Ladies and gentlemen, i have so far, in the preparations for this item on the agenda, given the impression that you, as a Member of Parliament, the European Parliament as a whole, the Commission and the Council alike, are aware of the urgency. What is more, I would like all of us to have the utmost political ambition so that we can tackle the major problem of money laundering in the European Union even more effectively than has been the case so far!

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Executive Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this opportunity to present the Commission’s approach to fighting money laundering and terrorist financing. We have made a clear commitment to deliver a comprehensive approach to fighting dirty money, to better protect our economy and financial system in the future. This is one of our top priorities and I know that they can count on your full support.  The Commission fully shares the European Parliament’s view that it is high time to create an effective enforcement policy in this field, where all the pieces fall together and where the roles of the private sector, and the competent authorities in the Member States and in the EU are clearly set out.  The Commission adopted an action plan on 7 May on a comprehensive policy to prevent money laundering and terrorist financing. This ambitious and multifaceted plan sets out measures that the Commission will undertake over the next 12 months to better enforce, supervise and coordinate the EU’s rules on combating money laundering and terrorist financing. Our aim is to shut down any remaining loopholes and remove any weak links in the existing EU rules. Any flow of money of dubious origin, any company created without a real business behind it, any offer from a suspicious investors to buy property – these all create opportunities for criminals and we must crack down on each and every one of them, wherever they are in Europe. Our first and most critical objective is to make sure that everyone in both the private and public sectors applies the relevant rules rigorously. The Commission is doing its bit. We have launched numerous infringement procedures to ensure full transposition and application of our two core directives, the Fourth Anti-Money Laundering Directive (AMLD 4) and AMLD 5. Since I took office in December, the Commission has referred three Member States to the Court of Justice for non—transposition of the Fourth Anti—money Laundering Directive. We have sent out three reasoned opinions for the incomplete transposition of the Fourth Directive, issued four letters of formal notice for non-conformity in the transposition of the Fourth Directive and 17 others for non—communication of measures under the Fifth Anti-money Laundering Directive. We have also closed nine cases for non—communication under the Fourth Anti-money Laundering Directive, recognising the important efforts undertaken in some Member States. AML rules must be effective. That is why Commission proposed in May to issue country—specific recommendations to 11 Member States in this area. The European Banking Authority now has additional powers and I expect it to use them in full. In terms of the next steps, I would like an EU AML supervisory body to conduct systematic on—site checks in Member States. We need to build up our preventive capacities. But we also need to go further and strengthen our rules and tackle remaining weaknesses.  Let me highlight some key issues. Cases of online money laundering are on the rise. Authorities in all Member States should have the powers to freeze suspicious transactions of this kind. However, we are also aware that the way rules are currently implemented is not optimal for legitimate businesses. Clearer and risk—based rules will avoid companies facing unexpected consequences due to divergences in the way rules are applied. Our rules should not make life harder for honest operators.  Honourable Members, the Commission fully concurs with you – national supervisors cannot supervise rules on their own. This has become abundantly clear from the string of scandals we have recently witnessed. Dirty money is highly mobile. If it is dealt with in one Member State, it moves to another one with weaker supervision and enforcement. Dirty money should have nowhere to hide. This is why we will have to establish EU—level supervision. An EU supervisory body would require direct supervisory powers over the riskiest financial institutions, with oversight for the non—financial sector. Different options for EU supervision are possible, as set out in our consultation. We may propose a new EU agency or add to the responsibilities of the European Banking Authority, depending on the feedback we get and on our own assessment. However, if the European Banking Authority is to become the EU supervisor, both its track record and governance will have to improve. Let’s be clear, an EU supervisor cannot effectively enforce AML rules in the EU unless additional flanking measures are in place, and they are critically needed in three directions. First, our work towards better preventing and fighting money laundering will be supported by the European Public Prosecutor’s Office, Europol and Eurojust, but also through better protection of whistle—blowers with a comprehensive new regime that Member States will need to transpose by the end of next year. Second, we will set up a mechanism to improve how suspicious flows of money are tackled and reported and better coordinate this analysis across Member States. We know that too much money laundering takes place across borders. Third, AML does not stop at the EU borders, so strong rules and enforcement in third countries is also essential. Not all countries, however, have strong regimes in place.  The new methodology issued alongside the action plan provides the EU with the necessary tools to take action. In this respect, I commend the positions taken by both the European Parliament and the Council with respect to the delegated act on the list of high—risk third countries, which recently entered into force.  To conclude, to effectively fight money laundering, we need to act in multiple directions. Let me assure you that the Commission is fully ready to play its part to ensure that our internal market and financial system are protected from criminals. The Commission thanks the European Parliament for steering as this debate towards a successful conclusion.

name: Eero HEINÄLUOMA
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the Socialist Group is very pleased that the German Presidency has taken anti-money laundering measures seriously in its programme. We are also pleased that the Commission is acting on its promises and has prepared comprehensive proposals on what needs to be done.  Big assets in money laundering. Europol estimates that 1% of the national product is in this illegal movement, and only 1% of this money will be recovered for society. It is therefore worth doing something fundamentally differently.  Our group is in favour of the time for directives being clearly over. Binding EU legislation is needed. In addition, our group is also in favour of a European supervisor. There must be a European institution that can ensure that the problems of money laundering in all Member States are addressed. In addition to this, we are also prepared to go a little further. We would have liked to have seen sanctions, proper sanctions for mistakes, and we would also have liked to have seen greater account of the auditors.

name: Luis GARICANO
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, Mr Vice-President, thank you for your good purposes. Criminals earn EUR 160 billion per year, 1% of the Union's gross domestic product, and each year taxpayers lose 825 billion in uns paid taxes and another 50 billion in VAT fraud. This money laundering, unfortunately, is largely unpunished. According to Europol, 99% of the profits of criminals are not confiscated and are available to them. We must remedy this problem if we are to build a fairer society. Recent scandals, such as luanda Leaks or the murder death of Daphne Caruana Galizia, show that Member States are not doing enough and that Europe is not leading in this area either. That is why we believe that the European Commission should take a more ambitious approach and Parliament adopts this resolution, with a large majority, with five demands which I would like to stress. First, the creation of an anti-money laundering supervisor with sufficient resources. Second, the creation of a European financial information unit to eradicate the most sophisticated forms of evasion. Third, use the European Public Prosecutor's Office to combat bleaching. Empower the European Central Bank to withdraw bank licences in cases of laundering. And, fifth, make it easier for the property records of opaque societies to be public and know them. Mr Vice-President, the Commission must take the necessary measures on the path laid down by this Parliament. Criminals have benefited from the lack of solutions for too long. Mr. Dombrovskis, it's time to act.

name: Gunnar BECK
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, I would like to thank the In the fight against money laundering, you are calling for transnational cooperation and sanctions. The right way, for sure – wouldn't everyone be blind to a particular money laundering industry: NGOs.  Eurojust, Europol, the European Court of Auditors, Moneyval and national bodies have for years criticised NGOs as stealth caps for money laundering. But the EU puts NGOs above the law. With laundered money and commercial expertise, such shady entities as the Open Society Foundation have an influence on public opinion with more than 20 billion euros. Hungary has tried to force such opinion-makers to be transparent and has been condemned by the ECJ.  Ladies and gentlemen, when you talk about money laundering and tax avoidance, please do not forget your good old and generous friend Soros!

name: Saskia BRICMONT
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the European Commission for this ambitious action plan on combating money laundering and terrorist financing, which incorporates many of the recommendations of the Green Group. So the problem is not so much the absence of European rules as their effective application by our Member States. And so it is indeed time that the directives are partly transformed into regulations, that the whole European legislative arsenal is transposed into our Member States and that the European Commission conducts infringement procedures against states that do not respect the rules, because the fight against money laundering is a priority for citizens. We know that the crisis has provided new opportunities for criminals and financial criminals, taking advantage of the vulnerability and fears of the citizen, and that 98.9% of criminal activity, criminal money, is not recovered today. And so the priority is also the transposition of the directive on the freezing and recovery of assets so that this money is returned first and foremost to the victims of crimes and also used for investments in our public services.

name: Nicola PROCACCINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, money laundering and the financing of terrorist organisations are the two sides of a powerful and dangerous enemy. That is why there must be no grey areas in the European Union's commitment and, personally, I will identify at least two of them to which I would like to draw attention: firstly, I am concerned that a certain political party wants to shield NGOs a priori only for ideological reasons or because their name is 'non-profit-making'. I believe that we need maximum transparency, both in the reports that NGOs have in the exercise of their activities and in their sources of funding. That would be a guarantee of legality for everyone. Then there are some Member States that unfairly conduct aggressive tax policies, have very permissive legislation on the use of public money and, in addition, guarantee virtually impenetrable protection of bank data by the international police force. I believe that all this is unacceptable and must be corrected promptly.

name: José GUSMÃO
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, we are asking for this debate not only in the wake of the Luanda Leaks scandal, not only because of the importance of the facts that have gone public, but because, in my country, the man who denounced the Luanda Leaks scandal has been imprisoned for almost a year, no fault of his own, in effective arrest, and only because of enormous citizen pressure has been transferred to house arrest and has not yet been tried.  And also in my country, we have a tax haven, the offshore of Madeira, which is a customary stop of international money laundering circuits, and that is why it is so difficult for us to understand why, here in Parliament, so often by political or national sympathies, it hesitates to point out within the European Union the jurisdictions that, by action or omission, benefit money laundering.  If we ask, and we do well to ask the European Commission for courage to deal with the phenomenon of money laundering, that courage has to start in this Parliament, i.e. we have to understand that, yes, there are high-risk third countries, but not all high-risk countries are third parties. Many of them are within the European Union and cooperation is needed and national legislation must be analysed. There are several aspects to this resolution that are very important at this level: the end of Gold visas, the protection of whistleblowers (and the case of Luanda Leaks is an excellent example to discuss this matter). The identification of the last beneficiaries and the return of assets that are illegally withdrawn from their rightful owners - these are very important points of this resolution.

name: Mislav KOLAKUŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, we have recently witnessed the emergence of a new and most dangerous category, which is the category of viral-pandemic profiteers. We are witnessing that individuals, in the day, become richer by several billion euros. Twenty-six individuals in this world have the same assets as 3.5 billion other inhabitants. Viral-pandemic profiteering uses countless paid articles and ads that provoke and spread the fear campaign. In this fear, and the closure of states, profits those who have enormous wealth and can buy large companies, airlines at a tenth of the price. We have to pay attention to that now. We need to see who funds certain content in the media.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the German Presidency of the Council, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work on the I see with some concern that for years the European Commission has had a certain – shall we say – kindness towards the Member States, which have become accustomed to not implementing money laundering directives. There have been no infringement proceedings at all in the Money Laundering Directive 3. In the case of the Money Laundering Directive, number 4, a very significant number of Member States have fallen short of what was required by the Money Laundering Directive in terms of standards. In point 5, four do not report any transposition at all, and a significant proportion of others do not report any transposition, and less than half of the Member States have reported transposition. We must, for one thing, be very strict in ensuring that the necessary transparency, the necessary publicity prevails, or that the transmission to public authorities and those who are economically justified is carried out, that we can only uncover networks if we really achieve the full implementation of the measures that we have set out to take. Mr Commissioner, I would like to ask you most sincerely that we should carry out the most rigorous follow-up and that we no longer have to deal with Member States that do not comply with it.

name: Paul TANG
text: – Mr President, EUR 1.4 trillion. That’s one of the latest estimates of money laundering. It’s mind—boggling, it’s staggering and it’s a bloody shame. This is money stolen, illegally gained, and it’s taken from governments and people that need it the most. It is money that can be laundered and can be spent, thanks to our financial secrecy and thanks to opaque firms and funds, of which the owners are unknown.  We need to shine a light on them and to bring them to justice. We need registries of ultimate beneficial ownership. It’s a shame that not all Member States have implemented the last directive and that one Member State has failed to create a registry. The result is that the ultimate source of EUR 96 billion of Russian investments in the Netherlands is still unknown.  So we need implementation of the current legislation, but we also need people to execute and supervise this. We need further harmonisation. I would like to encourage the Commission and the Member States to continue to fight for justice. This is what we need.

name: Ramona STRUGARIU
text: – Mr President, according to the United Nations, the amount of money laundered globally in one year is between two and five percent of global GDP,  meaning anywhere between USD 800 billion and USD 2 trillion. These are stunning numbers. Fighting money laundering and fiscal paradises not only protects our economy, but saves lives and has a huge impact on large communities and whole countries deeply affected by organised crime.  We have called on the Commission numerous times to establish an EU supervisory body and an EU financial intelligence unit. We stressed the need for interconnected and high—quality registers of beneficial owners in the Union and I would like to salute and welcome the Commission’s action plan. We know, however, that Member States have mostly failed to properly transpose AMLD 4 and 5. It is high time therefore for a regulation and for coordinated action. We need to translate our priorities into legislation and actively monitor implementation and results.  One last essential thing that could have been better reflected in our resolution and more courageously reflected in the text is that we also need to look at our own backyard and look at our own avoidance, low taxation and secrecy jurisdiction issues. The Tax Justice Network has just released a report showing that EU Member States are losing around EUR 27 billion in tax revenues to what it describes as an axis of avoidance due to profit shifting. So let’s start properly fighting money laundering in the Union here and now.

name: Herve JUVIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are of course all in favour of the fight against money laundering and the financing of terrorism.  What have we done when we do not challenge the system of trustees and nominees, which allows for considerable financial transactions without the identification of the final recipient? What have we done until we quickly come up with the regulation of electronic currencies which allow both unidentified transfers and, I would also say, absolutely considerable unjust enrichment phenomena.  On the financing of terrorism, I would gladly repeat the recent comments of the Nigerian Defence Minister, Mr Issoufou Katambé, at the Dakar Peace Summit, who said: "No illusions, we know the states that finance terrorism". Some of these states are good customers of European Union countries, some of these states are nato allies or even partners.  It has probably even happened to countries of the European Union, here or there, I am thinking personally of the Balkans or Syria, to have equipped, trained, armed groups that have turned out to be terrorist groups. Let us not be under any illusions, financial control is important, it is police and military control that will make the difference on the ground.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, Minister of State Roth, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his work and for the work he has said. The European Commission has put forward strong proposals, and the Council of Member States has also made considerable moves in the fight against money laundering.  These proposals also have The Support of Parliament: common supervision, common stronger rules, but also an effective European financial police force that can investigate across borders.  However, we should not turn a blind eye to the fact that the infringement procedures, compared with the implementation of the recent reforms of the Money Laundering Directive, must not obscure the fact that old law, which is thirteen years old – the Money Laundering Directive 3 – is being broken in many Member States, including Germany, and there are no infringement proceedings against it. I therefore appeal to the European Commission and the Member States: finally implement the existing law, initiate infringement proceedings not only if the letter of the law is not fulfilled, but when money laundering is actually prevalent in the real world. The Commission has not yet fully complied with its obligations. More speed, more pressure, Commissioner!

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the fight against money laundering and terrorist financing must become a strategic challenge for the European Union and must be combated by other criminal activities, such as corruption, arms, drugs and human trafficking, as well as tax evasion and fraud. Where rules and supervision are less stringent, individuals and criminal groups are being able to pollute the economic and financial system, which has already been put to the test by the effects of the pandemic, with illicit proceeds. We cannot allow divergent interpretations or deficient and uneven applications of European law in this area to occur in some Member States. The presence of European tax havens that attract companies and capital, undermining the fairness of the internal market and distorting competition, cannot be tolerated. The implementation of a prevention policy must be full, identifying high-risk jurisdictions, harmonising different legal systems and enhancing information sharing tools on beneficial ownership of companies and financial transactions, in order to attack the proceeds of crime and the assets of organised crime.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. The cases of money laundering in the European financial system in recent years show that we are still making it far too easy for money launderers.  I would like to mention two very specific problems: firstly, the lack of implementation has already been mentioned. Last week, Commissioner, you opened infringement proceedings against three Member States in the implementation of the fourth directive – I do not want to talk about the state of implementation of the fifth.  Secondly, it is a directive. In other words, despite complete implementation, we have a patchwork, because it is being made different again in each Member State, and new loopholes are being created.  The second problem, which I would also like to raise quite openly here, is, of course, that communication between authorities at the back and front does not work. We are also seeing in Germany that supervisory and investigative authorities have difficulties – And I say it in a very abstract way – of working together in concrete terms. Recent cases prove this.  Things have been identified, and we are really waiting for proposals from the Commission: a central authority with investigative powers and regulations instead of directives. Otherwise, we will have to have the same debate year after year.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: – Mr President, this debate on the fight against money laundering certainly reminds — and much - of the debates on the fight against tax havens, evasion, tax avoidance... areas where there is a very broad agreement in Parliament, in the Commission, in the Council. An agreement strongly supported by the citizens of the whole of Europe that he believes is not acceptable for us to continue these loopholes in our tax systems.  But at the same time as there is such a broad consensus, we are not able to put in place new initiatives, to comply with the directives we have adopted or to have efficient coordination between States, and we contribute to the frustration of European citizenship.  I therefore believe that it is time not only to analyse how directives are transposed or not, but to use Community legislation, regulations in this area, to avoid any kind of indiscretion, a regulation which has a common European supervisor which also imposes clearly indiscentive sanctions on such behaviour.

name: Roman HAIDER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The fight against money laundering and terrorist financing is, after all, a concern that, apart from all ideological orientations, is supported with equal commitment by all political actors in the EU – that is what one should at least think.  However, if you look at the Commission's action plan to combat money laundering and terrorist financing, and if you know that the European Court of Justice declares transparency requirements by Member States against such non-governmental organisations illegal, then, unfortunately, we are being taught something better. This preference for non-governmental organisations, which are really well-connected in Brussels, is really striking.  The reason for this preferential treatment is that one does not want to give the impression that these organisations are engaged in illegal activities – even though all the bodies involved in the issue are really pointing out that these organisations are at risk in the fight against money laundering, even though ISIS and other terrorist organisations have used such organisations to raise money. The Commission and, unfortunately, the European Court of Justice are putting the safety of citizens at risk.

name: Lídia PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, tackling financial crime must be a priority. EUR 160 billion associated with suspicious financial activities requires decisions and Europol's recognition that 99% of the profits from crimes remain in the hands of criminals reveals the urgency of action. Money laundering is a complex crime and is at the epicentre of many other criminal phenomena: corruption, trafficking in human beings, drugs and weapons, terrorist financing or tax fraud and evasion. That is why our debate goes beyond financial crime. It is a real issue of human rights, democracy and the rule of law. Europe needs more cooperation, more harmonisation of more effective rules and structures. A fragmented Europe, with different country-to-country rules, is a window of opportunity for criminals. Only with a truly European strategy can we close this window and only with more Europe will we be able to have less crime.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – (start of off-microphone intervention) ... 1% of the Union's gross domestic product in financial activities suspected of money laundering from corruption and organised crime, including terrorism. I therefore fully support the Commission's action plan, the first objective of which is the implementation of the fifth Directive, which is in force and needs to be implemented not only, transposed, but implemented by the Member States. The second objective is supervision, with a single supervisor communicating all financial reporting units. The third objective is harmonisation and therefore moving from the Directive to the Regulation, which ensures uniform compliance with European law by the Member States. The fourth is international cooperation, which has to be reinforced in a problem as serious as this. The fifth, training and, of course, ensuring the identification of beneficiaries of money laundered from corruption and organised crime.  Only in this way will we really be able to account for the meaning of this Resolution, which is to support the Commission's demand that the Member States implement the fifth Directive as soon as possible.

name: Enikő GYŐRI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European  There is no question, honourable Members, that money laundering and terrorist financing must be combated in every way possible. We cannot allow commercial crime, even across borders, to continue freely. The question is how best to achieve this goal. In recent years, we have introduced EU rules. Some of them have only just come into force, so we do not yet have practical experience of how it works. Serious financial scandals have occurred before, not under the legal framework that now applies. I also have doubts about the transfer of supervisory functions to new institutions at EU level. Such a move runs counter to the principle of subsidiarity, as it reduces national competences in areas where strengthening national authorities and better cooperation between Member States could provide an adequate response to challenges. Parliament likes to move forward, but perhaps with a little thought we can do more in practice in this fight. Despite my reservations, I believe that further development of the anti-money laundering and terrorist financing system is definitely an objective to be supported. That is why I will support it with my vote, with my fellow Members, with my fellow Members of the Hungarian People's Party.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Executive Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of the European Commission, I would like to thank the European Parliament for taking time to debate this important matter and for your commitment to further strengthening our defensive tools against money laundering and terrorist financing. We need to act upon all findings and be ambitious in our efforts to make the European Union more effective in preventing damage to the integrity and reputation of the Union’s financial system.  Many points were raised in this debate on effective implementation of current rules. Indeed, it’s one of the work directions, so more effective implementation, strengthening preventive capacity on transposition of anti—money laundering directives.
