The Commission has made very clear, including to Member States, that we are going to be very assertive about proper and timely transposition of these directives and also, on the way forward, that we need to move away from directives to regulations, at least in a substantial part of the legislation, which will allow for more effective direct enforcement at EU level, and we need EU—level supervisors. My thanks to all the colleagues who were supporting those points.  There is the question which was raised by several colleagues on taxation and, indeed, the fight against tax evasion and tax avoidance often goes hand in hand with the fight against money laundering. Next week, the European Commission will come with a new set of measures to strengthen our framework dealing with tax evasion and tax avoidance, so the tax package will be presented by the Commission next week. We are also looking at the scope of operators subject to anti-money laundering rules and there, at the very minimum, we need to include virtual asset service providers, just to give you some examples. In any case, the European Commission remains committed to the fight against money laundering. We see it as a priority and we thank the European Parliament for the strong support you are providing.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I am pleased to take the following from our debate: money laundering and terrorism must be better combated. We all agree on this in principle – with a few exceptions, and I will come to that in a matter of time. We need more transparency, we need more regulation and we need more control. I think it is worth it that we really look seriously at every proposal that is on the table in order to get better and simple. I am also very grateful to the honourable Members who have once again referred to the financial dimensions of money laundering: a 1% of gross domestic product, possible tax losses of 8%. It is clear here that this is by no means a question of cavalier offences. However, I would like to make one more point. I am here for the first time, I do not yet know whether this is customary here, but I must once again break a lance for a committed, even critical civil society, which is part of a living democracy.  Now not all of us may like what non-governmental organisations say. But that, too, is what distinguishes a vibrant democracy. I object to the fact that this gives the impression that even critical non-governmental organisations, which some honourable Members do not like, have anything to do with high-crime activities such as money laundering or the fight against terrorism. This is about murder! This is about manslaughter! This is about drug offences! They have nothing, but nothing at all, to do with the critical commitment of non-governmental organisations in the European Union.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The debate is closed. In accordance with Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure, two motions for resolutions have been tabled. The vote on the amendments will take place tomorrow, Thursday, 9 July 2020, and the final vote will take place on Friday, 10 July 2020. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Carmen AVRAM
text: in writing. – I support this resolution. According to the Commission around 1%, or EUR 160 billion, of the European Union’s annual GDP is connected with suspect financial activity such as money laundering linked to corruption, among other things. That is a lot of money that could be used in a better way and help our societies recover from this crisis. We are aware of the problems identified in combating money laundering: fragmentation of rules, uneven supervision and limitations in the cooperation among financial intelligence units across the EU Member States. Better cooperation is needed. We know what we have to do to improve the situation. The resolution welcomes the EC action plan launched in May. We should increase pressure to implement all six pillars of the EU action plan for a comprehensive Union policy on preventing money laundering and terrorism financing. The EC committed to deliver all of the six actions by early 2021. Let me finish and add that as a former career journalist, I very much welcome the paragraph of the resolution calling on Member States to fully investigate in a transparent manner cases of money laid and related crime against whistle—blowers and journalists. In particular, the resolution refers to the Maltese journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia and the Panama Papers revelations.

name: Erik BERGKVIST
text: Written. In recent years, we have witnessed a money laundering epidemic in Europe. The largest known heartset to come is Danske Bank's money laundering in Estonia of a staggering SEK 2,000 billion. No less than three Dutch banks are accused of Russian money laundering. Germany's national heirloom, Deutsche Bank, is accused of laundering more than SEK 8 billion, to be added to previous allegations of involvement in tax evasion in the so-called Panama leak. The equivalent of SEK 40 billion has been channelled by 50 customers in Swedish Swedbank in the Baltic states. All 50 customers show clear signals of suspected money laundering. To this should be added that the equivalent of SEK 150 million stolen in the so-called Magnitsky affair was sent to accounts in Swedbank. The Russian tax fraud was uncovered by accountant Sergei Magnitsky and led to his death. The money laundering scandals of recent years clearly show that Member States have not set aside sufficient resources to implement EU anti-money laundering and terrorist financing legislation. That is why a new EU authority against money laundering and terrorist financing is needed. Such an authority would need legal powers to carry out activity visits in the Member States to ensure that EU legislation is implemented and enforced. National financial intelligence authorities must step up the exchange of information, while at the same time strengthening Europol's capacity so that cross-border investigations can be requested.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. Despite the adoption of the fourth and fifth anti-money laundering directives and the directive on combating money laundering through criminal law, the EU legislative, institutional and regulatory landscape on anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing remains fragmented, thus encouraging companies to register where standards are less stringent and generating disparities in interpretations and practices in the Member States. The Commission's communication on an action plan for an integrated Union policy in this area, which must be followed up as a matter of urgency, must therefore be welcomed, given also the danger, reported by Europol, of organised criminal groups exploiting the current situation of economic uncertainty to launder money through the on-shore financial system. A single body of legislation must therefore be established, including by transponing the provisions of the anti-money laundering directive into a regulation; create an AML/CFT supervisory authority at EU level and a European support and coordination mechanism for FIUs; ensure effective cooperation and exchange of information between them and law enforcement authorities. Regulatory uniformity and investigative, judicial and operational coordination are in fact indispensable to guarantee security and deprive crime, in particular organized crime, of one of the main instruments of roots in the territory and infiltration into the legal economy.

name: Julie LECHANTEUX
text: In writing. Since 2018, Pakistan has been registered by the Financial Action Task Force (FATF), an intergovernmental body established in 1989 to develop standards and promote effective enforcement of legislative, regulatory and operational measures to combat money laundering and the financing of international terrorism.  Among the countries under surveillance, therefore, is Pakistan, which for years has received a considerable contribution from the European Union in terms of development aid. Indeed, the country would not have taken the necessary measures to remedy the shortcomings of its institutions in the prevention and fight against Islamist terrorism and its sources of funding. For this reason, on June 30, the FATF renewed Pakistan's inclusion in the list of countries under increased surveillance.  In this context, one will not be surprised by the statements of Pakistani Prime Minister Iran Khan who, in parliament, called bin Laden, the historic leader of al-Qaeda, a martyr. On the other hand, we will be more struck by the staggering lack of common sense and foresight of the European institutions and by their ideological blindness to the Islamist threat!

name: Andżelika Anna MOŻDŻANOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. " International terrorism is one of the most serious threats of today. It is financed by money from illegal sources , mainly economic crimes. Tax fraud is a huge global problem. It's an open door to terrorist financing! The fight against VAT carousels is our duty and responsibility! The European Union loses around €825 billion in untouched taxes every year, of which around 180 million go to criminals!  That is why in Poland we fight vat mafias so hard and with good results. We have already recovered 52 billion zlotys. Mf data shows that Poland is a country where the threat of terrorism is at one of the lowest levels in Europe.  An effective fight against money laundering and terrorist financing must be based on solid cooperation both between EU countries and globally. At the initiative of Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki, a meeting of representatives of 21 EU countries was organised for deeper cooperation in the fight against tax fraud. Poland proposes to Europe closer cooperation and experience in combating the VAT mafia.  Money laundering is a risk to the EU financial system. We support the EC's proposal to eliminate systemic weaknesses and seal the legal framework. However, the establishment of a new body at EU level, which, in addition to coordination, would oversee the state counterparts, requires a deeper analysis.

name: Emil RADEV
text: in writing. – I thank the European Commission for its action plan on a comprehensive Union policy to prevent money laundering and terrorist financing. We need such a comprehensive policy, a strengthened legislative framework in the area of money laundering and terrorist financing, to protect the European Union's financial system. It is very important that this framework is applied uniformly in all Member States. That is why controls on the implementation of the money laundering directives need to be strengthened. I hope that soon the European Commission will turn some of them into a regulation, only to unify the rules for all and close the loopholes in our legislation that criminals use to abuse our financial system. We demand an enhanced role for our common police unit Europol and its newly established European Centre for Financial and Economic Crime. At the same time, it is important that the newly established European Public Prosecutor's Office starts working as soon as possible and we encourage all EU Member States to join it. Effectively countering money laundering and terrorist financing will increase the security and confidence of our citizens in the financial system.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the EU's post-COVID-19 post-COVID-19 pandemic (2020/2691(RSP)). I would like to point out once again that there are no blue cards and no spontaneous speeches in this debate.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We are all dealing with an exceptional health situation which has a massive impact on our societies and our people. At this moment, we are certainly thinking of the more than 100 000 Europeans who have lost their lives so far because they have been infected with COVID-19.  In these weeks, we are discussing very intensively what we can learn from this serious crisis for our health care and for coordination within the European Union in the context of an effective and as preventive fight against pandemics as possible. We are also, of course, talking about the massive social and economic consequences. Last but not least, the Federal Chancellor has once again made it clear that this is one of the major priorities of the German EU Presidency, and I am sure that all of us, including here in the European Parliament, share this commitment to make every effort to ensure that we come out of this serious crisis as quickly and as united as possible and as united as possible. However, I would like to take this opportunity to express my sincere thanks to the nursing and health care workers who have done immeasurable work in these difficult and dramatic times to protect human lives and provide the best possible care for patients. In order to shape the European Union's future public health strategy, we need to be honest. We must talk openly about what has been achieved, but we must also talk openly about what has failed and, above all, what was our weakness at the beginning of the fight against the pandemic. Only then will we be able to respond better, faster and more comprehensively to another crisis in the future, and we all know that this crisis is far from over. We are still dealing with a very volatile situation. In some countries, the committed approach has been able to contain the crisis, the pandemic. But also in Europe, and also in our immediate neighbourhood, we see that nothing is certain.  We must therefore be vigilant, and this, of course, in liberal democracies such as ours, always involves an imposition on the population. This too has been the subject of intense debate here in the European Parliament, but also in the Member States: how can we protect the health of citizens without disproportionately restricting citizens' freedoms and constitutional rights? That is why our Presidency aims to adopt conclusions on the lessons of the COVID-19 crisis in order to gain useful insights for future action. I would like to thank you for the great interest and commitment you all devote to this issue.  Globally, and not only in Europe, the pandemic continues to spread faster. We have around 200 000 new cases every day worldwide, and we all know – and this is obvious – that a global crisis of this magnitude naturally also requires global responses. No country, however good health care, is in a position to fight this pandemic on its own. This also makes it clear that a policy of national isolation, a policy of small-stateism, a policy that weakens Europe and the European Union, always goes along with unacceptable risks to the health of our citizens. It is a very painful experience, admittedly, ladies and gentlemen, but perhaps it also encourages us to work together even better in a spirit of solidarity and shared responsibility than we have done so far in order to overcome the pandemic. This means a lot of work that lies ahead, because we will not be able to deal with the economic crisis successfully until we have also combated the virus in the long term. A comprehensive and successful strategy to overcome the pandemic for Europe and, of course, for the whole world requires the development of safe and effective vaccines and therapies, as well as equal access to them. The pandemic can only be defeated once and for all if it is wiped out everywhere. A lasting solution can only lie in science and solidarity.  The European Union is committed to making newly developed vaccines against COVID-19 a common, public, global asset that is available to all who need it. What we need is a vaccine for Europe as well as for the rest of the world. There can be no cannibalisation of "everyone against everyone", but we must all stand together here. Here, too, we are all to protect people's health, wherever they live, in Europe or in the world.  I am very pleased that the European Union, together with its international partners, has pooled its forces within the framework of the global crisis response initiative. A record amount of EUR 16 billion – as of 30 June – has now been raised to accelerate the development, production and delivery of vaccines against COVID-19. We must act decisively so that we can take the next steps. So we need safe and effective vaccines, we need to encourage their mass production, so that all people really have equal access.  In this context, I would like to thank the European Commission for its recent legislative proposal to enable the rapid conduct of clinical trials on COVID-19 vaccines and therapies, and I also thank the European Parliament for the decision to adopt a position on this dossier today. I am pleased to inform you that the Council approved this dossier last Friday.  As regards the elements of the European Union's future public health strategy, the Commission has recently proposed an ambitious EU for Health programme as part of the Multiannual Financial Framework and the Building Package. It reiterates that health in the European Union must be given a higher priority and that we need to be better prepared for health crises. One thing has been shown in the crisis: high-quality health care is still a great protection for our people from such a pandemic. That is why we give this dossier a very high priority in the Council, and we hope that, with your support, we will be able to adopt this dossier at the end of the year. We look forward to working very closely and with confidence with you on this important proposal.  However, it is also crucial that we improve the availability of medicines, medical equipment and other crisis-related goods in the Union. You know how this started at the beginning of the crisis. That was not ideal, but I think that we, as the European Union, and the Member States have also drawn the right conclusions. The COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated the problems arising from the European Union's dependence on third countries for the production of pharmaceutical active ingredients, raw materials, pharmaceuticals and medical equipment. Now we do not want to take globalisation off the hook – by no means! However, it must be ensured that, for key goods that guarantee the protection of the citizens of the European Union, we can ensure, on our own European strength, that these funds are also produced in the European Union – that is, European sovereignty. We must, of course, also be better able to deal with these crises, gather information, evaluate assessments and then act quickly in the event of a crisis. Close cooperation is essential for this, between the Member States and the institutions, bodies and agencies of the European Union, such as the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control or the European Medicines Agency, as well as with international organisations such as the World Health Organisation. One of our objectives is to strengthen and develop the functioning of these European institutions and agencies.  The EU for Health programme should focus on the lessons of the pandemic, while supporting longer-term projects. It should focus on the availability of medicines, vaccines and medical devices, reducing the number of antimicrobial-resistant infections and the EU's role in global health policy. In addition, the programme will also serve to implement the EU's medicines strategy and the European plan to combat cancer, which the Commission intends to adopt at the end of the year.  The Corona crisis has once again painfully demonstrated to us the need to expand our digital capabilities in healthcare. We need to overcome the fragmentation of health data and improve EU-wide implementation within the health system. In their recent conclusions on the shaping of Europe's digital future, the members of the Council have called for the creation of a European area for health data. I would also remind you of the controversial debate about an EU-wide app that can be used everywhere to protect people even better, and there is also a Need for improvement, you all know that at least as well as I do.  Equally important is the reference to the fact that investments in health are also made possible through other instruments of the Multiannual Financial Framework. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. One thing is clear: health will be a central area of activity at European Union level in the future, and this is not at all painful for the Member States, because the pandemic has shown that we need more Europe here too, a Europe that is more capable of action, because it will benefit the interests of the citizens. And the COVID-19 pandemic has also given us the opportunity to reflect on what measures we need to take to overcome the current pandemic and prevent future health risks. Together we can make the European Union and the world a healthier and safer place. Many eyes are on us, and we should show that liberal, democratically constituted societies are able to deal well with such serious crises, which lead to existential hardships for many people, and that our primary objective is to protect the people of the European Union, but also to provide solidarity at global level.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: We will now continue with the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the EU’s public health strategy post—COVID—19 (2020/2691(RSP)).

name: Stella Kyriakides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this debate comes at a key moment for our management of what is the most severe health crisis of modern times. Today we meet as countries relax restrictions and open up for travel: a chance for people and our economies to breathe after months of lockdown. But this is an opening which comes, as we all know, with considerable risk. Whilst no one knows with certainty how the coming weeks and months will develop and while it is still too early to speak about life ‘post-COVID’ (I speak of the ‘new normal’), it is certainly the right time for us all to reflect. We need to reflect on the painful lessons we are learning. We need to reflect on the areas we need to improve and where our actions should be strengthened to protect the EU from future cross-border health threats. And we need to reflect on what the EU’s role in health policy should be more broadly, in respect of Member States’ responsibility for their health policy enshrined in the Treaty. Next week, on 15 July, we will present an Action Plan setting out a number of immediate short-term actions to help EU Member States prepare for and manage possible new outbreaks of COVID-19. I want to be absolutely clear: a full-blown second wave is, unfortunately, not inevitable. It is, however, up to us to control it and prepare, if and when it comes. Our actions should focus on reducing the burden on health systems, particularly if new outbreaks coincide with the influenza season in the autumn and winter. COVID-19 has shown us very clearly that a united approach is critical, but that we must also strengthen the EU’s current preparedness and response mechanisms to better protect the health of our citizens. Many, including members of this House, and our citizens, have called and are calling for a stronger role for the EU on health. I cannot but agree, and say that I stand ready to work on this together. As a first step, we should increase our capacity to support Member States. This will require stronger and more operational EU agencies. In the coming months we will be proposing to strengthen the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, to improve its coordination capacities and its mandate to respond to health crises. We will also be proposing to strengthen the European Medicines Agency to ensure it can effectively coordinate our actions in preventing medicine shortages. We also want to look at how to strengthen our EU framework on cross border health threats. Beyond the immediate priorities, now is also the right moment to reflect on the EU’s competences in the area of public health, and its limitations. I, for one, have, from the very beginning, said that we need more Europe in the area of public health. The Conference on the Future of Europe provides an excellent forum to really debate this, whether we need to look again at who does what between the national and the European level, and particularly so as regards threats that touch us all, regardless of borders. Even within the deepest crisis, however, come opportunities – opportunities from what we have learned. Strengthening the strategic autonomy of our health and pharmaceutical systems is a case in point from the current crisis. With our proposed EU4Health Programme and the unprecedented EUR 9.4 billion envelope we proposed, we send a very clear message that public health is a priority area for our recovery, that we have been listening to citizens, that targeted investment in crisis preparedness and stronger health systems for the future is key. What is now required is very close cooperation and a swift agreement between Parliament and the Council in the coming weeks and months to ensure it can be delivered. I fully count on your support to take the ambition forward. In parallel, and I am very aware of the importance, our new Pharmaceutical Strategy will be coming later this year – an opportunity for us to ensure and reinforce the strategic autonomy of our pharmaceutical sector and ensure access and affordability of essential medicines for our citizens. I have been in contact with stakeholders for this strategy over the last few weeks. The next six months are critical. Now is not the time to let our guard down. The situation remains very fragile, and we see this in a number of Member States. Stable numbers change very quickly. A safe and effective vaccine likely remains the only permanent solution to this pandemic, but this is still some time away. Together with the Member States, we are fully engaged in negotiations with vaccine manufacturers to ensure access to vaccines when they become available. We will ensure that the EU continues to play a leading role in international efforts to develop, manufacture and deploy a universally-accessible vaccine for all Member States of the EU, leaving no one behind, and for the world. We are not going to say ‘us first’. We will continue to support countries inside and outside the EU to protect all people from new outbreaks, especially the most vulnerable. Solidarity will remain key, because it saves lives. And here I just want add that from the beginning of this pandemic, I have held over 26-27 meetings with all the Health Ministers and I am in constant communication with them, because this is the only way that we can build up this level of coordination, consensus and working together so we can deal with what it means to move forward. We need to pool resources, we need to tackle jointly the issues that affect all of us. This is the first and possibly the most important lesson learned from this crisis: we need to respond to the expectations of our citizens, ensuring a stronger role for the EU when citizens’ health is at stake from threats – threats which do not stop at national borders. And we all have a collective duty to ensure that.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which In March/April, at the beginning of the pandemic, I went back to practice like many medical professionals. And the first thing I noticed when I asked my colleagues was: we didn't have masks. I had to look patients with fever and cough in the throat without being able to protect myself. It was a queasy feeling for me. For many nurses and doctors in Bergamo and Madrid, this has meant that they have become infected and that they are no longer alive.  This is one of many examples where we simply need to get better: we must not be so dependent on China and others when it comes to vital things for our health. That is why I am very pleased that we have the opportunity to debate this resolution today. Thank you to Manfred Weber for being here and for supporting the fact that we have this resolution, and thank you to colleagues for their good cooperation. Mr President-in-Office of the Council, we support the priorities of the German Presidency and the proposals of the European Commission. We want to achieve a great deal together in the coming months, but we also want more European commitment to health in the long term. In the past, the Member States have often reflexively said that health is only national, that Europe should stay out. That has always been wrong, and that is all the more wrong now. A virus and other health threats do not stop at the border. That is why we need a European health union.

name: Heléne FRITZON
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his One thing is certain: the virus knows no bounds. This crisis has taught us that Europe is really needed. No Member State can cope with this crisis alone. We need more cooperation and coordination in our Europe. The starting point is very clear. It is the EU Member States that are responsible for public health issues, and therefore also for health systems. But that does not mean that our Europe does not have an important role to play.  From our S&D group, we call for the creation of a European Health Union. It is important that we now learn lessons and aim at how to develop this better for the future. We will protect our citizens and improve access to medicines and medical equipment, so that it reaches those who need it most. We need to strengthen cooperation.

name: Véronique TRILLET-LENOIR
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Minister, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we are going through a health crisis which is a tragedy in terms of loss of life, but which is also a real awareness. So let's seize this unique opportunity to learn lessons together and in a cross-party way. Opportunity to prepare, in conjunction with WHO, our European health response mechanism, already committed, thanks to you, Commissioner, dear Stella. Opportunity, as you said, to strengthen the competences of European health agencies. We need them to be responsive and operational. Opportunity to implement prevention, in particular prevention through education on basic hygiene measures and respect for the ambitions of the Green Pact in terms of nutrition, pollution and global warming. Opportunity to enable member countries to optimise their health infrastructure, while respecting specific criteria so that the European Union does not become a mere cash machine. Opportunity to exchange medical practices and data within European reference networks. We want to see them strengthened. Opportunity to restore our independence for the production of health products, vaccine research and equity of access to the best treatments for all. Opportunity to show solidarity with health inequalities and, in particular, to take into account the most affected populations, also the most affected regions of Europe, and the most fragile third countries. Finally, I suggest, I offer you, to measure the health impacts of all our European policies. This is how we will meet the expectations of our fellow citizens and associate them with our common project of a europe of protective and concrete health.

name: Silvia SARDONE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today the WHO declares that the pandemic is accelerating, the peak is not reached. And what is the European Parliament's response? A resolution on the Post-COVID European Health Strategy. You have gone from responding badly and late to the pandemic to closing the problem: COVID is over, we are already at post-COVID. But that's not all, because in today's resolution on coronavirus you manage to insert a number of things: the link between COVID and climate change, references to the fact that ethnic minorities would be more affected, when instead everyone was affected, especially the elderly, an inevitable passage on the LGBTI world and contraception, which have nothing to do with the coronavirus , and finally an indecent praise to the ESA. But on one thing you are very good: increase the armchairs. Yes, because under the pretext of the pandemic you want to multiply the agencies, task forces and organizational units. In fact, the citizens felt the need for new prams and new bureaucracy. We need answers now, not unnecessary propaganda.

name: Petra DE SUTTER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, it’s actually very sad that we needed a worldwide health crisis to put health at the top of the European agenda, but let’s look forward now. Let’s learn from this crisis and let’s ensure that, from now on, health remains at the top of our agenda. Beyond enhancing crisis preparedness, we should also work towards a real ‘health in all policies’ approach and take action in three other fundamental domains as well. One: let’s focus on prevention, as this benefits citizens and national health budgets. Two: let’s revise our pharmaceutical system to ensure access to affordable medicines for all. And three: let’s reinforce the ‘one health’ approach. Any efforts to work on a healthier Europe are doomed to fail unless we address the interdependencies between human health and the health of our planet. It’s now up to us. Will we remember COVID-19 merely as the world’s worst health crisis in recent history, or will we also remember it as the start of a better European public health policy?

name: Margarita DE LA PISA CARRIÓN
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, as a pharmacist, I hoped that this Resolution on public health would be a technical document, detailing how to deal with this pandemic. And no: it tells us about new organisms, new institutions... Another attempt by Parliament to increase the power of Brussels and take more sovereignty from our nations.  Empty words of content are looped: Green Pact, ecological transition, gender equality, resilience..., mantras numbing consciences, in order to impose a new world order, which Mrs Merkel mentioned today in her speech.  A new world order or a new normality (as it is now called), which is only at the service of supranational interests.  However, our needs are different. In this health crisis, we need clear, precise, immediate protocols of action that truly protect us from future outbreaks, from potential new viruses.  I would like to remind you that the Union is not here to replace the Member States, but to facilitate free, voluntary and, above all, sensible cooperation.  Only in this way will Europe be strengthened; that's the only way we're going to get out of this crisis.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: I will now move to the second voting session. We will vote on the files as indicated on the agenda adopted today at the opening of the sitting. The voting session will be open from 20.30 until 21.45. The same voting method will be used as during the previous voting session. All votes will be held by roll call and Members will be able to verify their votes and the results of votes by consulting the documents which will be published on the plenary website.  I declare the second voting session open. You have until 21.45 to vote. The results of the second voting session will be announced tomorrow at 9.00.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: We will now continue with the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the EU’s public health strategy post—COVID—19 (2020/2691(RSP)).

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank all the other co-authors in advance for their good cooperation. This time, the text of the joint resolution presented really reflects a broad agreement across the political spectrum. Today we are facing an unprecedented situation, and new unprecedented solutions must also be based on this. Old tutorials and corny "business as usual" will not help us now, we need fundamental reform. Health care in the European institutions has always been such a Cinderella, it also shows that around 10 people are doing it in the European Parliament and we all know each other well. The COVID-19 pandemic has shown in full banity that the EU does not currently have sufficiently strong tools or competences to address extraordinary health problems. The establishment of a Health Union along the pattern of other deeper integrations seems absolutely necessary in today's light. However, I am afraid that we are able to achieve something similar with the incoming German Presidency, because it is the German Government that has been blocking for years the completion of negotiations on, for example, the HTA Regulation, which, from today's point of view, is a complete step in the area of expanding cooperation. For me, the question of where we need to move is the joint purchases of medicines by the Member States, at least in the case of those for rare diseases and vaccines. As far as vaccines are concerned, intellectual property rights, such as patents, should not restrict rapid access to them and other treatments. Scientists around the world developing these vaccines and treatments often use huge amounts of public money. Large pharmaceutical companies should not profit from this pandemic at the expense of people's health, and they should not pay for research already paid for with one of the public money. GUE/NGL wants to ensure guaranteed access to COVID-19-related diagnostics, therapeutics and vaccines for all. That is why my colleague Botenga and others launched a Right2Cure petition 2 weeks ago, which I hereby invite you to sign. I will not stretch this out, I beg you to adopt a joint resolution, it may be a good start for the future.

name: Daniela RONDINELLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the pandemic has shown us the need for greater cooperation, integration and solidarity in public health. So this European strategy is acceptable, but at the same time I believe that it is too ambitious and unrealistic because, in order to implement it, we need an unsustainable spending capacity for most European and non-European countries, not to mention the war that is taking place and the business that is being created around the search for the vaccine. It therefore makes no sense to plan new health strategies if we do not first make a great political choice, which sees investment in health, research and welfare not as costs, but as an answer that we must give to our citizens, who ask us to be treated in the best possible way, with high medical and health standards, regardless of the macroeconomic conditions in the country in which they live. The Stability Pact must therefore not only be suspended, it must be permanently cancelled even after the COVID emergency. Austerity is a political virus that has infected the Eu ropean Union and risked destroying the European project forever. If we can defeat austerity once and for all, we will not only make the European Union health but we will also be able to deal with any other crisis at European level.

name: Dolors MONTSERRAT
text: – Mr President, we are suffering the worst health emergency of our lives in terms of health, economic and social consequences. But we have the opportunity and obligation to achieve better coordination and strengthen our health systems in the face of future threats. With the recovery plan we renew our commitment to the well-being of Europeans and to all health professionals to ensure them more protection and responsiveness, both in the face of health emergencies, as well as in the fight against chronic diseases and, for example, cancer. We want a Europe for health, with a health approach to all policies, with more funding in the European budget and with the EMA and ECDC with more competence and with decision-making and coordination capabilities, for an effective response across Europe. This strategy is the first step towards effective prevention, towards more and better research to have effective medicines and treatments, as well as a vaccine accessible to all. We also need to support the health production sector and its activity in Europe, so that it brings the creation of new quality jobs and, above all, autonomy in production. Europe has the best national health systems in the world. That is why we are the reference for health in a global world, increasingly exposed to threats. That is why this is the Europe we are defending, the Europe of health and the Europe of people.

name: István UJHELYI
text: - Madam Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your support. Can our European Union be happy if access to health often depends on who was born where. Can our Europe be united and healthy in the future if health is not a strategic sector for us? As a Hungarian, as a socialist, as a member of S&D, I am working to give our children a European future that is about the European Health Union. For example, in my country, it cannot happen in the future that a Hungarian is three times more likely to die of a hospital infection than in Germany; 6 nurses and nurses per 1,000 inhabitants in Hungary, 12 in Germany. We need a Europe that is united in giving all its citizens the opportunity to live, because it is a human right. Health is a human right. That's what this program is all about. This should be supported, together with minimum requirements and all others.  We do not take powers away from the Member States, we give health to our members.

name: Nicolae ŞTEFĂNUȚĂ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, happiness depends on freedom and freedom depends on courage – that is what Tucidide said. At the moment, European citizens, unfortunately, are neither happy nor feel free, precisely because we have not yet won the fight with COVID-19. I want to offer them, to make their situation better by providing them with a solid European health programme. Commissioner, I am concerned about the budget situation of the EU4Health programme, which comes 85% of that Next Generation EU and on which there are now some suspicions on the part of the Council's legal service. Commissioner, I am also concerned that there are Member States where hospitals - as Mr Ujhelyi said - are totally out of date and there are others where hospitals have five-star rooms. I am also concerned that there are many people who are now looking at us and, although they do not suffer from COVID-19, they suffer from chronic diseases and cannot go to hospital. I believe that we have the opportunity to do, to contribute to the happiness of European citizens by giving them the best health in the world – European health.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: Mr President, the European Union is clearly a relevant level of cooperation in public health. But the implementation of a public health strategy after the outbreak more than 6 months after the epidemic is proof that Europe has failed in its missions, mainly two of them: First of all, anticipation, because the European Union has set up a specific monitoring and alert agency, the CDC, and it is deplorable that this agency only reacted on 22 January , one month after the official information began. The second mission is to provide financial and logistical support to Member States in the face of financial, social and health consequences in the event of a crisis. Of course, the Commission has deployed many legislative financial resources, but all this in a disorderly manner and in a climate of absolute foresight. To call today by this resolution for more Europe, through the creation of a Europe of health, in complete disregard of state prerogatives, is a real attack on national subsidiarity. Thus, the EU, through its three bodies, would do much better to reflect on the health catastrophe caused by the continued opening of borders, in particular the Schengen area. This stubbornness to maintain the free movement of people carrying viruses, by land, sea or air, is responsible for the current disaster.

name: Tilly METZ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, this crisis has shown that, in order to build a fairer Europe, we must guarantee access to quality care for all. For this, we need a Europe of health that allows us to better coordinate in order to invest in a Europe at the service of citizens. And I would like to highlight two points. First, the austerity and crisis of COVID-19 have exhausted our public hospitals and caregivers. Europe must support Member States' investments in our public health infrastructure. Second, health should not be the preserve of the private sector. To do this, Europe must invest and create public laboratories and research centres whose results will benefit everyone and allow access to cheaper treatments.

name: Helmut GEUKING
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Health policy is not a European policy – that has been the case all these years. COVID-19 has taught us something better. Health policy is certainly European policy. We have seen in the countries the state of health systems and how different they are. I come from a country with an excellent health system – I am very grateful for that. I have three healthy children, and when I see screening in other European countries and the standards that prevail there, I say that it is high time to act.  We all need to learn. I think we have learned from COVID-19: these are strategies for the post-COVID-19 period. In other words, we must now learn that we are not only setting up pandemic plans that will take effect immediately – because this will not be the last pandemic, we must be clear about this – but we must also address the health systems in the various European countries to the extent that we create framework conditions that must be taken for granted, for example, framework conditions for the Under-examination of infants and young children. in order to alleviate or completely avoid and reduce misery, hardship and suffering in advance through early detection. After all, we have already entered Europe through cancer prevention, and we must address these issues, and we must create standards here: quality standards that are binding.  In other words, framework conditions, and of course respect subsidiarity. We have found 21 Members from the health service who are prepared to speak out on this. I will try to bring them together in Strasbourg in September.  I hope that this will be the anchor for Europe-wide health policy here in Parliament in the future.

name: Jessica POLFJÄRD
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr It is important that we gather here tonight not only to discuss, but also to learn lessons from the health crisis that we are currently going through, and which we will have to deal with in the future. I would like to raise an issue that is particularly important to me. This is what is also happening, perhaps a little overshadowed by covid-19, namely the presence of antibiotic resistance. We know that some 33 000 people in Europe die from antibiotic resistance, which is something that may actually also be important to consider in the face of future health crises. I therefore welcome the fact that the resolution should raise this and that several thoughts are still being held at the same time. I believe that, through a more responsible use of antibiotics and more research in this area together, we will be able to combat antibiotic resistance. But then we need joint work, we need new technologies, we need joint efforts. However, I look forward to this work together with the other political groups and with the Commission.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the pandemic reminded us that health is a global public good that directly challenges our national security, but has taught us that it is necessary — but not sufficient — to have quality, universal and accessible national health services.  We need to put in place a true European health union that includes minimum standards and stress tests to national health systems; a European rapid response mechanism; strengthen our procurement mechanism and have a pharmaceutical strategy that ensures domestic supply and production in Europe; more funding for medical research, and ensuring the principle of environmental, human and animal health.  More importantly, it's not enough to applaud health professionals every day. We, the European institutions, have a responsibility and a duty to ensure that they have working conditions proportional to the heroic effort they have made on this continent over the past few months. And that is what the European Health Union must do.

name: Kim VAN SPARRENTAK
text: Mr President, we are stuck in a system in which the profits for shareholders of large pharmaceutical multinationals are put above the interest of affordable and accessible medicines. While we are talking about one of the most profitable sectors in the world, the European Commission is proud to organise a benefit concert for the pharmaceutical industry, in which it has also donated EUR 5 billion of public money. The Commission really needs to realise that the pharmaceutical industry is not a good cause. If big pharma really were to care about public health, they could invest their own sky-high profits in a corona vaccine.  This system needs to change and the new plans around pharma give us the opportunity to turn the tide. Create a system of solidarity, promote better cooperation between countries in drug procurement and make it mandatory for drug manufacturers who receive public money to be transparent about development costs. We must finally start making hard demands on how much profit can be made on the backs of sick people.

name: Edina TÓTH
text: Thank you for the word. The coronavirus will be a part of our lives for a while, but we're about to get back to normal. A lot of criticism has been made about the European Union in recent months and, indeed, we must say that the Union was not able to act effectively enough in the initial period and to help protect against the coronavirus. State involvement, regional cooperation between nation states and countries have proved effective. But right now, let's talk about the future. We have a document in front of us which is intended to define a public health strategy for the period after the coronavirus. In this connection, I would like to draw attention to the fact that, in my opinion, we do not need the single European minimum health service proposed by the left, but the maximum health protection of the citizens of the Union. The EU must work closely with member states, support and coordinate measures, as we have seen with the vaccine strategy.

name: Mohammed CHAHIM
text: Mr President, this corona crisis teaches us that we need to work more together in the field of health. Whether it's jointly purchasing and producing ventilators and mouth masks or building strategic drug supplies, together we stand stronger. Stop the hoarding behaviour of Member States and make us less dependent on foreign countries. That's really the least we can do. Yes, health care is primarily a responsibility of the Member States, but we have seen that cooperation leads to the protection of our people and that is why we welcome this new EU4Health programme. One thing close to my heart is the health of our employees. We have seen during this pandemic that European rules to protect workers from diseases at work are insufficient. The newspapers are full of stories of factory workers who have become infected with corona at work, often because they were not given protective equipment or had to work too close together. It's a disgrace. This directive therefore needs to be revised as a matter of urgency, Commissioner.

name: Stella Kyriakides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I listened to everybody’s input and comments very carefully, and I want to thank you for that. A great deal was said and I must say I share much of what was expressed. Peter Liese said that health threats do not stop at borders and I think that we have all been witness to this. He spoke of the situation that we had with PPE when we had the shortages, as many of you have also pointed out, and I wanted to just say here that in EU4Health, as part of our crisis interventions, we have strategic stockpiles not only of PPE but also of medicines and vaccines that can be deployed to Member States for any crisis when needed, because it does not mean that COVID-19 will be the only crisis that we will be faced with. A number of you have said that no Member State can cope with this on their own, and I think that we have all seen this. Some of you have also mentioned the issue of subsidiarity, and I want here to be absolutely clear. Even within Article 168 as it stands now, there is a great deal that we can do. In EU4Health all the actions that are promoted are within Article 168, so there is a great deal that we can do and it is still a game changer for health within the EU.  Ms Trillet-Lenoir used the word tragedy. She said that and I immediately shared that feeling with her because for myself in the last five months, if I may say this, it has never been just about numbers, it has never been about waking up every day and being told about the numbers of new cases and the numbers who lost their lives because behind every number there is a story, there is a person. So yes, we have been seeing a lot of personal stories and tragedies in the last months and we need to do something. We have already mentioned that part of our vision and ambition is changing ECDC and EMA and strengthening our agencies.  As Ms de Sutter has said, prevention is part of EU4Health – prevention, the issue of One Health, the issue of looking at non-communicable diseases as well, and really stepping up on promotion and prevention and building up the resilience of health systems. These are part and parcel of the objectives of EU4Health.  Ms Konečná said that we have an unprecedented situation, and this is why we need an out-of-the-box and unprecedented solution. This is what EU4Health is: an ambitious and innovative proposal that can be a paradigm shift within the EU.  Ms Rondinelli said our European strategy is possibly too ambitious and not realistic. I agree with her that it is ambitious, she is right, but it is realistic and it has to be ambitious if we’re going to be able to make a difference to the lives of European citizens. It is a dedicated programme for the next seven years.  You spoke of better coordination that we need at all levels and of course we must ensure that working together the European Union remains as one of the healthiest regions of the world, so we need to look at it in that way and as a matter of protecting human and patients’ rights as you have said. You mentioned the budget. Yes, we are aware that there are issues with this and we’re looking at it with our legal department, but we do depend on you to support the MMF so that we can move forward and, of course, Next Generation EU because only by doing this are we going to be able to move forward with programmes which are ambitious and innovative such as EU4Health. Last, but not least, Mr López mentioned the issue of health systems’ resilience. This is included in EU4Health, and I also want to tell you that the issue of stress tests are going to be included in next week’s communication. So all in all, you have touched on very many issues which are already in the programme. The way we are working as a Commission,  we are working very closely now going forward with the European vaccine strategy because we are very aware that the virus is still circulating amongst us and no one is safe until everyone is safe.  So with that I want to thank you for your input in today’s debates and I look forward to really working very closely with the European Parliament at all levels throughout this process of change that we need to do.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Thank you for the inspiring debate. I can only agree with those of you who have just stressed once again that the virus does not have a passport and does not care about national borders. In this respect, no one should be afraid of an ideologically charged debate about competences. No one is being taken away from anything – the opposite is the case. In the face of this crisis, we all have a duty to ensure that we better protect people. In this respect, it is a question of regaining the ability of the European Union to shape things that, in a globalised world in the face of a pandemic, no longer possess the nation-state. What are we talking about at the heart of it? I am grateful that we have achieved a high degree of agreement on this.  Firstly, the European Union must help to build high-quality health care throughout the European Union.  Secondly, we need more European sovereignty, less dependence on third countries, for medicines and essential goods.  Thirdly, we need more exchange and coordination. Especially because we were very afraid at the beginning, it is important to learn from each other and from each other.  Of course, it is also important that the institutions of the European Union – Parliament, the Council and the Commission – send a clear signal to the citizens that hygiene and distance regulations must be respected, precisely because we are fighting for a free Europe, for a europe without borders. And it is more important than ever in the holiday season, when many people are still worried about whether they can travel at all, that we are sending a clear signal here too: no one has to be afraid, but we must be vigilant.  Then, of course, it is also a question of ensuring that the vaccine that we hope to find soon – which science, research will hopefully find soon – is available to all people and that we do not exclude anyone here. It is also, of course, a question of us fulfilling our responsibilities in the world and, above all, in our neighbourhood. I am a little concerned that no one mentioned it. It has been said time and again that the European Union is incapable of acting. We have supported the Western Balkans alone, worth EUR 3.3 billion, in the decisive and far-reaching fight against the pandemic there too. Solidarity is also needed here, not only within the European Union, but also towards our neighbours.  I would be very pleased if we could reach a rapid agreement. The German Presidency is very prepared to do so, as far as it can. I look forward to further cooperation and a clear signal of unity and solidarity on this central issue, which is massively moving and still calling for people throughout the European Union.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: The debate is closed.  I have received six motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 132(2). The vote on the amendments will take place on Thursday, 9 July 2020 and the final vote on Friday, 10 July 2020.  Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Magdalena ADAMOWICZ
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Although the crisis caused by the spread of coronavirus in Europe has not yet ended, it is time to draw the first conclusions of recent months, in particular as regards the european Union's ability to take action.  It is true that, according to the EU Treaties, it is primarily the Member States that are responsible for defining health policy, as well as for the organisation and provision of health services and medical care. At the same time, however, the spread of a new infectious disease, which by definition knows no borders, has shown the need to significantly strengthen European cooperation in the field of health, for example in the creation and mobilisation of strategic reserves of medicines and medical equipment.  The same approach should apply to covid-19 vaccines and therapies as soon as they become available. The role of the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, which aims to monitor emerging disease threats in order to respond to them in a coordinated manner, should also be strengthened accordingly. Europeans expect European countries to cooperate and coordinate much better in times of crisis and to have greater opportunities for the European Union itself to respond to cross-border health threats. We must not let them down!

name: Marc BOTENGA
text: In writing. Any European health strategy should encourage the rebuilding of our public health systems. This means abandoning the bad habit of encouraging member states to cut public health care for good. This is the true meaning of integrating health issues into all policies: a break with budget cuts and the commodification of health. The public sector not only provides more accessible care, but also has a huge advantage in primary care and therefore screening. Let's support, restore, develop the public hospital. Let's invest in prevention and screening. And finally, let's avoid privatizing the future Covid-19 vaccine or treatment. Public money funds research and development. Let the final product be public too. Let's take the example of the American inventor Jonas Salk, who discovered the polio vaccine. When asked who obtained the patent on his vaccine, Salk replied: "The people. There is no patent. Could you patent the sun? The polio vaccine has thus entered the patent-free international market. The disease has now been eradicated in many parts of the world.

name: Sara CERDAS
text: in writing. – At a crucial moment for the world, health is an essential pillar for our society. Health is an investment and all sectors must contribute to protecting and promoting health. The European Union has the essential role of defending health in all policies, thus focusing on health determinants, a progressive and constant improvement of socio-economic conditions, and promoting healthy environments and behaviours, and should carry out an assessment of the health impact of its policies. We need a European, coordinated, supportive and united response to COVID-19 and to improve our preparedness for future threats, but we cannot neglect other diseases and health care. The European Union can do even more for the health of our citizens by increasing the competence of its European agencies to better support Member States and collect health data, to have more evidence and information to support health authorities and political decision-making. A short, medium and long-term strategy is essential so that Member States can adequately respond to health needs and improve their health policies in order to contribute to building a more resilient and healthier Europe in the long term and for all.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – The European Union is in dire need of health reform. We need increased EU cooperation to create a Union-wide, future-proof health care system, set common European minimum health standards, and to use the lessons learnt from COVID-19 to propose reforms. First, we must formalise the working methods established during the pandemic and ensure the creation of a health-crisis unit. We also need a European Health Union and Health Care Index to track the progress of healthcare systems. Second, we need to futureproof our medicinal product purchasing system. All Member States should be able to fairly negotiate medicinal prices with industry and avoid unfair competition for medicinal prices, accessibility and distribution. We must also upgrade our pharmaceutical patenting rules which currently stifle innovation and need a monitoring system that ensures that national stockpiling initiatives are proportionate to countries’ needs. We should also lower our dependency on third countries via an updated EU strategy to address obstacles in the pharmaceutical supply chain and to attract back manufacturing sectors for raw materials that previously moved out of the EU. Finally, we must invest more heavily in research and innovation to ensure that our health care systems are always at their strongest.

name: Cindy FRANSSEN
text: Written. – This pandemic must be a gamechanger for our vision of health care within the EU and for our determination to put the EU in the cockpit in the context of such a crisis. We need to seize this momentum.  First of all, cooperation must be the starting point. We must play out the European economies of scale by pooling expertise and resources. The vaccination strategy is a good test case in this regard. But let us continue this mainly in the context of the cancer plan, the new pharmaceutical strategy, etc.  Moreover, a strong health care system guarantees solidarity. Accessible health care is a fundamental right, intertwined with our European pillar of social rights. The place where your crib is located should no longer determine the number of healthy years of life.  Thirdly, protection of the people on the front line must be paramount. Not only the many healthcare workers, but also employees who can be exposed to the virus on a daily basis. Prevention through a healthy working environment is also an essential part of this. Our respect for those who take care of care must be more than symbolic applause.  Let us learn lessons, not only for another crisis, but also structurally. An economy of well-being puts people first and health in all policies presupposes public health as a yardstick in policy decisions.

name: Robert HAJŠEL
text: Writing. – I consider the creation of the European Health Union to be a key step since March, when the Covid-19 pandemic broke out, which highlighted the need to significantly strengthen the EU's public health competences and to intensify cooperation between Member States and EU institutions in this area. Through the European Health Union, we must be able to provide affordable vaccines and medicines against Covid-19, both for all and for the most socially vulnerable sections of the population. Although the greatest effort today is focused on finding a suitable vaccine, we must also focus on finding and researching suitable medicines, especially if we assume that we will not overcome Covid-19 in a few months, but it may appear even more massive in the second or subsequent waves. I also consider the proposed stress tests of national health systems to be a good step forward in helping to detect shortcomings and to check national preparedness for the next wave of the pandemic.

name: Joanna KOPCIŃSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Health policy, the organisation and provision of health services and the provision of medical care are the competence of the Member States and Union action should be complementary. However, the COVID-19 epidemic has shown that in cases of critical risks to public health, cooperation between all Member States is required to protect public health and to coordinate appropriate actions. These unprecedented pandemic experiences identify 3 areas where closer cooperation between Member States is indicated, coordinated throughout the European Union, namely: – ensuring the supply of medicines and medical devices for the EU4Health programme, the New Pharmaceutical Strategy and the EU Medicines Shortage Report, – ensuring the supply of strategic supplies such as intensive care equipment, respirators and personal protective equipment , – digitisation of healthcare: we must place great emphasis on health computerisation activities and on the development of remote forms of care, including telemedicine and efficient data collection, respecting privacy principles, as well as the possibility of efficient exchange and comparability.  Integrating these three factors can bring about a viable EU strategy to protect public health after a pandemic. However, we cannot allow the current health crisis to be used for political changes to the treaty facilities on the pretext of helping patients.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The COVID-19 pandemic has brought on suffering and grief to hundreds of thousands of people in Europe and around the world. It has shown us the limited capacities and pre-existing structural issues of national health systems. In doing so, the pandemic has served as a catalyst for much needed EU-wide health care policies and reforms.  Of course, the EU Public Health Strategy should respect the fact that financial resources and competences in the health sector are mainly at the national level. However, health threats do not stop at borders.  There are many steps the EU can take to better prepare for future crises and to ensure the health and well-being of our citizens: a Health in All Policies approach; increased funding for health research and innovation, hospital infrastructure and health services; strengthening cross-border healthcare cooperation and adequate human resources healthcare capacity throughout the EU. The EU should also decrease its dependency on third countries for critical medicine, ventilators, PPE and ensure strategic autonomy of its supply chains. Lastly, we must recognise the tremendous potential of Big Data and AI in taking health care to the next level by allowing researchers and medical professionals to collaborate and make more informed decisions.

name: Dan-Ştefan MOTREANU
text: in writing. – Once we have overcome the COVID-19 crisis, it is absolutely necessary to ensure the implementation of the 2011 Directive on cross-border healthcare, which sets out the conditions under which a European patient can access healthcare services in a country other than that of origin. A resolution adopted by the European Parliament in 2019 indicates that a significant number of Member States have not correctly implemented the provisions of the Directive, raising certain administrative barriers that considerably limit patients' access to cross-border healthcare, such as unreasonably complicated prior authorisation requirements or limitations on reimbursement. Health can be considered a fundamental right in accordance with Article 2 and Article 35 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, and I call on the Commission to ensure uniform implementation at European level of this directive.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: in writing. – The repercussions of Covid-19 revealed the imperative need for robust, quality, universal and free public health systems capable of giving adequate and effective responses to emergencies. Furthermore, the consequences of systemic disinvestment resulting from the imposition of neoliberal policies, including the economic and political constraints imposed by the EU on Member States and specifically their public health systems, have been clearly highlighted. We reject the covid-19 as a pretext for strengthening the EU's supranational health competences, as such a strengthening would not cease to be based on the mercantilist assumptions that the EU has advocated and implemented, that the Directive on cross-border healthcare is a paradigmatic example. What is needed is to strengthen the public, universal and free character of the National Health Services, through increased investment in infrastructure, material resources and human resources, valuing all professionals. To this end, any conditionality in EU policies that imposes restrictions on strengthening investment in the National Health Services must be put to an end; abandon the path of privatisation and disinvestment in public health services; and reject the maintenance or promotion of Public-Private Partnerships in the health sector.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: Written. – The COVID-19 crisis has clearly shown that we need a stronger European health policy to protect citizens from communicable diseases that move across borders and more compensation for the EU in the field of health. Member States alone will not be able to act effectively effectively in a global policy area such as health, which is why we would need an infectious diseases regulation for the EU, which sets common criteria for monitoring, preventing and regulating communicable diseases at EU level. The new regulation would be science-based and strengthen the resources and mandate of the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC). The regulation should also set a minimum level of investment in health in order to ensure that member states' health systems are well prepared for future pandemics. I applaud the Commission's EU4Health programme, which is an excellent step towards strengthening the common European health policy. We need stronger cooperation in a wide range of policy areas to better protect our citizens, to act more effectively, to keep pace with medical progress and to improve the health of our citizens. This means reference centres for all diseases, the development of digital health through, for example, a common European health register and the extensive takeover of digitalisation, which ensures accessibility for all user groups. We need more effective measures to prevent antibiotic resistance and a common European manufacture of active medicines. Patients' rights should be strengthened by their own directive, which would guarantee access to treatment, the right to effective treatment and medication, the right to rehabilitation and support, and the right to second opinion and treatment in another Member State. It is also important for the EU to play an active role in strengthening who's resources and capacity to act.
